success:
Classic Ap Midrange with some new Weapon-combo

Axe Sharpener and Blackhall Warleader are very good in early game and they can be buffed with a Vanquisher's Blade for snowballing. They also can be recruited by Tavrod, Auric Broker.

Axe Sharpener + Star-Reader's Blade = Sword bring back Axe Sharpener and the entomb ability provide you back another sword. You can pledge at the start of the game with Imperial Loyalist for sword ability ( not necessary).
***each one can be buffed byTavrod, Auric Broker for an Axe Sharpener 15\3 with max buffs***

Imperial Loyalist + Vanquisher's Blade = for Hojan, Crownbreaker,Axe Sharpener,Blackhall Warleader

Imperial Loyalist + Star-Reader's Blade = for Valkyrie Enforcer ( silence effect ) or Market
Imperial Loyalist + Inquisitor's Blade = for Vara, Vengeance-Seeker or another Imperial Loyalist

***Imperial Loyalist + Vanquisher's Blade with additional cost CAN NOT summon Tavrod, Auric Broker***

Market
Burglarize vs relic
Others cards can be replaced

Suggestions are welcome
Hope you enjoy ^_^

Summary

At its core you are a tempo-based aggressive deck centered around Secret Passage and void recursion. Your main objective is to try and connect with your infiltrate units (Teacher of Humility and Amaran Stinger) and push damage through stalled board states using Secret Passage and Heirloom Seeker or 'go wide' with Scorpion's and Xenan Obelisk.

Pledging: This deck has 16 pledge units (Heirloom Seeker, Cykalis, the Burning Sand, Dread, and Moonstone Vanguard) so you are able to turn one pledge fairly often. Unlike other pledge decks (i.e. Ixtun and TJP) you aren't a 'pledge or lose' deck. Your only pay off is Glasshopper and often the passive ability is good enough in an aggressive deck.

Unit choices

Glasshopper: This helps reduce the cost of your 16 pledge units and provide some card advantage. You can aggressively trade Glasshopper off and bring it back with Dark Return to retrigger its ability.

Heirloom Seeker: A great fit for the deck. Adds to the evasion aspect and combos well with Xenan Obelisk. The deck has access to a lot of relics: Disciplinary Weights from Teacher of Humility, Secret Passage, Xenan Obelisk, Kerendon Merchant to get Secret Passage, recurring your Kerendon Merchant or Teacher of Humility from the void with Dark Return or Dread, and using Be Gone to retrigger Teacher of Humility or Kerendon Merchant.

Teacher of Humility: One of the best units in the deck and is your preferred two drop. Use Secret Passage to force infiltrate and Be Gone or Vara's Choice to clear blockers out of the way. Don't be afraid to aggressively use Secret Passage's activated ability to permanently give Teacher of Humility unblockable as you can recur it later from the void with Dread and Dark Return and retrigger infiltrate. You can also use Be Gone to return Teacher of Humility to retrigger infiltrate.

Amaran Stinger: Another great unit and part of your go-wide plan with Xenan Obelisk. It is a great target for Secret Passage in combination with void recursion. This deck triggers Amaran Stinger A LOT. It's not uncommon you trigger it 4-5 times in one game. Retrigger it using the various interactions of the deck (see Teacher of Humility's description).

Kerendon Merchant: This is the preferred merchant since it gives you access to more copies of two of your most important cards: Secret Passage and Dark Return. Can aggressively trade it off in combat to get back from the void for more market access.

Cykalis, the Burning Sand: A staple card in any aggressively-slanted time deck. Provides a pledge unit for Glasshopper. This is a huge threat and if it isn't removed you can often do 15 damage with in in conjunction with Secret Passage (first charge attack, Secret Passage's summon ability, and then Secret Passage's activation). A great target for Dark Return and extends the number of high-power charge units in your deck.

Dread: A key unit for the deck. Ideally, the play pattern you want to achieve using Dread is to play another unit (Teacher of Humility, Amaran Stinger, ect.), use Secret Passage's ability to give the unit unblockable and put it in the void, and then use up to six power to play Dredge (six power usually but cost can be reduced with Glasshopper), use Secret Passage's ability on it, and then recur the unit from the void with a permanent unblockable buff.

Once Dread is in the void and permanently given unblockable and you have drawn another Dread you can start chaining Dread by recurring them each turn to provide no less than an eight point life swing. You don't want Dread to be killed in combat so try and find windows to connect with it. You can also play Dread and not attack with it to use it as an expensive Dark Return.

Moonstone Vanguard: One of the best remaining options for good pledge units. Powerful with Secret Passage to guarantee a card draw and also survive in combat. Great if given a permanent unblockable buff with Secret Passage as you keep drawing with no repercussions of it dying in combat. A good unit to ramp out with Glasshopper a turn early.

Attachments:

Secret Passage: This is the best card in the deck and most games you win involve using it many times. Helps push through stalled board states, allows you to easily gain value using Teacher of Humility and Amaran Stinger's infiltrate ability or Moonstone Vanguard's card draw, and its permanent unblockable activation is great while recurring units from the void. If your units get hit with Permafrost you can sacrifice them to Secret Passage.

Xenan Obelisk: This is part of your go-wide plan with Amaran Stinger. Works well with unblockable units to push through additional damage. Works great with Heirloom Seeker to push through no less than three damage.

Spells

Be Gone: This is an effective card in the deck. Helps with your fixing by providing shadow influence. Clears blockers out of the way for your infiltrate units and adds to the aggressive tempo plan with charge units. Against control decks with non-fast speed removal you can attack with your charge units and then protect them by returning them back to your hand (Cykalis, the Burning Sand being the best at this). Works well with Teacher of Humility and Amaran Stinger to retriggering infiltrate. Also works well with Secret Passage since you can active it to permanently give a unit unblockable, attack with the unit, and then return the unit to your hand before you have to sacrifice it at end of turn. With this in mind, Be Gone can function like additional copies of Dark Return.

Dark Return: Use on charge units by providing additional virtual copies of units with charge. Good in conjunction with Secret Passage after units have been given permanent unblockable buffs. Also great with the infiltrate units since you can retrigger infiltrate. The +1/+1 ability works well with an unblockable unit to push through additional damage. Use with Glasshopper to provide more copies of your pledged unit. Use with Kerendon Merchant to provide more access to your market.

Vara's Choice: Like Be Gone, Vara's Choice clears blockers out of the way for your infiltrate units and adds to the aggressive tempo plan with charge units. I also believe Vara's Choice is a well-positioned spell in the format since there are many Aegis units or other units you don't want to ever enter play along with their full card text.

Note: In version 1.21 the remaining copy of Vara's Choice has been removed from the maindeck and a Banish has been put back in.

Desecrate: The best removal spell from the new campaign. You can mitigate the three damage by gaining life by attacking with Dread, blocking with Moonstone Vanguard, and drawing Vara, Vengeance-Seeker from the market.

Banish: A removal spell to round out the deck. I like Banish because it can interact with a lot of commonly played hate cards like Statuary Maiden, Adjudicator's Gavel, or Urn of Choking Embers. Also nice to have a main deck out to Avigraft in case your Kerendon Merchant gets hit and your market gets disabled.

Powerbase

The powerbase is solid and you rarely have issues with influence requirements since you have so much fixing with your pledge units. Your main bottlenecks on influence are TT on turn two (for Teacher of Humility), SS on turn 2+ (for Desecrate), and to a lesser extent SS on turn 4 (for Dread). Often you don't want to cast Dread until after turn four anyways so this is not a strict requirement on shadow influence.

Be Gone provides additional shadow influence. Although unscientific, the deck has access to 31 time influence and 31 shadow influence counting all the additional influence provided in addition to the 26 main deck power.

Market

You have additional copies of Secret Passage and Dark Return, a way to clear out a blocker out or stabilize with Desecrate, and Banish to interact with hate cards.

Vara, Vengeance-Seeker: Vara, Vengeance-Seeker helps shore up the aggressive matchups and interact a bit more with Aegis units. The lifesteal also helps if you are racing flying units in combat that you are unable to block. A great target for Secret Passage as you are gaining a steady stream of unblockable life. Great with Dark Return or Be Gone to retrigger the summon ability.

Strengths and Weaknesses

Strengths: Like Haunted Highway, this deck is fairly hard for the opponent to calculate how much damage they will be taking each turn due to the high number of charge or unblockable units, and cheap bounce effects. The powerbase is good and you have a proactive aggressive strategy that can punish slow removal and expensive tap out threats. You are great in board stalls due to the number of unblockable units. You are also strong against removal-based midrange decks that have slow removal like Desecrate or Harsh Rule. Rather than trying to use multiple spells to interact with Aegis units you can instead use unblockability to go around them.

Weaknesses: This deck is weak to fast spell removal, silence effects, and transformation effects (i.e. Equivocate) since your goal is to stack additional skills onto units and bring them back from the void. I would imagine that Jennev Peaks would be a bad matchup but you may be able to maneuver around them once they tap out to play a large threat or have exhausted their fast speed removal. As with other aggressive strategies, your are weak to large lifesteal units like Vara, Vengeance-Seeker. You are also weak to fliers. Make sure prioritize you removal for lifesteal and flying units.

Void hate cards are very good against you so be aware and try and proactively answer them if you can.

Version 1.1 changes

Mainboard:
-1 Xenan Obelisk
-3 Vara's Choice
-1 Crest of Mystery
+1 Xenan Banner
+3 Desecrate
+1 Banish

Four Xenan Obelisk were clunky so I have cut one copy. I am experimenting with Desecrate in place of Vara's Choice due to power level reasons but may return back to Vara's Choice. I have made a few changes to the power base to help smooth it out. Added another Banish in place of the Xenan Obelisk but not sold on this change (Might want Vara's Choice instead).

Note on Be Gone: I believe that Be Gone is worth it and the shadow influence gains are even more relevant due to the new additions of Desecrate and Vara, Vengeance-Seeker from the market. Eliminating the ability to return your own units is a large aspect of this deck that I do not want to remove yet.

Market:
-1 Vara's Choice
-1 Xenan Banner
+1 Desecrate
+1 Vara, Vengeance-Seeker

I like having access to one copy of Vara, Vengeance-Seeker to shore up some issues with aggressive decks and Aegis units. Xenan Banner has been cut because I wasn't accessing it that often.

Version 1.2 changes

Mainboard:
-2 Banish
-3 Crest of Mystery
+1 Vara's Choice
+2 Diplomatic Seal
+2 Shadow Sigil

I want undepleted power as much as possible so I've cut the Crest of Mystery entirely. Was feeling the loss of Xenan Banner in the market so I cut one piece of interaction for a 26th power. Banish was clunky so I've changed them to Vara's Choice.

Market:
No changes

Version 1.21 changes

Mainboard:
-1 Vara's Choice
-1 Diplomatic Seal
+1 Banish
+1 Crest of Mystery

Did some find tuning of the powerbase by exchanging one copy of Diplomatic Seal for Crest of Mystery and added a copy of Banish in place of Vara's Choice to have another answer to hate cards.

Future directions and thoughts

You am still trying to fine tune the interactive spells and market choices. A card I am interested in trying is Madness since it combines well with Secret Passage and is a huge tempo swing.

Note on 4/9/2019: I tried out a few common recommendations including three Vara, Vengeance-Seeker over Xenan Obelisk and two copies of Blackhall Warleader over Heirloom Seeker in the main deck. I was unimpressed and was losing more matches. I've gone back to v1.2 with no additional changes as of now. Desecrate has been great so I am happy with that inclusion.

Match History

Since version 1.2 I have added my match history if you want to see the deck results.

I was playing around with an old Argenport Empower list that IlyaK made back in January. It was my first month playing the game and it got me to Masters. I tweaked the list and went 9-1 at Top 100 Masters in the past few days. I don’t have much time to play test this week unfortunately but so far it feels like a fun list.

I really like the new card Ponysnatcher and wanted to find a way to make it work in a deck. Getting the 2 shadow influence on turn 2 is quite easy with this deck so it’s usually not a problem to play it on curve. My main concern is limited card draw and not having market fodder for merchant. I was considering adding 2x Xo to fix that problem and would be interested in getting feedback. This is why there is 2x Dark Return to act as card draw / play back one of your big threats.

I also didn’t include Hojan in an empower list because I was tight on space and did not have enough Renown activators. I’d rather play Lost Scroll to ramp or Ponysnatcher on 2. It could definitely fit the deck though.

The main spots I’m not sure are 2x Regent’s Tomb (it did win me a game vs camat0 by sabotaging his Grasping at Shadows) and 2x Makto (I feel like it was a good additional recurring threat although there is a lot of Equivocate/Silence right now). I’m also not sold on market choices besides Chains and Vanquish).

Telut has definitely been MVP and you can usually get to play him on curve. Always great vs all the Aegis out there. The only issue is that you can’t attack Sites or his effect won’t trigger which makes it awkward sometimes in this Site meta.

I feel like Argenport has potential and would welcome your feedback and input on how to make this deck better.

Thanks!

I used this deck to make masters (Rank 60), and it has been performing quite well for me in the current metagame. Here's a breakdown of my card choices, as well as my reasoning for not including other options:

3x Defiance: Critical for answering an early teacher of humility, and it has utility for locking down lethal charge units. However, it's quite bad against sites in general as it requires the unit to attack. Also bad against Sandstorm Titan and Moonstone Vanguard.

1x Seek Power: Should probably be 2x, but I'm greedy. There are 2 reasons to play seek power over a regular sigil. First off, it fixes your influence. More importantly, due to the way mulligans work you have a smaller chance of ending up with a 2-sigil opening hand when you have non-sigil cards that fetch sigils for you, like seek power and privilege of rank.

4x Strategize: One of your main card advantage spells. Usually just a draw 2 as you can get rid of extra Jotun Hurlers or useless sigils.

3x Vanquish: Very efficient removal when it works. Sucks to have 2 of these in hand against a board of 3/2 aggro units.3-of is a safe spot to be in.

4x Hailstorm: Amazing removal spell, one of the main reasons to be playing Hooru Control. This card will usually net you a 2-for-1 at least, and is good against any deck playing units (kills merchants at the very least).

4x Jennev Merchant: Not the best merchant, but she does the job. I'll explain the market later.

4x Privilege of Rank: The justice version of Wisdom of the Elders. Also has amazing synergy with Honor of Claws.

4x Wisdom of the Elders: Instant 2-for-1. The backbone of any primal control deck.

4x Auric Runehammer: Incredible card right now, the more the merrier. Also one of the only ways to answer Vargo.

4x Honor of Claws: MOAR CARDS (Bear Voice).

4x Harsh Rule: Do I need to explain this one?

4x Jotun Hurler: Snowball is basically worth an entire card in the current metagame. They pop aegis, kill hojans, team up with hailstorm to kill vargo, etc. You also get to put away the 4/4 with cards like Jennev Merchant, Strategize, and Honor of Claws.

2x End of the Story: Sweepers aren't at their best in the current metagame since so many decks are playing 4 copies of Palace. That said, sweepers are still very important for control decks. We also have extra board clears in the form of double Hailstorm, so 6 Harsh Rules works.

2x Channel the Tempest: Not always necessary, since we already have tons of card draw with strat, wisdom, and honor. However, having a big finisher once in a while can be nice. Channel also deals with sites very well.

3x Sword of the Sky King: Our main win-condition. Kills people dead. Nuff said.

Market:
1x Vision of Austerity: Great for answering opposing runehammers. Also great against Rat Cage.
1x Rain of Frogs: Pretty much an auto-include for most control markets. This card single-handedly answers palace. That's HUGE!
1x Eilyn's Choice: Multipurpose fast speed removal and counterspell. Useful against Maul in particular.
1x Eilyn, Clan Mother: Incredible win-con against decks that are low on removal (praxis). Is also a silence effect for cards like Scourge of Frosthome. All-around great card.
1x Aid of the Hooru: Almost always castable in long games, and will win you the game on the spot.


Discarded Options:

Korovyat Palace: Not a huge fan of this card in general. Any decently skilled player will just ignore it and continue to target your life total most of the time, at which point it's just an extremely slow wisdom. We don't have enough units for the rest of the site to be relevant reliably.

Throne Warden: Fun card, but a little underpowered for my taste. You almost never get to curve runehammer into this.

Eilyn's Choice: Yes, we have a market copy, but there are no maindeck copies. The fact that it costs 1 more than vanquish and can only target an attacking unit makes it just worse, since you can't stop cards like Palace and Peak from going off.

Stormhalt Knife: Just not a great card. 5/5 weapon for 6 is a terrible rate, and even when it's free it's usually going to be about as good as a vanquish or defiance. It's just not worth the effort.

Brilliant Idea: Good card in decks that can really lock down the game (Temporla Control). We're actually looking to kill the opponent once we get to 8, so Channel the Tempest does the job better for us.

Martyr's Chains: Why would you play this over Sword of the Sky King? It has the same problem as palace, namely that we don't have any units for it to buff.

Hello fellow gamers!

This is a pretty simple deck that is surprisingly uncommon in the current* meta so I've been having fun getting to masters with it.
11-2 record last 13 games so it has proven it's worth in my opinion.
(*current meaning as of this deck's posting date April 10th 2019)
DECK TECH

Only 6 smugglers because this deck is mainly about tempo and often these guys are better for fetching finisher cards.
Glasshopper may seam like an odd pick since this deck is NOT a pledge deck but sometimes grabbing an extra Cykalis w/ beserk just wins you a game. Don't feel like you have to pledge in this deck though- more so about maintaining a steady board and chipping away at your opponent.

This deck has a lot of different ways to win with Teacher, Cykalis, Moonstone (which is fantastic against aggro) and other cheap reach/tempo cards like Torch, Permafrost, Equivocate and Display of Instinct.

Market has Maul which people rarely expect along with Accelerated Evolution which can surprise opponents as well and get those minions to hit the face. Feel free to tinker with the Market as I typically only fetch Maul and Accelerated Evolution with the occasional spell negation. But often this deck is strong enough to win without much market play.

Currently only running the Seats for influence since curving out is usually much more important than scouting but have not tried experimenting with banners.

That's pretty much it- keep an eye out for board clears and lifesteal and you'll do just fine on that god-forsaken ladder.
Deck has been working fantastically, it stabilizes so well.
First draft for Ixtun Armory, 6-1 so far to start day 1. Need to figure out what weapons are best suited for the meta, Jawbone Greatsword is a weapon I want to slot in.
Played against a deck on the ladder today based of this list by a player named "Specture" it struck me as a very synergistic idea.

I thought ManuS's Hooru Control deck had promise in gauntlet, but I wanted to increase the anti-aggro tools. KCBandit has convinced me that you'll lose to the swarm decks more than value decks. I cut some of the extra card draw and Privilege of Rank. I added in full sets of Hailstorm, Copperhall Bailiff and Savior of the Meek. I'm still deciding on card draw - stick with Wisdom of the Elders, switch to Strategize, or go big with Honor of Claws.

My (with some help from Rhike) take on Hooru Control post Homecoming. Below is a detailed description of why each card or card set was included.

Draw Suite: This deck has a lot of card draw in the form of 4xWisdom of the Elders, 4xHonor of Claws, and 4xKorovyat Palace. This helps you dig for Chains, removal, and power. Privilege of Rank is also a pseudo card draw spell, always drawing you power so you can hit your power drops (and kill stuff with Chains). Combos well with HoC too.

Removal Suite (aggro): 4xDefiance, 3xSnowball, and 2xHailstorm +1 in market. The deck lacks any form of healing so dealing with aggro units as quickly as possible is important.

Removal Suite (midrange): 4xVanquish, 4xHarsh Rule, and 2xAuric Runehammer. You can also contest the board vs midrange with your various units.

Units:
4xJennev Merchant allows for 3+1 Palace plus has built in aegis helping it stick to the board to protect Palace.
4xValkyrie Enforcer is a solid utility minion that generates instant value when played. Mid to late game he's a random unit (well not random, he has flying which is useful evasion) to heap palace buffs upon.
4xSvetya, Orene of Kosul is a solid beater and blocker, card draw engine late game if digging for units to close a game out, and prevents removal spells from killing your board before Palace can beef it up
3xJotun Hurler is a natural 2 for 1 (considering there's 8 ways to pitch either half), and serves as a random unit upon which to heap Palace buffs. The snowball can threaten Tomb alongside Baby Icaria, and of course kill x/1s

Top End
4xKorovyat Palace is the centerpiece of this deck, serving as a way to draw cards, fog your board, and beef up your utility units into game ending threats.
3xMartyr's Chains is the second piece of top end, also serving to beef up your utility units so they can end the game. Chains also turns every single card you draw late into straight fire because power cards are now cost-free slays.

The Market.
Vision of Austerity is the deck's only relic removal (one of Hooru's main weaknesses). Fortunetly if cast early against a deck using 1 touchstone relic such as Obelisk, it can shut down their entire strategy.
Unseal currently sits in the market's flex slot. Useful for countering any number of big touchstone spells like Grasping at Shadows or Parliament. Can also counter Scream/Dark Return from Haunted Highway, and Display of Ambition from FJS.
Hailstorm is the go to grab vs aggro in this deck, since you only have 2 maindeck.
Polymorph on the other hand is the go to grab vs midrange decks just to have another removal spell. Polymorph is especially useful against revenge units or units with entomb (and against Vargo), although its not as good vs units with weapons on them. You can also clear the frog away with your Snowballs.
Korovyat Palace finds a home here in the market as well, doing all the same stuff it does in the maindeck.

As of posting this decklist I am climbing through Gold with it and am 11-3, plus I am also 11-3 with an older version called Big Hooru Control.

If you have any comments or questions about the deck, especially sharing your experience playing the deck if you feel so inclined to do so, comment below, or better yet ping me @14ierophant in the Eternal Discord's #deck_discussion channel.

Deck is centered around Rat Cage and Bloodrite Kalis, to get a huge relic weapon, and using for both life protection and getting control of the board.

Deck is very good when it goes of, but I am still working on getting it to do that, consistently.

Note: I am a mostly FTP player, and so can't test out everything.

Fantastic deck for beginners. Relatively cheap, though requires 4x Champion of Fury to be playable. Heavily inspired from ManuS' Skycraggo

Strategy: Keep it simple. Play one drops on curve and overwhelm opponent with as much damage as fast as possible. Keep torches and perma late game for stronger units. You also always want to attack with your units - you rarely ever have to worry about blocking as you usually outdamage opponents early on.

Core cards
Champion of Fury: Most important card in deck. Fantastic for quick damage and just great overall.
Ankle Cutter: Without him we lose to Titan and Varra every time. Must have 4x imo.
Oni Ronin, Rakano Outlaw: -Warcry buffs are so good early on. A buffed Champion of Fury ends games in a few turns.
Dusk Raider: While a little slow, if you draw a champion of fury with berserk and board is empty, you will get incredible amounts of damage off. Also great for your warcry units a d really any units. The nightfall is also really helpful in terms of providing you with an extra card, which is a godsend for aggro.

Card Explanations
Mischief Yeti: A cheaper version of Pyroknight. While it doesn't have the late game mana sink or overwhelm, it is still fantastic value and synergizes great with the 6 weapons and 4 buff spells in the deck. With this around I honestly wouldn't even bother crafting Pyroknight
Ornate Katana: Honestly just a cheaper version of Longbarrel. If you have that, use it instead. Notably synergies with Dusk Raider though.
Smith's Hammer: A much, much worse Shogun's Scepter. If you have that, play that instead.
Snowfort Trumpeter: A filler card really. Any 2 or three drop that you think is better can go there.
Granite Acolyte: Another filler. Synergies great with Mischief Yeti though.

Upgrades
IXTUN MERCHANT. While some deny the importance of a market in skyaggro, I personally believe that a market is incredible for aggro. This card allows you to get rid of an extra power (you only need 3) and get a much better card instead. Craft 4 of them and put em in place of the snowfort trumpeter and the granite acolyte. Fixes many of the inconsistencies with Skycraggro. Market: Up to you, but I really like warhelm. So neat for bursting the following turn (play a unit, play warhelm, attack with merch + unit). My market: Warhelm, Ankle Cutter, Censari Brigade (underwhelming in main deck in my experience), Cloud of Ashes, and Obliterate. Notable options: Unexpected Results allows you to counter harsh rule or hailstorm.
Vadius, Clan Father: Wouldn't be skycraggro without him. Really solid card, but I recommend crafting the merchant and Shogun's Scepter before him. If you have him, take out one ankle cutter (you have one in market), a dusk raider, and a permafrost and slap 4 of him on the deck.
Shogun's Scepter: So much value. Craft 4 of it and replace em with Smith's Hammer and 2 ornate Katana.
Longbarrel: Craft 2 and sub for Katana.
Pyroknight: Kind of unnecessary as Mischief Yeti does a more than a fine job, but if you really have extra shiftstone, I guess you can craft 4 of them and sub em for the Mischief Yetis. If you already have Pyroknight then definitely play it over Yeti.

Upgraded List

A modified version of IlyaK1986's Auralian Pledge list. I made a single change:

Removed 1 copy of Suffocate and 3 copies of Jotun Hurler

Added 4 copies of Feeding Time


I also made changes to the Market and Powerbase, but that tends to be the case with every list.

Deck Strategy
Most of the time, the deck plays like a Midrange Control deck. The first few turns are spent setting up, finding the influence you're going to need, and keeping the board from getting out of control. Every now and then, though, the deck just jams the gas and comes gunning out of the gate. If Glasshopper hits the board on turn 2 and survives, Severin, the Mad Mage on turn 3 is straight filth.

The mulligan is the key to the game - you need to find a Pledge card in your opening hand, and board interaction is usually key. If the pieces don't line up for a fast start, the deck simply outvalues the AI's deck and wins the long game (especially if you can grab Cursed Prophet Deleph from the Market - I've won a few games simply because of him).

Power
Power Sources: 37 (25 power, 4 Auralian Cargo, 4 Auralian Merchant, and 4 Bear Guard Bayonet.
Influence: 23 sources of all colors (counting Auralian Cargo, Bear Guard Bayonet, and Diplomatic Seal as a source for each color - I also assumed an extra source of influence for each color as a result of the Pledge cards. This assumption is probably, at best, sketchy math.)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.
A different flavor of Argenport Ramp

I based this deck on my Cursed Mill Deck. I thought the primal curses might add something new to the deck but it needs some tuning to make it viable with 3 colors. Because it's far better to force your opponent to keep their cursed units than give them an obvious choice of which they should sacrifice I was finding that Vara, Vengeance-Seeker should probably be cut. This variant uses Permafrost, Winter's Grasp, and Ice Sprite to ensure their cursed units stick around a while. If you can get control in the mid game with these it's just a matter of time until you get the Profane Censer, and Black Iron Manacles combo to end it.

As it stands this is a hot mess right now but it has potential. I think Alu, Death-Dreamer would fit in well but haven't committed to crafting her yet.

So, tried another variation of the Auralian pledge theme. This time, the idea being: go big, or go home. Ultimately, it's frustrating that I have to use Severin instead of a good Elysian pledge card because the silly flyer is just godawful (meanwhile, cough cough, Aniyah, pls.) Just wanted to see if the concept could be done. And, well, it's okay, nothing world-breaking, and ultimately, it doesn't really feel like you gain too much by streamlining the influence demands and playing apex predator and Severin over say, Aniyah and Courier, along with all the other goodies you get from TJP.

Ultimately, it's basically a "can you" play this deck, as opposed to a "should you" play this deck. And you can, and it'll win some games, but ultimately, I think it lacks the bullshit factor found in more refined lists.

Its time to flip some tables!
Much like StarStorm's Clutch Ruckus, the central idea behind the deck is to spread out amplifiable spells over a number of renown-units in order to trigger multiple abilitys with one high-cost cast.

let me introduce the main cast:
Ruckus Rouser: This loveable tableflipper is the heart and soul of the deck. Renowning with an amplified Mighty Strikes or Bottoms Up turns him into a small, red nuclear power plant.
Glacier Shaper: The Yin to Ruckus Rouser's Yang and your main source of defence. Since most of your spells are fast, Glacier Shaper essentially allows you to play an Ambush whenever you need it.
Xo of the Endless Hoard: This guy doesn't really need introduction, but here we go. He's a power 7 dragon that likes to pop Aegises, create value, kill weaklings and soar above the waves in the moonlight.
Kenna, Shaman of the Scale: Since both Xo and Kenna have soewhat high influence requirements and this deck focuses on playing them as early as possible through Rabble Rouser, I put both in the market and draw one depending on my current influence. I prefer Xo, tho.
Bottoms Up (snickers) and Mighty Strikes trigger the Renown of your Oni and Shapers. I hardly use their actual effects. It's more important that they are expensive, spells and hit multiple units.

The Strategy:
Xo and Kenna are usually your winning conditions. Use Ruckus Rouser to play them early. Then use more Ruckus rousers to create loads of power to either
-Turn xo's first Attack up to 11
-cast loads of Spells to beef up Kenna

But wait! There's more. When you can't find your merchant or don't want to spend your precious Shiftstone for some Legendaries, you can still control the board without them.
Glacial Shaper, when renowned properly can churn out a monstrosity of eerie proportions and if you're lucky, a Shingane Firebrand may even one-hit your enemy.

Let's do the math:
Q: Jimmy has 6 power and two Tableflippers on the board and a copy of Mighty Strikes on his hand. What does this allow him to do?
A: Renowning both Ruckus Rousers will grant Jimmy 24 power for one turn. Depending on the board and hand he can:
-Renown F Firebrands and/or G Glacial Shapers to dish out 24xF direct damage and/or G 24/24 Overwhelm Ice Dragons.
-Burn down his neighbours house while creating value with Xo
-Senselessly play spells to transform Kenna into a freaking beefcake. BEEFCAKE!
-Play another Mighty Strikes on any unit and deal out some damage.

Let's get to the Sidecast:
Fevered Scout and Softfoot Burglar are your pawns against Aggro. Given their Stats, that sounds ridiculous and it is not that easy to pull off, but if you have enough remaining power and Parry
Gruanform on your hands, they work quite well for a surprise. Especially in Gauntlet, as the AI falls for these tricks all the time. That being said, they also work quite well later in the game, as you will sling spells left right and center.
Speaking of slinging spells: Sooner or later there will always be the option to play Pyre Elemental for the low, low cost of 2 power, making it a fairly good drop.
Skycrag Scalebreaker is mostly in there because I like that gal a lot. Her renown is quite nice, especially since it stacks when you play a copying spell on her. And her Goad lets you renown any unit for four power or send a Schwarzeneggeresque Monstrosity flying. That being said, her 2P influence can also slow you down in some rare cases.
Kosul Huntsman is mostly a filler, but his killer can win you a game when he is high on Mighty Strikes and targets a low-health unit.
Mirror Image and Sudden Schism can renown your units in a pinch wihile leaving the oportunity to use their ability again later. This is especially great for getting Xo on the board and providing him loads of power the following turn. Whether you prefer Mirror Image or Schism is up to you, though keep in mind that higher cost is actually better in this deck and Schism is not only reminds you of Tool but actually provides you two 4def Ambushs when combined with Glacier Shaper.
Your main problem with this deck will be flyers and the removal spells may help here. Especially since you can crank them up with your Howling Peak Smuggler. And as a neat side-effect, they also act as stereoids for Kenna, the Softfoot Hamburgler and the Scout.
Finally Staff of the Arch-Magister ramps up quite nicely with all your spells and gives at least some kind of use to all the Treasure troves that you have to discard to reduce your hand back to nine cards. I have not yet used it, though.

If you are lloking for some replacements for the two legendaries, anything that can profit from enough power will do. It is, of course also possible to focus on one of them and switch your merchants accordingly. and without their influence demands, it may even be possible to splash in some Time, just so you can abuseMaddening Whisper to trigger all the renown abilities (or even Xo's Ultimate) twice.

This deck is pretty much a first draft and there's a lot room for improvement. Especially since it does not hold to well against many forms of aggo or control (and especially airboune) decks.

And if you're still here: Thanks for reading my ramblings! I'm stoked to see any improvements or additions!

Pretty basic Shadow Mill with Fire Torches and Manacles.
Devour Fallen Oni/Spitefeeder or if blocking some heavy dmg.
Return Deathcaps or baby vara.
Case is to cast Manacles asap.
Eremot for some spell based/armory cleaning.
Burglarize to steal the Chains.


It is pretty self-explanatory deck. Survive and try to annoy the enemy as much as possible.
lack of mass unit removal is my most issue with this deck (ex. harsh rule), but I hate tri-influence decks. So i created 3 different Mills.
Devour is the only card drawing generator in here, so use it on blocks or Spitefeeders. Even on vara if you have Dark Return in hand.

Please comment your feedback and concerns. : )

Edit1. A bit of movement - I discovered Profane Censer which compliments Manacles pretty nicely.

Use Hawks on Solitude or Deathcaps.
Deck is mostly about surviving early to draw Deathcaps and Solitudes. It works surprisingly well.

You can swap Baby Vara's with some Dreamsnatcher's or drawing cards - preferrence. I like Baby Vara's cause it is kill/lifesteal for sure. as well as aegis coverage.

Please comment your feedback and modifications :)

Edit1:I swapped 2 vara's for dreamsnatchers - playing vara is equal to killing permafrozen unit, which is not as good as I thought initially. Left 2 for aegis coverage. Plus some minor changes. 26 power seems better for deathcaps.

Edit2: Swapped remaining Vara's for Profane Censers. I love Baby Vara, but she can't find place in this deck :(

This deck is my variation on Wispr's "Milling in the Name of".

Devour Fallen Oni, Spitefeeder or Crownwatch Press-Gang. Try to make it whilst blocking, but not necessarily.
Dreamsnatcher's are just to gain some HP, but can be a surprise for enemy if not killed before you can use their ultimate (they usually are dead tho).
Avigrafts, because it is awesome.
Burglarize to steal that Chains... I meet Chains in 3/5 games
Rest is pretty much self-explanatory. If you have 2 Solitudes - opt for 16 discards with 1st one, second one will be execute.

You can swap Azindel's Gift with Baby Vara, as this deck is vulnerable to Aegis. Azindel's Gift gave me a lot of surrenders tho.
I am also thinkink of replacing Dreamsnatchers with Baby Vara completely and leaving Azindel's Gift in the store. I have had really REALLY rarely a situation to use Dreamsnatcher's ultimate.


Please comment your feedback and concerns. : )

This is a Divining Rod deck that uses the Pledge keyword to get advantage. Hailstorm is the flex spot in the deck and you can make those into whatever removal you'd like, I just put them in there because I was running into a lot of aggro decks and it helped the match-up considerably. Your big Rod payoffs in this deck are Eilyn, Apex Predator, and Aniyah. Your best target to put Rod on is Imperial Loyalist. Often times Loyalist will pull another merchant for another rod or for the Sword of Unity but you can also pull cost reduced cards from the deck like a cheaper Eilyn if you have multiple glasshoppers in play.

You may be wondering, why the Kosul Recruit? I had Serene Meditant in there before and was not a huge fan of his cost, Reyna has a similar issue of costing too much, I ended up settling on Recruit because it helps the aggro matchup once again.

I had about a 60% win-rate up to masters with the deck. Enjoy!

I updated my old Merchant Combo deck from last summer, taking advantage of the Black Market mechanic to give us a higher density of merchants. We now have 12 Time and Primal Merchants and 8 Shadow and Fire Merchants, so the deck is more about finding a quantity of pieces, rather than trying to draw specific cards, which is an issue the old version often faced. If you're unfamiliar with the combo, basically, we try to get Recurring Nightmare down to 0 cost, play an Iceberg Scattershot, and then slam the free Nightmare. The Nightmare pings the opponent for a single damage, doubles its attack value, and puts itself back into our hand. We then execute this loop as many times as our opponent has points of health, or until they see the writing on the wall and concede. Check out the old list to see the exact card interactions we use to go off.

The Praxis Arcanum is a bit of an experiment, as we only really utilize the cost reduction part of the card in this deck. It's worked out fine for me thus far, and the power base has been warped somewhat to accommodate. Now, even if we never find a Time merchant, if we've drawn an Arcanum, we can use Primal merchant to go get Avisaur, Shadow merchant to go get Nightmare, and on 7 maximum power, just play Arcanum and Scattershot in the same turn. If your opponent isn't presenting any kind of pressure, we can also go off over the course of 3 turns if we get stuck on 4 power by playing Avisaur to bring Nightmare down to 2 cost, pass the turn, Arcanum to uhhh gain 4 health, pass the turn, and then play Scattershot and Nightmare in the same turn.

Things to note:
- Dont't blow your only Howling Peak Smuggler grabbing a Primal card! This deck can't combo off without an Iceberg Scattershot, which presents a unique challenge for our merchants. The cost-reduction half of the combo can be executed with several multi-faction cards, allowing for a great deal of flexibility with merchants, but the Fire part of the combo can only be grabbed with one of 8 merchants, so use them wisely!
- Don't be afraid to play a Crest on turn 3 instead of your first Merchant. This deck needs to either grab 4 cards from it market, or grab three cards and draw an Arcanum, so waiting to build up more cards in your hand before you start to fetch the combo pieces is preferred if you can afford the time.
- You're pretty much only playing Journey Guide on the same turn you play a Shadow or Primal Merchant to go grab Nightmare. Never expect your "dorky" units to survive.
- If it becomes clear that your opponent has a torch or other fast spell interaction, try to pivot into Merchant + Avisaur beats. Even if it doesn't work out, you may just pressure your opponent enough that they spend all their power dealing with the units that don't actually matter
- Play your Common Cause before your merchants! I can't tell you how many times i've played one of the two remaining Merchants in my hand, only to find myself with a faction-less power card in my hand and an egg on my face.

Haaaaaaaaaaaaaave fun

I've been tooling around with this deck since Beta and Defiance finally gave it the tools to be competitive.

Before Defiance, you really relied on the combo of Black Iron Manacles and Solitude for the kill; but sometimes Solitude wouldn't be a large enough hit to finish the job. But Mournful Deathcap changes things. It fills your opponents bin ahead of time so Solitude is almost always lethal with a manacles and you can even just deck your opponent with Solitude if they leave your Deathcap alone long enough.

Deathcap of course also pairs amazingly well with Dreamsnatcher. I think the best opening hand is: Turn 1 Crest or leave up Torch, Turn 2 Dreamsnatcher, Turn 3 Deathcap + Power card. It is entirely possible to win a game with just Dreamsnatcher beatdown.
Shakedown Also helps the Dreamsnatcher of course as well as with the Manacles.
The Dreamsnatcher and Deathcap have really helped the deck avoid getting run over by aggro decks.

The Ixtun Merchants are there because the Manacles can really hamper control decks and reanimation decks, so you want to make sure you've got that online as much as possible. And of course Bore can be an absolute savior.

Naturally the removal suite changes with the metagame. Devouring Shadow usually gets -3 to -5 by the time you've got something worth casting it on. In Cold Blood synergizes with Dreamsnatcher and Manacles against Justice cards.
I've cut back on Devastating Setback since adding Ponysnatchers; sometimes its a 4 for 1 and sometimes its an overpriced Sabotage. I've swaped it for a Stray into Shadows in the Market since Stray doesn't cripple opposing boards as much right now.

The Treacherys could come out though I'm generally happy with them and they help with the drip damage that the Manacles do.

When reireibarker posted about his storm (https://www.a-space-games.com/storm) combo deck awhile ago, I played with it a bunch. It was super cool and fun when it worked, but very inconsistent. I've been playing it again and this deck is the result of the changes I've made(it is still inconsistent and dies to anything that can attack for lethal by turn 5).

The basic idea is get Calderan Cradle into play, then play a bunch of fast power, a Tamarys, copy the Tamarys, then loop free draw spells, filling the board with dragons. This version of Storm has basically no interaction, and is just focused on comboing off.

Excavate - The main function of this is to act as extra copies of End Of The Barrel, though sometimes you'll get back a dead smuggler or draw spell.

Research Assistant - Fixing, ramp, tribute enabler for End Of The Barrel, plunder target, banner turner on-er, this cheerful friend does it all.

Cull the Deck, Quarry -The main difficulty I had before was fizzling out of draw spells on the combo turn, so I splashed shadow just for these. The influence requirements are FFPPTTS, but you don't need FF til your combo turn(Barrel), and the TT is optional for the monolith in the market, PP is just for wisdom, so hitting influence is almost never a problem.

Plunder - Perfect in this deck, functions as a free draw 2 that triggers Cradle 3 times.

Strategize - if using before the combo turn, the main things you want to tuck back are Xo, excess Tamarys, or excess mirror images.

Mirror Image - Remember it will cost 2 after you play out a Tamarys. It's generally better to use additional ones to copy more Tamarys rather that dragons, so that any End of the Barrels drawn net even more power.

Wisdom of the Elders - If you need to burn a draw spell before the combo turn to dig, this is generally the first choice, as it is actual card advantage(to help smuggle away stuff) and won't be free with double Tamarys when you go off.

Tamarys, the Geomancer - Your opponent can disrupt your combo with fast removal, but this mostly means to try to watch out for equivocate and display of instinct. Non Elysian based decks don't usually have fast removal that affects Tamarys. Avoid running her out there before you're ready if at all possible.

End of the Barrel - Sac Research assistant before playing. When tributed, you can play your first Tamarys before playing the second Barrel/Excavating, because tamarys will make the second Barrel cost 5.

* MARKET*
Calderan Cradle - Always the first thing grabbed

Sudden Schism - Emergency 5th copy of Mirror Image.

Riddle Game - Hand reload. Given the draw density of this version of the deck, you don't necessarily need this, but it feels sweet when it draws like 15. Very hard to have enough power for though.

Etched Monolith - Allows you to OTK with a board full of Charge Dragons.

Equivocate - Emergency Removal


My win rate in Casual with this is maybe 30%. And a portion of this is from people snap conceding after I've played two Tamarys and drawn a few, perhaps not realizing that it is far from certain that I've won.

Have any ideas or questions? Are you playing an Icicle Marksman/Hunters Harpoon version? A more controlling version with hailstorms? Let me know in the comments.

Main Deck
the idea of the deck is to make the herald cheaper with either stone shaker or quarry if you are lucky enough to have it as a one of the two choices so you can play it earlier and cheaper, and more importantly making all your units cheaper so you are able to play two units a turn more easily as this is how the combo works most effectively. play out the scattershot have mirror image in the void by either playing it earlier in the game or putting it into the void with herald song or nocturnal observer, and then play out westwind - if you have to wait till next turn to play westwind it gives the opponent a chance to kill the scattershot and this unit is the enabler for the deck allowing you to deal damage without attacking. There is a back up plan as, if or when scattershot dies then you can scream it back into play then play a herald the same turn for 7 power (non down costed) and try to combo again

My initial idea was to play basically the following strategies:

1) Inspiring units to get Berserk through Dusk Raider during the early stage to lead mid/late game
2) Early board control or taking lead in damage race with Kerendon Steward. Siraf's Beacon for more bonus if your units on board reaches 3 or more with rats.
3) Using Blood Quill to recover life by attaching with Berserk units mid/late game
4) Haunted Scream to finish the game with one of the Berserk Units or follow up with Dark Return to finish with a unit that gained charge and flying.

Taking note of some of the common/uncommon cards that performed well:

- Dusk Raider
- Blood Quill
- Kerendon Steward
- Civic Peace Keeper

One of the key concepts in draft is to analyze which factions are available at an early stage and collect the cost-friendly, high-tier commons and uncommons. In this context It was fortunate for me to get a good number of Dusk Raiders and Kerendon Steward. I almost always try to get Civic Peace Keeper these days if I am playing Justice as it is one of the best Empower Skills for late game out there.

The deck's goal is only to deal spell damage.

I don't think this deck needs a guide.

Deck needs refinement, all comments and advices are welcome !

This is based on LocoPojo's Orene Eilyn deck. I started with his list, then tweaked it as I played from Gold 2 to Masters (I was the 16th person there this month). This is what I ended up with, but I'm still testing modifications. The basic idea is to use Hojan, Icaria, Bear Guard Bayonet and Copperhall Bracers to ramp into bombs. It's very proactive as all the interaction is in the Market or on Weapons/Units.

Strats

The strategy is pretty straightforward, but it can be kind of tricky to execute sometimes. The main important thing is ramping/fixing as the deck is filled with expensive bombs but runs 25 power and no Seek Power effects (although it does have 10+ pledge units). For example it's usually correct to wait until 3 to play Hojan if you have a Bayonet. It's also usually right to grab a power from the Market if you already have a 6+ drop (or even a bunch of 4+ drops) ready. The main exception to this would be if you really need a specific answer like Defiance or Vision.

The deck is packed with bombs so making the game go longer is usually the right play. You can have some very explosive draws, but usually you're just trying to ramp, stay alive, and stay even on board until you can start playing 5+ drops to win.

Generally you want to redraw (to 7 not 6) if you don't have pledge but there are plenty of very keepable hands without it. If you have a good proactive curve, especially if you have some ramp or a Merchant, then it's fine to keep a no-pledge hand.

Nearly all the interaction is on Weapons/Units so you have to be careful about how you use your threats (since they're also your removal). Knowing the matchup is pretty valuable as things like knowing when to use Enforcer as a 3 drop 3/3 vs a Silence can win or lose you games. All of the interaction is like this but some more than others - 8 drop Eilyn is always going to have a good target (but sometimes you want to save her for a site). The main cards to really think about using this way are Enforcer, Vanquisher's Blade, and the Merchant (especially if you're running Harsh Rule and/or Vanquish).

The main important Market cards are Defiance, Banner, and Palace. They were super excellent and I'd never change them. Vision of Austerity is probably not useful often enough to be worth, but it's also meta dependent. Eilyn was somewhat useful but I don't think she's really necessary. Harsh Rule, Vanquish, and Auric Runehammer are on the top of my list for Market cards to try. Right now I'm testing Harsh Rule and Vanquish instead of Eilyn and Vision and it seems pretty alright.

Cards

Korovyat Palace is goddamn ridiculous, usually it's what you use to win. Theoretically Svetya is great for the deck with 35 units but it's actually pretty hard to get through the Agenda without winning the game, I think I only got to her once. Every Agenda card is great, although Sack the City is definitely the least useful. But playing Palace as Sack the City to deal a bunch of extra damage and/or force some bad blocks is a common wincon. Sometimes you need to use the Site as Wisdom + a distraction, but that's usually a last resort.

Reyna, the Unwavering and Amilli, Cloudmarshal have both been pretty nice. The extra Pledge from Reyna is great and she's straight up impossible to kill (or much harder) for a decent number of matchups. And if not, a 6 drop 6/7 with Endurance is usually pretty strong. Amilli is just a nice synergy card. He's a Valkyrie for Icaria, a good cheap blocker, and a one card wincon. Plus he's crazy good with the site.

If you don't have Reyna or Amilli (or you want a more aggressive build), the 4 cost Svetya would be a good replacement. In fact, I'm testing 4 of her instead of Reyna and Amilli right now. I'm still not sure if it's better overall but it's definitely better in some ways. Silverwing Courier is another potentially good option, the Pledge synergy is obviously nice but it's also a Valkyrie for Icaria. It's very possible the Courier is the best card for that spot.

Both Eilyns have been great, the only one I'd cut is in the market. And it's probably worth putting her back in the main. Eilyn, the Rising Storm is definitely better as a wincon, but Eilyn, Clan Mother isn't strictly worse. A lot of games end with you beating them down with a succession of Eilyns. Generally you want to play them proactively, it's rarely worth waiting for a good target. The main exception is if you have other bombs that can win like Palace and Amilli to soften them up first, or if you know they're going to play a Site or some important unit.

Linebreaker's Shield and Vanquisher's Blade play similar roles but neither is always better so I think 3 of each is correct. The main reason you want them is the 2 cost 2/2 weapon part. Copperhall Bracers is nice redundancy for all the main themes of the deck. It's ramp, a renown activator, an attack buff, and a way to convert a decent board into a strong advantage. But it also kind of clogs up your hand, and it's not really the best at any of those things, so I think 2-3 is the right amount. Bear Guard Bayonet is actually pretty nice without Pledge as a way to give random huge units some evasion or buff a Borderscout, but it's still pretty mediocre. However with Pledge it's absolutely nutty and well worth building this entire deck around.

Shadowlands Borderscout wouldn't be in the deck without pledge (unless it had better stats), but it's actually amazing and low-key one of the best cards in the deck. Obviously when it gets to stick and draw a bunch of cards you'll probably win in a very commanding fashion (if you weren't already). Even drawing one card with it is nice, But the real reason it's great is it gives the deck another angle of attack as well as yet another must-answer threat to overload their removal. A Borderscout is extremely threatening regardless of its attack damage, your opponent's life total, and even board state to some extent. Basically, playing it forces your opponent to spend cards/power interacting with you unless they're very far ahead. The deck wants to be the aggressor as much as possible, so this is extremely valuable to regain the initiative or keep them on their back foot.

Overall the deck feels really strong. I'd say it's probably the best Hooru deck I've played so far, and one of the best ways to use Palace. The meta is obviously in flux but I'd say something like this will probably be tier 1/2 once it settles. Adding Fire or Shadow might make the deck better, but I'm not sure exactly how I want to do that and this version is very strong already.

My version of LocoPojo's deck Tempest Tantrum. All shadow cards are removed and this is a pure Elysian deck now.

The main idea behind the deck is to play some awesome pledge cards: Moonstone Vanguard, Eilyn, the Rising Storm and Apex Predator. Glasshopper creates more copies of the pledged card, and makes all of them cheaper.

Journey Guide, Nesting Avisaur and The Praxis Arcanum in the market make cards cheaper, and Trail Maker, Auralian Merchant and Eternity Core help ramping.

Lunar Magus is a good 3-drop and helps with life gain. Nightfall from Dusk Raider and Twilight Hunt goes well with it.

My take on Hooru Ramp. There are tons of lists out there so look around and find what works for you best but this has been the best list I've played to date. The balance between pledge/ramp support and midrange threats + late game value seems very good to me.

Merchant - If you're intending to play ramp then I don't see a case for Jennev Merchant being better than Winchest Merchant. You lose Savagery and maybe a few other cards but gain access to Martyr's Chains and Vanquish or Harsh Rule.

Units - Once again, if you're playing ramp then I don't see too many flex spots for units as the ones with pledge are pretty much essential. I suppose you could flex Imperial Loyalist for Shadowlands Borderscout. That said, Icaria, Valkyrie Captain has been one of the best performing cards in the deck for me - I've won a lot of games from opponents ignoring her for too long and her turning into beater very quick. Valkyrie Enforcer is another card that has performed super well for me. Silence is very good right now and playing it on curve adds to pressure which is ideal for this deck. Silencing opposing flyers so yours can get through and being able to turn off Vargo Redclaw or Vara, Vengeance-Seeker in a race is great. Eilyn, Clan Mother has also been great for me and probably better than Telut, Queen's Hand even though I've been very tempted to see how Telut performs here.

Removal - I think you need to run 3-4 Vanquisher's Blade in the main here. It renowns/buffs a unit while serving as great removal and providing the extra anti-graveyard benefit. I haven't needed any Defiance so far but that's another card that could be good if you want to try it out. If you do try it I would suggest you use it in addition to the Blades, not in place of them.

Fluff - I'm not sure if Copperhall Bracers should be something else. It's very likely. I could see adding in some removal or a couple of Honor of Claws in that spot.

Questions and critique is always welcome

A revised Hooru list from the one I used last season. Feels stronger overall but some stuff still needs to be fleshed out. I feel like there are more Shelterwing+Palace shells to be explored, but for now this and TJP are likely the best ones.

Big Spells and Diogo Málaga, Elonze.

This deck ramps up to 6+ power to amplify Diogo and potentially play many spells at once and draw a lot of cards. It has a secondary goal of getting Calderan Cradle from the market asap and pumping out dragons.

Echo spells have a great synergy with both Diogo Málaga, Elonze and Calderan Cradle. When an echo spell has Destiny, both copies will get played, which means you also get to draw two additional cards.

Moment of Creation quickly becomes massive and often plays for free from Destiny. You'll also ramp enough to play Channel the Tempest if that too doesn't receive Destiny.

Playing Diogo Málaga, Elonze on 6 power is fine, but if you think you will reach the next even number by next turn, I usually wait. Amplifying two or three times makes a big difference but it's still very good with just one:
-Torch is usually the worst card to hit, followed by Equivocate (unless you happen to need it).
-Find the Way and Unstable Form, will draw you a couple of extra cards, with the latter being especially good if you have Mind Link going.
-Wisdom of the Elders is like drawing three cards.
-Moment of Creation and Channel the Tempest are obviously brutal cards when free.

Using the free Mirror Image on a turn after Howling Peak is played, can get you massive amplifies on Diogo.

Still a work in progress. May swap out Mind Link for Kaleb's Choice.
all credits to gozuuu, who piloted it to master 3 days ago

Ever wanted to complete the 'deal one million damage' achievement? What if I told you it could be done in one game? The following is probably the most efficient way to get this achievement. What I have here to offer is more of a strategy than a set-in-stone deck; It can be adjusted based upon your budget needs. Let's talk about what is absolutely necessary for the strategy to function

1: 1 copy of Talir's Unwinding
This card is absolutely pivotal to the deck's success. It shuffles both players' decks, allowing the game to continue for a much longer time (and it's going to be a very long game). Its "your opponent draws 7 cards" clause makes it seem so useless, but that is exactly why It's good here. More on that later.

2: 1: Access to the Azindel boss fight at the end of the Vara campaign.
Starting with a high power count makes this much less tedious than if you were to try to get the achievement vs. say, a gauntlet opponent. You will actually need to have the into shadow campaign anyways in order to use the card:

3: Messenger Hawk
Since Talir's Unwinding has voidbound, we will need a way to put more copies into our deck in order to play infinitely.

4: A set of merchants that can fetch your Talir's unwinding.
Since Azindel has ways to discard the top of your deck, it is safer to put Talir's Unwinding in the market. My only advice is to avoid Auralian Merchant because it has no attack, and you will need to have units that can attack to get the achievement.

5: At least one copy of Martyr's Chains This card allows us to get our units to 999/999. More copies is always preferrable, as it allows you to set up your damage engine faster, but once you get going, having more doesn't affect it at all. Remember that you can get a copy of chains in one of the theme decks for 2500 gold if you don't have one.

6: At least one copy of Scourge of Frosthome
this is important because it prevents Azindel from interacting with our units or relics, and ensures that he will do nothing but put units on the board.

7: tutors, cards that let you search your deck for other cards.
The most important one is Display of Knowledge. This lets you grab chains from your deck, and later in the game it lets you swing into deadly units, and use it as a fast spell to give your unit quickdraw-- keeping it alive. Celestial Omen and Rise to the Challenge are also great.

8: a few non-evasive bodies to fill out your board. Prefferably cantripping ones like Temple Scribe and Heart of the Vault because they make it easier to get your set up early. It's important that these units can be blocked by opponent's so you don't win the game. Putting at least one lifesteal unit in your deck can be important so you don't die to nightfall.

9: more cards to fill out your deck so you have 75 cards. I like Frost Talisman because it stabilizes early and you can use your 50 power to dig through a lot of your deck. Card draw in general is nice.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Strategy
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Before you begin, check the achievements page. See how much damage you need to do to get the achievement and divide that number by 999. Remember the number.

Mulligan for a hand with a good number of combo pieces/card draw. Azindel will go first, so remember that you can use your cards like Display and Celestial Omen on his turn.

Put a Scourge into play as quickly as possible. You really don't want azindel breaking your chains because you will have to use Talir's Unwinding to get them back.

Build up your board to stop his attacks. During this time, get as many chains into play as possible. Remember that if you only have one Chains, you can use a hawk to put more into your deck. Remember also not to play power once you have chains down unless you need to do so to stay alive.

Once you have some 999/999 units on board, you can start attacking. Remember not to attack with more units than he has blockers, or else you will win.

Use Messenger Hawk to make copies of Talir's Unwinding, and then play it. This will give your opponent 7 more cards on his turn so he can build out his board. This will allow you to attack again. Count the number of times one of your unit attacks so that you don't play for too long or not long enough.

use hawk on talir's unwinding enough that there are a lot of talir's unwindings in your deck, but not every single card. You want to be able to cast this almost every turn. Once you have a comfortable number, use hawk only every 4 times you reshuffle.

Attack the sufficient number of times, and then kill azindel. You have gotten the achievement!

First impressions:
I know it's early in the season still but I've been tearing through Gold and Diamond with this deck. The idea was to prey upon all the new Ixtun decks that want to play Vargo. Anyways, the deck feels pretty good as of right now because it can be aggressive while still putting up a solid fight against aggro. I don't know. Still testing the deck. Don't know exactly how I want to tune it yet.

Palace is really good in the market.

On Second Glance:
This deck feels incredibly strong with the current meta though I'm uncertain how long this particular meta will last. Rakano aggro is already very good as a much up due to giving our growing units killer. The midrange match-up feels very draw dependent as we usually can out aggro them with the value game dependent on whether we draw a merchant. Suggestion welcome on that front. Funny enough, I keep finding other people on ladder who are playing this deck and that's super funny. Your best units all do very poorly against defiance and I'm considering adding Stand Together somewhere in this deck. Not sure where. Probably gonna replace Savagery
Not sure what the Vault should be, I never really want it.

Currantly 14-5 on ladder going from silver 2 (start of the new season) to gold 2 in 3-4 hours over the last couple days.

So basically with Korovyat palace being a thing i wanted to make a deck strictly to abuse withstand (SO DUMB) dark return being the biggest hitter in this deck without a doubt.

Your main wincon is deathtouch unit+flyer+palace.
Deathtouch unit is just another layer of protection for palace, if you can use withstand and sack the city whilst having a flyer you'll more often than not win before seeing wisdom.


Tips and tricks.
As stated dark return will be your best friend, if you play it right.
Dont be afraid to make subpar trades or even chump block especially with valkyrie enforcer or merchant its better to save some life or remove a threat knowing you can return what you need whenever.
Plus baiting out more board commitment by chump blocking can make harsh rule plays that much sweeter.
In all honesty you'll probably not attack with ripknife assassin very often, he's mostly a ground blocker for palace but dark returning him IS a good play, dont be afraid to do so.
Winter crown+flyer is incredibly difficult to deal with, but make sure to hit with the flyer BEFORE playing crown otherwise theres a good chance it'll get equivocated.
And before anyone asks no Vara and Palace really dont clash that much, sure losing the eagis sucks but giving Vara +4/+4 is awesome and if you're really wanting the aegis just make a trade with Vara your opponent cant pass up.
The market looks pretty wonky but this isnt a combo deck everything in there is reactive to what the board looks like so playing merchants before knowing what you need is foolish.
Madness is a weird market card but its really just a game ender, soley responsible for at least 6 different wins, you'd be astonished at how many times it can just steal the game (pun heavily intended lol)
Dizos office will be grabbed 9/10 times for cut ties but the lifesteal can come incredibly clutch with a flyer on board.
Desecrate and grasping at shadows are just to fill the little niches, theres an argument for last chance instead of grasping but thats entirely up to you, personally ive been loving grasping cause voidbound can be back breaking if you NEED to dark return that unit again but with harbinger being the only unit with a higher cost than grasping -shrug-

Match-ups.
Aggro isn't the worst, this deck has incredible longevity as long as you can get a couple blockers, merchants/assassins and a flyer its usually pretty hard for them to break your wall.
Its important to get your 7th power ASAP cause dizos office will seal the win 9/10 times.
Midrange is probably your hardest matchup, especially the pledge decks that are running around.
Lean on lost scroll to ramp and your deathtouch units to ward off early plays and hopefully get a harbinger+palace on board, otherwise theres a good chance they'll out pace you.
And lastly with control you really want to play the card value game.
Assume they have a board wipe the whole game so dont commit more than 2 units at any given time.
Winter crown and burglarize really shine in this matchup; they play a pit? Steal that crap, they have +2 card advantage on you? Start getting a free draw end of turn.
It can suck if they chain brilliant ideas, a good rule of thumb is if they have +6 card advantage it might be time to cut your loss and get on with the next game.

Hope you guys enjoy it as much as i have :) cheers.

Updated 4/5: Includes Vara... because we're in Shadow. Also, I somehow missed that I had teched the deck way down; Aurialian cargo is not necessary.

This is a board based deck that uses the new Homecoming pledge synergies to flood the board with damage and generate card advantage with Severin, Glasshopper, and Dread. This allows you to fight for board with aggro while outlasting them in the midgame.

Also, it feels like Severin is being overlooked even in Glasshopper decks which is a shame because he does a lot for Auralian in terms of color fixing, mana cheating, and just general relic pressure. Also, if you have the Homecoming campaign, this deck is relatively budget friendly.

Unfortunately for these type of board based tempo decks, there are too many strong counterplay options, and control decks win the day in Eternal, but it's still fun to play with.

Basically, the strategy is to always mulligan for pledge with the best options being Severin for color fixing or sometimes Moonstone Vanguard if you can pull it off without sacrificing Auralian colors. Always, ALWAYS pledge turn 1. Then just hit the board as fast as possible using Cykalis to push even more damage. One thing to note is that Lethrai Hideaway is the only relic which really ties the deck together providing an extra unit, cheap buffs with Severin, a buff for the smuggler, and ultimately a win-condition with Borderscout.

I've found Cirso's Cleaver to be a surprisingly powerful finisher for this deck, so I feel like it is the most important card in the market. Beyond that you have a lot of different options, but this is my best iteration so far.

Pledge decks work by pledging a card and essentially adding 3 more copies to your deck with roach. So I’ve trimmed up some lists to utilize the best pledge units in my opinion. (As well as 2 Legion Loyalist for consistency and combo plays)
Notable plays!
Hojan+Bayonet=+2 power.
Eilyn getting berserk off palace is usually an instant win.
Sculptor+Palace=draw 5.
Downsides!
If you don’t open a pledge unit, your entire deck can be shut down pretty hard so mulligan for the pledge units. Even going down to 6 to get one still means you’ll be rewarded in the long run through roach.

Description
Low on curve aggro deck with synergy on spell plays.
It's hard to play, so i would not recommend this for every player. This deck requires you understanding of match you play, continuous count of potential damage and cards you can draw.

Deck Design
- 28 Units, 8 One Drops, 12 Two Drops, 8 Three Drops
- 22 Spells, 12 Buffs, 4 Direct Damage, 4 Cycling, 2 Utility
- 25 Power Cards

Geme Plan
Setup your board during first 3 turns and finish game in one swing. We want few things to achieve victory.
- Play as cheap spells as possible coz we want to play as many of those as possible per turn
- Draw as many spells as we can, this achieved with cycling or some units
- Have units that benefit from spell pays
- Have threatening units that can finish game in one turn
- Have evasion for units to push through blockers

Cards & Reasoning
Units
- Powderglider: good body with so needed buff from spell plays, has an upside in scope of Summon ability, can stun Flyer if drawn later.
- Softfoot Burglar: another one drop that benefits from spell plays and provide cycling spells to chain spells as many as possible.
- Dusk Raider: two drop unit that make our other units quite threatening, also draws cards for us and deals damage to opponent from Nightfall triggers.
- Hotblood Barbarian: two drop threatening unit due to berserk, also provides spell in exchange of card in hand.
- Yeti Snowslinger: two drop that adds spell to hand if dealt damage to opponent.
- Crunch, the Hoarder: fulfills all we want, card draw, threat and overwhelm makes sure we get to face.

Spells
- Jump Kick: Buff + Evasion for our unit, quite good for this price.
- Kaleb's Intervention: +2/+2 and Overwhelm in most cases to push through with buffed unit, other mods are sometimes useful too.
- Torch: blocker removal or face finish, nothing to say more.
- Parry: protection for our units and probably way to deal with blocker or trick opponent into inefficient trade.
- Rampage: main buff that can result into huge damage due to Berserk and Units that benefit from spell plays.
- Mighty Strikes: reason why this overpriced Kaleb's Intervention in deck is because of Amplify ability and Fast speed, this can give two units Overwhelm, but it is still counted as one spell played.
- Read the Stars: cycling with upside, deal damage and draw one more card.

Tips & Tricks
- Snowball, Temper + Softfoot Burglar: you can target your Burglar to get buff trigger and draw spell.
- Crunch, the Hoarder + Parry: you can kill one life unit and deal rest damage to the face, this way you will trigger Infiltrate ability and draw two cards with potential of getting Berserk.
- Play fast buffs on Fast only if possible.

Don't forget to hit that like button.
Leave a comment if you have feedback or suggestion.

Feln Control in 2019?! yeah I know..weird. But I just took this deck to masters. While going back and forth in D1 I noticed alot of pledge decks either hooru or 3f and I wondered to myself if feln had what it took to beat these decks along with the various rakano decks I was facing, turns out it can and I think it actually has a spot in the meta.
Vara, Vengeance-Seeker is a must right now if you are playing any sort of shadow deck - it is crucial to remove aegis from the various hooru decks, esp Withstand from Korovyat Palace
Champion of Cunning - I know it seems strange to play a unit with aegis of your own when you play Vara but Champion is just that good - it still buffs your squad and if they kill this then they aint killing your vara (and tbh vara is usually a magnet for removal as soon as you play her)
Desecrate and Honor of Claws are fantastic additions to this deck - Feln's cheap removal is very specific to what it can kill so happy to have Desecrate here while Honor allows you to dig deeper into your deck for your threats while ditching power or kill spells that you can't use.
I'm playing 4 Suffocate because everything i'm playing against has multiple hits (smugglers, maidens, enforcers, hojans, etc)
Right now im playing Annihilate as my other cheap removal over Rindra's Choice because of all the pledge units being mostly single faction.
In Cold Blood is just a fantastic and brutal card against the FJS Smugglars and Hooru decks so im playing 3 you can interchange this with feeding time if you are seeing reanimator/mirrors/xenan recursion.
Black-Sky Harbinger - I love this card - Its another source of life gain, an evasive threat, breaks aegis, deals with go wide strategies (grenadins/praxis tokens), hits sites and relic weapons.
Dizo's office - A kill spell, value engine, and hard to deal with permanent. You don't get to use the lifesteal effect all to often but the site is still great.

Glasshopper > all

A hypermana deck with a Glasshopper / pledge twist.

I built this to try to combat all the Ixtun Vargo Redclaw decks out there. Stray into Shadow is good tech vs an unaugmented Vargo, while leaving most of your dudes alive.

The deck seems to ramp reasonably well, allowing you the fun of actually playing your Acantha, the Huntresses.

Deck lives for the dream of landing Diogo Málaga, Elonze on End of Hostilities. Once the End of Hostilities is in the void, Tribute a Kenna, Shaman of the Scale to fill your board with 20+/20+ Kennas and draw about 6+ cards plus all the spells in your void.

The combo isn't necessarily a common one to achieve, so the deck otherwise works like a typical Kennadin, splashing Time. Having Equivocate instead of Permafrost has been a nice addition as we finally have an answer to Plate.

You can wait until you see an EoH on top of your deck before playing Diogo, but even if the Destiny doesn't hit EoH, it often ends up being helpful.

I've had good results against all the FJP/FJS decks running around. Still a Work In Progress.
