After trying out a ton of Xenan/Aurelian/other three color decks with Time and Shadow after the release of Homecoming, this is what ended up being the most successful for me on ladder. I'll go through the cards in it in order of importance, and considerations I didn't end up playing.

---
KEY CARDS
Maindeck:

Teacher of Humanity
Cursed Prophet Deleph
Ebon Dune Smuggler
Vara, Vengeance-Seeker
Moonstone Vanguard
Xenan Temple
Vara's Favor
At Least 10 Pieces of Hard Removal

Market:
In Cold Blood
Azindel, Revealed
---

You aren't playing the same deck as me if you aren't running these cards. They all are excellent for various reasons. Teacher of Humanity is good on curve with upside against control, Deleph combos with her. Vara is, as always, real good. Moonstone Vanguard gives you late-game sustain and defends against aggro. Xenan Temple just does a bit of everything--- removes, draws, fucks up Revenge decks. Vara's Favor is great because there's a ton of dangerous x/1 drops being played right now, including Initiate, Hojan and Kerendon Merchant, and the fixing is often key to get to 5 and then 7. Ebon Dune Smugger is great in this deck specifically for the interactions with In Cold Blood and Azindel. The opposing player can't counterplay against a Smuggler on 3 into an In Cold Blood on a Merchant or other key Justice threat on 4, and likewise can't prepare for a Smuggler on 7 on an empty board into an Azindel on 8 that gets you a card immediately. I've won multiple games off both of these. Finally, I've seen some other Xenan decks try to jam as many hard-to-deal with units in a deck as possible and neglecting removal, but sometimes you just need an answer against a Heart of the Vault or something else you can attack through.

---
GOOD CARDS
Maindeck:
Initiate of the Sands
Desecrate
Banish
Sandstorm Titan
Dizo's Office

Market:
Xenan Initiation
Stray into Shadow
---

These cards are all important to the gameplan, but could be potentially shifted around. Initiate obviously helps you ramp to the all-important 4 and 5 drops, Sandstorm Titan is still good and really helps against the glut of flyers in the current Meta, and Dizo's Office does a ton for you but is a 7 drop so could potentially be changed if you wanna go more aggressive. I really like Banish in the maindeck because it's so versatile, but you could shift it to the side if you want, and Desecrate is an excellent card when you have board control but rough in a late-game topdecking situation where the opponent has pushed you below 10 health, which is why I advise not running more than 3. In the market, Xenan Initiation is a staple that can flip board control and Stray into Shadow helps against aggro.

---
FLEX CARDS
Maindeck:
Amaran Stinger

Market:
Passage of Eons
---

I've not been super-impressed with Amaran Stinger's performance in this shell. Sometimes she helps, sometimes she feels like she isn't enough to improve your board position. One of the more dead drops in the deck late game. Passage of Eons is just a personal preference for me over Disjunction, but they could be flipped or Passage could even be removed entirely if you want to keep 4 Banishes maindeck.

---
NOTABLE EXCLUSIONS
Ponysnatcher
Vara's Choice
The Praxis Arcanum
Worldbearer Behemoth
---

Everyone wants to fit Ponysnatcher in their Shadow decks post-Homecoming, but from my experience it only goes off so often, and when it is blocked it's a 2/2, which does nothing for your board position and trades poorly with more or less every unit played in Constructed. Vara's Choice is the card in this bunch I miss the most and wish I could find room for it. Praxis Arcanum doesn't really impress me, it's fragile and the spells are often dead plays, though if you did want to play it you'd probably also wanna play Behemoth and some other on-attack type units.

There are many ways to make Champion of Order work as a win condition.
This strategy involves the use of Strangers. Meditative Stranger is rather weak on its own but it can be a solid blocker with Hearty Strangers nearby. The idea is simple:

1- Play Meditative Stranger
2- Next turn, play Champion of Order and immediately play Stranger's Mark on him. Just make sure your opponent does not have a torch in hand when you play Stranger's Mark.
You won't win the game instantly, but once you have 2 big Champions on the field, your victory should be inevitable.

Unfortunately, Stranger's Mark is a worthless card in your hand unless you have all the combo pieces assembled. So you may have to fetch it with Celestial Omen in the market.
Reunite helps you fetch any stranger you need for defense or combo purposes. Even though Meditative Stranger is essential in the combo, you can still win with CoO alone if your opponent lacks removal...

Quicksilver Mirror and Nostrix are luxury cards in this deck. I think they can be replaced with something better, but I can't think of anything right now. Your feedback would be appreciated.

EDIT: Switched to a Justice market for more consistent control with Harsh Rule

So I wanted to play around with a fun deck and now I'm scared. The deck is currently 10-3 in gold. With the pledge, tempo, and late game decks running around, this deck is set up kinda well. Being able to consistently deal 15 to 20 damage by turn 5 is very good. Tempo requires set up, and this keeps them stuck on the backfoot playing defense the whole game. The powerbase is wonky, but that's more cause I don't have all the crests. You can play around with the market. I went for a more aggressive market running Feeding Time to deal with re-animator and Madness to move a big blocker and go for the kill. Jotun Feast-Caller isn't necessary but Rilgon's Disciple is. You don't need it but i recommend keeping Avigraft its good removal for baby vara. Overall I'm having a lot of fun with it and recommend it for everyone.

It's time to come home (to Master's ranks).
[Update as of 9-4-2019]
Xo has been pushed up to 8 and FFFF now. Understandably. And the metagame is starting to adjust to this particular iteration of Ixtun Palace as well. So I came back to this list and made a few changes, firstly, I redid the market and put 1 Xo in there for continued market cheatyface plays with merchants. Often you want to generate your value by swapping Hurlers out so perhaps the count there goes up to 3 again, I haven't decided. I have added 3 Hammer and 3 Display now maindeck. Display of Honour is surprisingly good even in a deck unlikely to bring two weapons back to use once again, here it also serves as a nasty trick on Vargo to establish board position when your opponents really don't expect a control deck to be running a pump suite. It also grabs Deepforged Plate back if you get blown out, plus bonus goat content. This list is still very much in a great position. The Xo nerf actually kind of helps us, to make some decisions about the maindeck if nothing else!

Original Intro:
I got very tired of playing against FJS so when I saw Vargo Redclaw spoiled I absolutely knew I had to build around him, he gives that deck so many headaches!

So, little did I know that Direwolf would also release an absolutely savage midgame site as well, one that fits perfectly into our strategy: Korovyat Palace. We are going to be seeing that card everywhere, I promise you.

This deck is about pure value generation. We use the tried and tested 8 merchant package together with 1 market Xo of the Endless Hoard and 2 Jotun Hurler, alongside a range of other cards you can ship to the market if they do not fit your board position. We have numerous little two-card soft combos, the most obviously juicy is to make your opponent over-extend with a Vargo out, and then Harsh Rule them. That's often a game ending play, on curve.

People will note there are 4 Torch cards in this list, 4 Defiance, and 2 Vanquish. You can change the removal package to suit your style and your ladder meta. I find Defiance a good draw as the game goes on, and this deck really benefits from a clutch swing play by stunning a beefy dude on the block. I like Vanquishes for easily getting rid of Varas and establishing an uncontested Vargo early on. The market is pretty standard, note that you will quite often be going to get Rizahn because he is degenerate with aegis and endurance from our Site, but pressure plays with our Red Canyon Smuggler are also pretty common. You will be grabbing Xo back a lot too.

Match-ups: So far it wrecks FJS, which is the point. You need to play carefully against Reanimator, you only have one out against them unless you have a mitt full of Harsh Rules. Agro is pretty decent, they will have to spend a lot of resources getting rid of Vargo. The deck plays very similar to Jennev midrange anyways, and has a close match-up against it. The fight here is one for Board control, so getting a palace down with a unit out to absorb that +4/+4 and aegis is clutch.

Happy homecoming!

I will write about the deck later. This shell have a lot of potential, and i think we could make a masterpiece deck with this core.

This have A LOT of synergies
Play Whoppers and win.

Overview
Burn is one of my favorite archetypes in TCGs so after some playing around with both a Skycrag and Stonescar list, I decided to just mash both of them together. Unfortunately, doing this makes our powerbase very awkward (be prepared to sometimes get color-screwed) and slow. The main idea of this deck is very simple; throw spells at your opponents face until they die and pray you're faster before you run out of gas.

We're not running many troops in order to have our opponent's removal be mainly dead draws. All the troops we are actually running have charge for immediate value or have some other benefit (merchant is obvious and ticking grenadin is usually just extra torches to the face).

Market
The market can be played around with but the only absolute mandatory card is Factory Quota. You will straight up lose to lifesteal dorks without it. This card can sometimes single-handily let you beat this deck's nemesis: Vara, Vengeance-Seeker

The banner is mainly to color-fix; all of our good burn spells require double fire and Champion of fury wants double primal

Combust is emergency removal; sometimes we can't let that Deepforged-plate merchant or Xo sit on the field.

Hailstorm lets us blow out aggro or tokens which are rough matchups although Torrential Downpour might be better, I haven't tested it.

Backlash doubles as a burn spell as well as protection against removal or sweepers.

Matchups
Aggro
Cards to grab: Hailstorm, Combust, Factory Quota (against Rakano)
Aggro can be pretty tough; our powerbase is clunky and they can often just run us over as we're color-fixing due to an abundance of depleted power. However lifesteal threats/spells of our own gives us game against aggro decks. Try to keep hands with Grief, Extract, Torch (obv), and especially Highwayman. And whatever you due KILL HOJAN ON SIGHT

Midrange
Cards to grab: Backlash, Factory Quota (against FJS/Xenan)
For the most part, midrange decks are pretty even. Usually midrange piles run a bit too much removal that makes them have a slow clock against us. Ixtun (barring the rare Whirling Duo) and Jennev run no lifegain at all meaning our spells/units are very real clocks against them and we can put them into lethal range from a burn spell off the top.

The tough part comes from FJS and Xenan/Kerendon decks running baby Vara. We absolutely cannot beat this card so make sure you try to merchant a Factory Quota to at least try and race before Bore/Banish/Disjunction comes down.

Control/Combo/Ramp
What to grab: Backlash
I'm grouping these all together because they pretty much are the same as far as we're concerned. These are usually good matchups for us. With no opposing clock for the most part from all of these, we have free reign to simply pelt our opponent with all we got. Our units almost always get in if you play them when the opponent has no power up and our deck is so redundant and inevitable that no amount of removal/counterspells/discard will stop us. Another good thing is that our reach can easily beat otherwise unbeatable board states (like obliterating your opponent for lethal when they went off with reanimator and put a million dudes into play or staring down a bunch of guys pumped by Martyr's Chains)

Other options
Just some other random cards that I've tried/can be run

Bore (in the market): Usually not great, we can usually remove small units before they get equipped and if you haven't finished off a deck that's running something like Chains or Pit of Lenekta by the time they get it, you're probably dead anyway.

Piercing Shot: Not that bad, helps the aggro matchup by being removal and reach, but it just never feels amazing. Can probably be swapped in for Grief to go even more unitless

Signal Flare: I ran this for a while and it's just not good enough. It hitting site's is irrelevant for the most part (we need all the burn to the face) and it's not fast. Decent if you want to improve against aggro though.

Card draw (Wisdom of the Elders/Strategize): Simply too slow for the most part. We need to kill our opponent ASAP and drawing cards is turns not killing our opponent. I guess you can run these if you want to crush control harder.

Madness: Can easily steal you games (especially against Timedudes.dek) but it's mediocre without sac effects. Definitely worth considering if you want.

Bandit Queen: Our deck doesn't go wide enough for Queens effect to matter so she's often just a bad Highwayman. Still a decent choice as 4 power quickdraw/charge is alright even for a turn

Censari Brigand: With no way to pump this, this card is often mediocre and trades down too much. It's still viable if you want to run it.

Oni Ronin: Good ol onion boy is alright. However, he's a horrible topdeck and warcry means little with how little troops we're running

Vara, Vengeance-Seeker: The main reason to run this is to pop Aegis (especially face aegis) which is a problem. It's always a good card but it turns on our opponents removal really well and is slow for what we want to do.

Conclusion
If you want to run an aggro deck that's a little different (although not super top-tier), I suggest giving this deck a shot. Topdecking a burn them all right when the opponent slams that Xo that was going to lethal you is really fun and knowing when to go face or remove units with your spells also gives this deck some interesting decisions compared to some other aggro decks.

Okay, so I'm a long time lurker, first time deck list poster. I've always found sentinels fascinating and wanted to find a way to build them. I've looked on here and tried a few lists, hut they always seemed clunky. So in my searches, and testing I've found this list has so far worked the best for me. Eventually I will replace some power stones with 2 more crests, though i digress.

The deck is fairly self explanatory, you want to draw as many sentinels as possible, reducing their cost, and increasing your power cap.

My take on cheating out Martyr's chains.

Update:
This is a little more controlish than other versions running Teacher etc.

Gets relics via Severin, or Smuggler -> Core.

Changed Hourglass to Core as it feels pretty good to go turn 5 Sahin into chains. Also added Dizo's office as a ramp payoff.
Did add the second chains because as the commenters mentioned, it is relevant to have two in the deck.

Formerly I had hourglass, previous description about hourglass: I went with hourglass as the market relic because it is the cheapest relic that might have an impact on the board, and is fetchable by both smugglers. Especially good if Hooru aggro running Aniyah continues to be popular, or you run into people still running permafrost. This also allows you to technically combo off with only 4 mana, which might be necessary sometimes. You can smuggler turn 3, Governor turn 4 against a deck you don't think can kill it, then you can go off next turn without needing to draw a 5th undepleted mana. Also just Great Valley Smuggler as a 4/4 endurance can be pretty annoying for aggro decks.

Completely Untested, If I found out you crafted this I'll smack you.

Just testing to see if we can make Blistersting claws do some work.

The new campaign gave reactive control decks some strong tools. Honor of Claws filters through your deck while creating card advantage. It effectively draws you three cards in mid to late game. Stormhalt Knife gains you five life in a pinch without losing tempo, it also enables you to play a sweeper and then kill an opposing relic weapon for free. It’s much better than Sword of the Sky King since you’ll have to tank a ton of damage while ramping in the early game.
Playing 4 Equivocates and 2 Desert Marshals to counter FJP, which turns out to be one of the best matchups for temporal. As long as you got some ways to deal with Vargo Redclaw, they’re actually pretty light on threats. Equivocate can also blow out Korovyat Palace which is very prevalent at the moment.
Running 2 Moondials for some flood protection. and it’s an answer to Auric Runehammer. It’s doing well against grindy three color mid-range decks for me.
Possible adjustments: If you’re in an aggro meta, consider switching in Defiance, more Stormhalt Knifes and the 4th Hailstorm over some card draw spells. If you find yourself in a lot of control mirror, bring in Eilyn's Choice and possibly Sword of the Sky King. If you’re against a lot of aegis units/ vargos, try out Unstable Form.
Although it’s not the best deck in the format, I had a lot of fun and made master with this deck. Hope you’ll enjoy it too.

This deck is the result of wanting to build a non-meme deck that Diogo Malaga, Elonze would seem good in, and Moment of Creation seemed to synergize pretty well with him. Firstly, you want a high density of spells for Diogo to get value, and you want a number of them to be bombs. The same is true when trying to maximize Moment of Creation. The late game option of Xo of the Endless Hoard is a sweet new pickup for FTP Moment as well.

The spell line-up needs a degree of consideration. Sometimes you will hit Torch off Diogo, which seems bad (and it kind of is). Obviously, we have to play Torch, and if you hit it off Diogo every so often, then that is an acceptable sacrifice we make to play Torch. However, the lack of Seek Power is very intentional. Jennev Cargo can at least be cast for free so we can play the same card we contraband into on that same turn, and Find the Way is a draw-two due to the echo trigger, whereas Seek Power would truly be an awful hit.

The deck is a ton of fun, but a little hard to play at first. Getting to resolve a huge Diogo is very satisfying however.

Just a fun Elysian deck to play especially if you like Eilyn.

Ideally you have a pledge unit opening hand and combo off with Glasshopper and Bear Guard Bayonet.

Crown is in there for fun if you're already ahead and feel like adding some spice to your play. In one of my games I had a destiny Eilyn and Jotun, FeelsGoodMan.

West Wind herald is there for when I tried to combo decimate with Honor of Claws, but it ended up being a brick in my hand most of the time, feel free to sack it for whatever.

Hailstorm is important for keeping you alive early on, good for aggro matchups as well and breaking aegis.

The combo is Excavator plus getting lots of power plus getting power into your void. This deck folds to aggro and relic hate (you have 1 excavator in the market and no way to get it back), but it's a blast when it works. A large number of your infrequent wins, however, will come from the silliness of Xo market swapping and not Excavator itself.

You had ONE JOB, Svetya!

(In criminal law, the claim that the deceased victim “needed killing” is known as “the Texas defense.”)

Notes:
1) Torrential Downpour (or any damage-dealing spell) becomes Deadly when you have TLW equipped.

2) You do not need to kill a unit with Nametaker for Nametaker's effect to work; equipping Nametaker effectively makes all of your removal read "remove all copies." It's pretty broken.

3) Multiple copies of Severin decrease TLW's activation cost, hence the Glasshopper in the market; early iterations of this included Quicksilver Mirror. However, Severin's primary function here is the same as Call for Aid's--they're non-relic cards which produce throwaway relics.

Ranked up to 1200ish masters at the end of last season. I took a concept from Twitch streamer LocoPojo and adapted it to suit my collection and personal play style. This deck utilizes the new pledge tools to cheat out minions and spells that lead to a lot of card draw, power, and damage. It’s a high roll deck where you live and die by activating your pledge cards. Always mulligan with the intent to pledge, even if you have to go down to 6.

Questions, thoughts, concerns, let me know!

Updates: As someone pointed out familiar was kind of a weird pick (which I knew would probably be the case), and after play testing it, i agree it felt underwhelming in this list. I elected to focus on the ramping aspect of this deck and due to some of the high influence costs (Darya and Tempest), trail maker made sense and is some nice fixing. I also swapped out strategize for honor of claws. It feels a lot better to destiny into, and it’s just generally a good card. If you’re running primal I’d encourage you to put HoC in almost any list.

so the idea is to incrementally deal damage to yourself via shakedown, instigator, fenris and desecrate
a nice combo is that you can draw a card with nightshade to bring your life low enough to play the weapon for free.

a nice little synergy we have been exploring is the severin which can be brought back with both knife and cross as well as discarded from the deck with tavrod, I'm not sure if that is too cute at that point as our tavrods have very few hits being 3 other tavrods and 4 swords as a maximum.

we also have the secret passage in our market because you can both smack your opponent through a board stall as well as potentially bringing back star reader whomstve could be brought back by the sac and then play a relic etc.

I used both this deck and Rakano aggro (Because I faced a lot of maul) to climb from Gold 3 to Rank1.


If you are interested I will make a guide for the deck!

Feln Aggro at its finest - it's technically possible to kill your opponent on turn two if you get 4 Bear Guard Bayonets on Direwood Slasher and a Rapid Shot (which would be absolutely beautiful and if it ever happens I will post a picture), but even one Bayonet will set the game off to a great start. This is assuming you were able to pledge to start.

This is very much an aggro deck, but it also has sticking power due to card draw from a pumped borderlands scout or from Winter Crown. Zende helps with the late game, bringing back 1-2 units from the void.

Make sure to play your cards in the right order to get the most out of your units.

Not sure what else to say, except that so far this deck is performing well, though not perfect - above 60% and rising as I make changes. Feel free to play around with it and make it better if you can! have fun!

Made the deck base for Jarrall; was too fast, will find him another deck.

T3 Scoundrel or Hojan with Bayonet is gross.

(EDIT: After watching Thatresolves play the deck, I agreed that the power was a bit awkward and that Teacher influence into Ponysnatcher influence was rough. Cut the Dredgers for more Merchants, at which point I stopped seeing the need for Teacher. It was hard. I love Teacher. But as good as it is early, it's pretty underwhelming late, and this deck wants the option to go late to maximize the extra value generated by Glasshopper. He also suggested Rhysta, which I didn't originally consider to be on-plan, but I may have been underestimating how much work pulling a Shadow sigil out can be. Thanks for the advice!)

I know a lot of people were down on the pledge deck, but there is no better feeling than a Moonstone Vanguard in your opening hand with these little Clockroach beauties. Chump them early and let Dread get them back for even more Vanguards. Slap a blade on them for even more Vanguards. Dredge them back for even more Vanguards. Or Cykalis, I'm not picky. What's not to love about Glasshopper?

Mull aggressively. You want to Pledge. You need to Pledge. Preferably Moonstone Vanguard. Cykalis is a really good second option. Dread is fine, and you can do some neat stuff with a lot of them, but I'd only pledge one as a last resort.
If you can't Pledge, Glasshoppers and Blades are not nearly as cool. If you have enough power that the Pledge unit cost reduction doesn't matter, just throw the Hoppers in the market. Blades are still useful, especially on Cykalis.
Non-Pledge stuff? Desecrate is so good. Initiation is nice with the amount of recursion in here. Vara is Vara. Teacher might be flex, but I like having another 2-drop with Memory Dredger. Ponysnatcher eats well, either removal or markets.
The market needs a better player to make it. I'm testing Apex Predator in there, but I only grab it when I've got multiple Hoppers to put its cost more in line with Carnosaur. Cheaper removal might just be better. And since everything has Time (for now) Auralian Merchant might be better than the Smuggler?

Third and probably final version of the deck.
Idea is to push early for damage and finish the game with either Crystallize or Maul. Which one you need will depend on the matchup. For instance:
Palace control is an instant Maul fetch. That deck has lots of card draw. Two things to take into account: if you get an early merchant, try to push for as much damage as possible pre-turn 5 (harsh rule incoming). Keep if possible an available Equivocate if they have a Vargo Redclaw and they are about to hit turn 6, to Equivocate before it gets the +4+4 aegis. If Maul damage is not enough, you can hold until they get a Xo of the Endless Hoard, and let it attack, so that they draw the treasure troves. That is when you Maul. Finally, one thing to note is that Permafrost will be less reliable post turn 6, so swapping it for somthing in the market is a very valid option.
Aggro decks. Here it will depend on whether or not you managed to keep your units, and how far ahead/behind you are. In a stalled board, you want Crystallize. If you got early presence, and an early merchant, Clock of Stolen Hours is good. If you feel the need to kill something asap, maybe Xenan Initiation is what you need. Keep in mind here, that you can delay playing Teacher of Humility for one turn to play Teacher of Humility with Bear Guard Bayonet, and avoid Torch / Suffocate. Will die to Vanquish now, though.

As a general rule, you will want to pledge a Cykalis, the Burning Sand, a Moonstone Vanguard and lastly a Shadowlands Borderscout (in that order of preference). This is a GENERAL rule, as you may prefer pledging a Moonstone Vanguard if you already have a Glasshopper against an aggro match up, you may want to pledge to keep the curve as smooth as possible (more than one Moonstone Vanguard or Cykalis, the Burning Sand and Shadowlands Borderscout both in hand). Still, pledging is not compulsory, and if you have a decent hand, you may want to keep it (having more than one card that benefits from pledging in your hand, and being unable to pledge is an instant redraw, though)
Another general rule is that, if you pledged a Cykalis, the Burning Sand, you will want to play Dusk Raider BEFORE a Glasshopper, to give the created cykalis berserk (and you almost always want that).
You may want to keep an eye open for whether or not you play Teacher of Humility + Bear Guard Bayonet in the same turn (I know i'm repeating myself, but bear with me). To keep in mind: justice will still be able to kill you with both Vanquish and Defiance; shadow will kill you with Annihilate, but not with Suffocate; Torch will no longer be a threat. Plus, Teacher of Humility gets overwhelm, and will most likely trigger its infiltrate if you attack (if you also have Twilight Hunt, you can unleash the wombo combo).

As side notes, although i do not like Shadowlands Borderscout in general, this deck plays many removal magnets before Shadowlands Borderscout comes into play, vastly increasing its survival chance. Once it's down and ready, this card is a beast, especially combined with one of our relics, or with a possible berserk, or with bear guard bayonet. drawing 4 cards from an atack is beautiful.

Mirror Image has earned its place here because most of what you can duplicate has a great added value. Be it a merchant, a Cykalis, the Burning Sand, a Glasshopper, a Dusk Raider, any creature to which you added killer, etc. Still, having two in hand is extremely awkward, so only two in the deck

Initiate of the Sands vs Journey Guide: Initiate of the Sands wins (for me) because of the following: i. it allows a turn two merchant into a turn three Clock of Stolen Hours. ii. it allows a turn two Teacher of Humility + Bear Guard Bayonet. iii. It allows a turn two crest (or other depleted power, remember, turn one you want to pledge) and Dusk Raider. iv. It allows you to push for some (meager, yes, but still non-zero) damage. The only real advantage Journey Guide has (IMO) is not dying to Snowball (being a better blocker is not important, as you will almost always be wanting to atack early).

I think that's all. Only things i'm still testing are the Cobalt Waystone in the market (which I still VERY occasionally need), and the split Permafrost - Equivocate (permafrost less useful against palace control and SST/Moonstone Vanguard). Any idea will be greatly appreciated.

Nearly identical to my WWH FJP Midrange list. Instead of herald we have JFC on 5, JFC being the best 5-drop in the game imo. We also get an extra market card instead of Scattershot, and Eilyn is a great counter to time midrange and FTP. If FTP doesn't have equivocate for Eilyn they just lose. What she does is similar to what Zal Chi does in FTP's market.

As has been pointed out by a few others, whether because people are having fun with Honor decks because of Vargo or because they're just experimenting with Homecoming in general, baby Vara is a little less on the scene, leaving Aegis strategies a place to come back in.

That being said, you can't be too cautious when Shelterwing Rider is one of your major beatsticks, hence the inclusion of Vanq blade, Enforcer, and two transform effects in the market.

The strategy is relatively simple - go over their heads, then play palace for a berserk air finish or a surprise 9/9 Sheltherwing Rider with its aegis back. And Wisdom of the Elders is great to get some card advantage in the late game.

Honor of Claws and Commando are something of a flex spot - I like what they're doing in terms of life and card advantage and filling out the curve, but I could see moving to more or less of either one, or even cutting some of them for jennev merchants.

Savagery is a great way to get a Vargo out of the way or other units in your way. Also a great way to activate either Feast-Caller or Aniyah on the turn they are played. Just having the overwhelm is very useful for pushing damage and taking down sites with only chump blockers to defend them.

So far this deck has brought me a winning streak and I hope it does the same for you. Have fun!
Easy deck for rank

Diogo Málaga, Elonze + Invoke the Waystones

Diogo combo! Plenty of people have been talking about this strategy since Diogo was spoiled, and I've fleshed it out here to a surprising amount of success. Is it good? Ehhhh, I'm not convinced it is once people figure out how to play against it, but it's fun and does have the OTK. I tried a few win conditions but Lumen Reclaimer felt like the best way to not die after drawing through the deck. I also tried Talir's Unwinding with Icicle Marksman but both cards were awful on their own and didn't end up doing a ton of damage together either.

How the Combo Works
Diogo gives Invoke the Waystones Destiny, which creates the following loop:

1) Invoke the Waystones is played.
2) The top 4 cards of your deck are discarded.
3) The next card is played for free.
4) Effects from the free card are put on the stack (for cards like Eilyn) or happen immediately (Temple Scribe)
5) A Destiny'd copy of Invoke the Waystones is drawn
6) A card is drawn (from Destiny). Repeat from step 2.

So in essence for every 6 cards in your deck, 4 cards are discarded, 1 card is played, and 1 card is drawn until the deck is exhausted.

How to play the deck

Redraw for a hand with preferably with Pledge + Diogo. With this configuration of the deck it is imperative to have the Pledge online, and I would even go down to 6 cards looking for it. The first order of business is to find Diogo Málaga, Elonze and amplify for at least one. Once you have amplified Diogo, you need to either draw Invoke the Waystones naturally (the hard way) or find a Jennev Merchant for Celestial Omen Then, you draw your deck, and are left with no cards in deck and a warning that you're about to lose the game! Fear not, for a Lumen Reclaimer from the market restocks your deck complete with the Destiny'd Invoke the Waystones. From there, you can play units until you have a full board and sacrifice the Lumen Reclaimer to put additional copies in your deck so that you don't just lose. With a full board and the ability to replenish it every turn, you frequently overwhelm your opponent's resources, but you can also win with a huge Temple Artisan with Savagery or with multiple Eilyn shots to your opponent's face.

The backup plan of Temple Artisan, Eilyn, the Rising Storm, or even just Invoke the Waystones turn after turn can work if the opponent isn't applying ample pressure.

The Market

Diogo Malaga, Elonze and Celestial Omen
Combo Pieces

Equivocate
Removal for when you need it. Could potentially be replaced by Display of Instinct if you're not worried about Deepforged Plate

Lumen Reclaimer
Main wincon, makes it so that you don't just die.

Savagery
Alt wincon, when paired with Temple Artisan.

Odds and Ends
-Always pledge turn 1.
-Be patient before going for the Omen -> Invoke; if you don't have power up after the Celestial Omen, it is possible to fizzle. The more time you have to set it up, the better.
-Bear Guard Bayonet on Temple Artisan is pretty good as an alt wincon.

Description
Super cheap deck in scope of Shiftstones, it requires you to have 3 Campaigns, but you can cut Messenger Hawk, use Bear Guard Bayonet instead Power Stone and it will be only Homecoming campaign. But let's be honest it's Into The Shadows campaign, that you probably already have.
Power Stone vs Bear Guard Bayonet:
- Power Stone doesn't require unit to be able to ramp
- Playing Bear Guard Bayonet on a Ramp unit will result in loosing 2 cards for one removal and get behind on Ramp
- Power Stone is a relic, so this will result in more consistent buff for Tunneling Gargantua, 12 vs 8
- You don't want to play Bear Guard Bayonet on Messenger Hawk, coz this unit is a chump blocker and you want to block most damage you can.

Deck Design
- 26 Units, 14 Pledge, 8 Ramp, 4 Utility
- 8 Ramp Relics
- 16 Spells, 4 "Mass Removal", 4 Draw, 4 Ramp/Cycling, 4 Utility
- 25 Power in 2:3 proportion, Primal:Time

Game Plan
Main goal is to have at least 1 Pledge unit turn 1, you always want to have it and pledge it.
Second is that you want your ramp for 2 and for 4.
Ideally you also want 1 cost card to de played off the pledged unit, Messenger Hawk into Glasshopper.
So turn 2 and 3 your ramp Turns, that means that you want to play ramp for 2 to increase your total power:
- Power Stone - doesn't afraid of unit removal, safer option.
- Trail Maker - great option due to influence stabilization, remember you need 2 Primal and 3 Time influences.
- Glasshopper - it's not really "ramp" effect, it's a unit cost reduction, it is more viable in cases when you have Moonstone Vanguard or you Pledged it. Coz you can't play 4 cost ramp on turn 3 off the Roach.
On turn 3 you want to play your 4 cost ramp:
- Eternity Core - once again it doesn't afraid on unit removal and it gives +4/+4 to Tunneling Gargantua that can be played on t5-6.
- Call for Aid - good in all aspects, it ramps, it cycles, it gives life and it is fast.

So having ramp on t2 and t3 opens us in multiple options, you can refill hand with Honor of Claws and more likely draw into threats or you can apply pressure by playing Moonstone Vanguard or Colossal Pteriax on turn 4.
The longer games goes, the more power you will have and more cards will be drawn as well as Glasshoppers that will bring your threats in hand.

You will be shocked how consistent you can be on ramping plan.

Sideboard represents possible cards to replace with:
Power Stone => Bear Guard Bayonet
Messenger Hawk => Permafrost
Adjust your power base according your new rates.

Don't forget to hit that like like button if you liked this deck.
Write your feedback, suggestions in comment section.

The point of this deck is to get Shard of the Spire out and get value off of it, and to appreciate never-played meme cards of course. Most of the units get hugely buffed from Shard of the Spire.

Copperhall Porter: This guy is just here to trade with aggro and draw you some power. Good candidate for replacement because he honestly doesn't do much. Signal Flare could go here.

Red Canyon Smuggler: One of the ways to get your shard out. Merchants stop you from having dead shards in your hand. If you Rise to the Challenge on her, she will come out as a 4/4 double damage.

Rika, Desert Navigator : Shard makes her a 5/5. She can also wear some weapons and still get her warps off if you didn't draw spire.

Winchest Merchant: Just another way to get shard. Not as good as the smuggler.

Momentum Builder : One of the main memes in this deck. Becomes a 10/10 and beyond, and even if you don't have shard you can still put a weapon on it to get it to attack.

Shieldsmith : Becomes a decent 5/5 with lifesteal. It's useful for stalling, and it can even attack naturally if your miner's musket dies or you lose armor from waystones.

Robobuddy : Another meme card that is only useful in maybe two decks max, this being one of them. 6/6 charge that creates a 3/3 when it hits. I believe that is the best you will ever get out of this card.

Miner's Musket : There is no real curve in this deck and you will usually be clumsily playing 1 card per turn. This helps with that by making the expensive cards playable, and also giving you something to do early, not to mention trading with aggro units.

Ornate Katana : If you don't get spire, this is one way to make your units actually do something while not losing card advantage.

Doorknocker : Yes for one more power you can just play plate in this deck. But can your plate create a 3/3 double damage on an empty board? Let us not speak of the fact that Twinstrike Master is already a 4/4 double damage for just 1 more power.

Defiance : You desperately need to stop early aggression until you can set up the shenaniganry.

Rise to the Challenge : Indirectly gets you shard. Immediately turns on Momentum Builder and Shieldsmith if needed, or otherwise just gets you whatever you need at that moment.

- MARKET -
Vanquish : This is usually to kill some big flyer or other problem unit.

Shard of the Spire : The deck is somehow even worse without this.

Deepforged Plate : Overwhelm and endurance are pretty good here.

Amilli, Cloudmarshal : Becomes an 8/8 and deals with fliers, not to mention probably wins the game if he doesn't immediately die.

Stormhalt Knife : I believe that this card is busted as heck and sometimes you just need a free 5/5 relic weapon.

In theory The Winter Crown is quite strong if you're ahead: it draws you cards when you're able to attack the face with units, and the stun lets you lock down two blockers for 3 power a turn. This deck tries to leverage The Winter Crown in an aggressive leaning Feln deck, where Haunting Scream works nicely as both burn and a way to trigger Crown when unable to attack on board. Argenport Instigator and Black-Sky Harbinger also allow for triggering Crown without attacking.

Desecrate was also a significant card for this sort of Feln strategy, as it provides another efficient removal spell and allows cutting Permafrost in order to play Vara, Vengeance-Seeker, who otherwise has excellent synergy in the deck.

Bear Guard Bayonet playing undepleted power is absurd.

This should not be a good deck, I just threw together some cards that synergize with the new Homecoming cards. It should probably include some form of interaction like some Enforcers or Blades. However ramping into Korovyat Palace is very effective.


Edit: after playing more of this I'm actually convinced it is a good deck (not tournament good, but still good). Its power is far too reliant on your opening hand but it still has game without Hojan + Bayonet openers. I mostly let Chains to carry me to victory, but a 10 attack Silverwing Courier with Berserk is an effective closer.

Pledge Cards
Considering the importance of Pledge and the available options I think this deck should run 12-16 sources. Aniyah, Arctic Sheriff and Silverwing Courier are pretty solid, leaving the rest to be filled out with Imperial Loyalist, Reyna, the Unwavering, Shadowlands Borderscout, or Eilyn, the Rising Storm. Pledging Justice is usually what you want in order to be able to play Icaria on 2 and hit JJJJJJ quickly using Bayonet. Loyalist and Borderscout are extremely good if you can hit them with Withstand but that is not reliable and they benefit heavily from some other activators in your deck. Reyna is usually just an expensive fat body and Eilyn does not pair well with Whispering Wind (you can't discard her and she reduces the chance of drawing Chains). Personally I find using Loyalist to tutor for Aniyah (Withstand) or a merchant (Mirror Image) quite fun so that's what I've been sticking with.

The original plan was to use Whispering Wind to tutor for Chains but I've found that it's important enough to just run several main deck. Having multiple Chains out is a great way to really drive a point home.

The main game plan is stall early. You definitely have the potential to win with vargo or rizahn + palace, but you should outscale pretty much anything if you can get a svetya down without instantly losing. At that point, even your merchants are 8/8 aegis units, and there are very few decks that can 1 for 1 that sort of card. If you can get a martyr's chains to stick on top of that, it's pretty much guaranteed gg.

Specific interactions: honor of claws + privilege of rank is amazing. Both cards are worth playing on their own, but if you discard privilege with honor, you get net +3 card advantage for 4 mana, while playing each card individually is net +2 card advantage for 7 mana. If you have both in your hand, passing turn 3 and then discarding privilege on turn 4 with honor is better than playing both on curve, even if you have nothing else to do on turn 3.

Vargo ignores harsh rule (including friendly harsh rules). You can potentially force your opponent to overcommit to the board in order to get past vargo and then get an easy 2 or 3 for 1 with harsh rule without killing your own board.

Merchant for stormhalt knife is a staple vs aggro. If the aggro deck can't reduce you below 10 health in a reasonable amount of time, then you should still win despite "wasting" your merchant. If they do manage to drop you low, a 0 power 5/5 relic weapon can do a great job of stabilizing you.

Ramp to 6, play Diogo Málaga, Elonze and Amplify 1. Fetch Resurface from market, put Invoke the Waystones with Destiny on top. Go through 90-100% of your deck, playing a couple of Xo of the Endless Hoard and/or Apex Predator, merchant for Display of Instinct and then Equivocate (if possible) to counter your opponent's next turn. Use Messenger Hawk to replenish your deck to ensure you can play Xos/Predators for the next 4 turns, or Lumen Reclaimer your full Void including multiple copies of Destiny Invoke to combo off again. Use Hawk in the middle of the combo to help hit additional copies of Xo/Predator or Great Valley smuggler to help set up a lethal attack on your next turn.

If you draw your single copy of Invoke, you can use Messenger Hawk to put 4 more in the deck before playing Diogo.

When setting up the combo, remember that Auralian Merchant cannot fetch Resurface, so use it first instead of another merchant in hand to fetch Diogo.

I'm playing Resurface over Celestial Omen in the market to make it easier to protect your tutor from Regent's Tomb/Sabotage as it can be fetched and played at 7 power. Putting Waystones on top instead of drawing it immediately guarantees you will have enough power to merchant for Display of Instinct and can fetch/play Reclaimer if needed at the end of the combo even though you sometimes combo off 1 turn later. I'm not 100% this is correct, but it has felt right so far.

This deck will fold to a single well-timed Vara's Choice. If Xenan is prominent, a 4 Invoke, 4 Diogo list would be more resilient. Getting Resurface or the first Invoke the Waystones negated is bad news, so play smart if an opponent is holding up power for a negate.

Premise: Combine two dirty synergies of the new campaign cards: Bear Guard Bayonet ramp with pledge units, and Honor of Claws with Privilege of Rank. If you don't feel like there's enough pledging, swap in Aniyah for Rizahn or Hurler (I didn't find it too necessary since it's easy to market/discard away Bayonets in the event you keep a hand without pledge)

Main Deck
There are a total of 16 pledge sources and feel that is adequate and probably the minimum needed (80& + chance) so its about right, and in testing seems to relaibly give me a pledge unit turn 1, and in 10 games so far have misssed just once. t.
I am only running 4 heirloom seeker, these are not key pledge units but still perform a function letting you attack un-blocked and are still ok to pledge though as the draw from the glasshopper still thins the deck and gives you a chance for a better unit.
The idea behind the name "glass slipper" is not only for the heirloom seeker to "slip" past with attack but also any of your other units too with the inclusion of secret passage. This enables some crazy combos as if you use this on an attacking dread it pretty much allows it to always hit face heal and deal damage without dying to a block due to its low defence, and if you give something unblockable later (which kills it after) that's ok too as when you have a killer unit whicjh has used its ability allows you to deliberately send it to the void to buy back and use again, or guarantees a draw from moonstone vanguard etc and I have managed to pull off some crazy combos already by making a vanguard and dread unblockable and looping them in and out of the void
Market

2-0 with this deck!!1 felt like posting, might delete later hehe

in all seriousness I wanted to take a shot at putting together a list that tries to take advantage of Svetya, Merciful Orene, Korovyat Palace and the revenge mechanic and this is what I've come up with so far.

Merchants - I initially wanted to run 8 Smuggler/Merchant but the 3-drop slot is a bit packed due to playing Stonepowder Alchemist - also it feels worse without having Xo of the Endless Hoard, however the market is pretty much built to support 8 if you want to try that.

Unit Suite - All of the units are pretty self explanatory in that they synchronize well with Svetya, Merciful Orene and Korovyat Palace. Shelterwing Rider is a card that I've pretty much considered as good as shiftstone since Vara, Vengeance-Seeker was released, but perhaps it can provide value in this theme. Inquisitor Makto is also a card that I've never been too impressed with competitively, but has always been enjoyable for me to build around so we'll see if he ends up being good enough here. Svetya, Merciful Orene is your big payoff card to try and finish games that Palace itself can't.

Removal Suit - I think the most notable piece of removal here is Auric Runehammer. I think the card is probably a must in this deck in that it answers Vargo Redclaw and is also often a 2-for-1. Other than that, feel free to play around with the amount and selection of removal you want. I don't have too much rhyme or reason as to why I'm playing the numbers of each card.

Card Draw - I want to play more Honor of Claws as it's very good in trying to find revenge units again but I feel that I'm going to be playing other things more often on turn 4 and Palace also allows me to Wisdom of the Elders when I need which is great.

Market - Market is also pretty self explanatory. Regent's Tomb on 4 (especially on the play) is very strong. I initially had 4 Harsh Rule main deck and Vanquisher's Blade as removal/graveyard hate in the market but I ended up taking them out and just playing 1 in the market. I think this deck has enough units/removal to merit not having to play main deck Harsh Rule.

A 17/17 one of course!

2 card OTK. Very easy to combo.
Opening hand look for Last Chance or Ebon Dune Smuggler + Auralian Merchant or Ebon Dune Smuggler.
setup: Get Talir, Who Sees Beyond from the market. make sure one of your merchant or smuggler is in your void.
Combo: Play Talir, Who Sees Beyond, play Last Chance target a merchant or smuggler in your void. trade a card from your hand (do not worry if you have no card in your hand, you will draw one from destiny.) to get Vodakhan, Temple Speaker, draw your whole deck. Trade one of the card in your hand to Twilight Hunt at the end of the chain, play it on Talir, Who Sees Beyond kill one of their units. Talir should have around 100~700 attack by the time, Overwhelm damage will win you the game.

Good Luck

This is a different take on conventional Hooru Fliers builds, one that sets itself up to win with a devastating Korovyat Palace.

The goal in the early game is to sculpt your hand with Master Cartographer, Whispering Wind, or Herald's Song (ideally discarding Privilege of Rank) and get in for some chip damage with your fliers. When you don't have Privilege to discard, look to use the loot effects to maximize your chances of curving out your fliers.

Once you're able to curve a Shelterwing Rider or Amilli, Cloudmarshal into Korovyat Palace, the game is pretty much won, even if that's your only unit after a Harsh Rule. Often times just a few small fliers will do the trick when combined with Palace.

The deck packs plenty of removal (Defiance, Permafrost, Vanquish) as well as an Avigraft and Harsh Rule out of the market for when the AI gets a nut draw.

I am listing this deck as a Work in Progress and am open to suggestions. It has done fairly well for me in my testing so far, but not as well as my conventional build when you factor in that this deck is slower. I think with a few tweaks this deck could have the consistency to be a very strong option for Gauntlet.

A spinoff of the pre-nerf Ixtun Howling Peak decks, powered up by the new site. Korovyat Palace seems extremely powerful and a great source of card advantage in a longer game, which matches well with our 8-smuggler, 4 Hurler, 4 Xo package. Whether Vargo earns his place here is a big question mark, as is the exact nature of the disruption and draw packages. I am testing the West-Wind Herald combo because it does have the potential to just end games, but I have always been leery of its inclusion. We will see if it earns its place.

So I haven't played a lot of games with this deck obviously, but I've been planning it for almost a month, I just want to start this pledge deck train as soon as possible, because I think Glasshopper is an amazing card.

While I'm sure better deck builders out there will take this idea and execute it better here is my current list and the idea behind it.

there are 18 pledge cards in the deck, I did not feel like figuring out the math on odds of having them in hand so I did a montecarlo simulation i found online. That found the odds of having at least 1 pledge card in your hand and 2-3 sigils at around 50%, and you are going to want to use that pledge.

Why you ask? well read the cards my friend we are here to capitalize off strong pledge cards and Glasshopper, and if for whatever the odds you don't draw a Glasshopper all game it also helps to make an indestructible Silverwing Courier.

Now to attempt to explain all the cards in the deck and why.

Cargos and seeks: cuz power fixing and they're the only card draw not off put by Andrik, Renegade Priest.

Annihilate: cuz removal, it's fast it's nice maybe you want to switch out a vanquish for it? I don't judge.

Glasshopper: The cornerstone of the deck, it's card draw it's ramp it's a body! it's everything fun and creative and a body, depending on who u pledge you might be playing this deck very differently!

Vanquish: again removal, it's a little slower, but it helps us deal with big threats without worrying about their factions.

Vanquisher's Blade: same deal as Vanquish, but also graveyard hate and a lil extra damage.

Display of Vision: mana fixing that maybe you'll get to use the other 2 modes on who knows what the meta is gonna be?

Hidden Road Smuggler: cuz smuggling, only running 4 smugglers because they don't synergize with Andrik, Renegade Priest very well.

Valkyrie Enforcer: a silencing 3/3 flier in a primarily justice deck? yes please! also it's good with Andrik, Renegade Priest, and Telut, Queen's Hand

Andrik, Renegade Priest: my boy and my inspiration, cuz his primary ability hates on merchants and control, and his secondary ability synergizes with Telut, Queen's Hand for extra big face damage (assuming you aren't swinging with Andrik himself)

Cykalis, the Burning Sand my other boi, aces face hates on sites and Glasshopper makes him cost 3!

Moonstone Vanguard: cuz card draw and life and pledge, be careful with him if Andrik, Renegade Priest is on the board too.

Silverwing Courier: cuz flying indestructible pledge! he's a hard to kill boi making him great with Telut, Queen's Hand, he's still weak to plenty tho, but he'll pull out their harder removal.

Reyna, the Unwavering: Ms. hard to kill ya can't Permafrost me! good at staying on the board as a blocker and a body with Telut, Queen's Hand. I honestly might increase the # of her because she's fun and u don't see her often.

Telut, Queen's Hand: cuz wincon.

quick market rundown: power cuz power, slay cuz removal, tomb cuz good card, sword cuz life steal and occasionally aegis, and lastly chains cuz extra wincon.

I really think this deck could be competitively viable, and if not it sure as heck is fun, because as long as you draw your Glasshopper the deck is going to play different depending on what you pledged. Also this deck might switch, market power for Burglarize

Merchant grab plate, play Vargo, plate on Vargo is much more common than you might think and just as strong.
All three modes on palace are very strong and berserking a couple of bears or a giant flyer can often mean lights out.

Hey all, this is my update of an empower playlist for the new Homecoming set.

The overall play style is a bit of flood and a lot of just overwhelm the opponent. Use your combat trick finest hour to activate Hojan and re-up everyone's empower, and don't be afraid to commit hard to the board state.

Siraf's beacon is a really good card and should be played on 3 when possible, it's a free empower activation when the conditions are right and since most of our units are small it should be easy to avoid most removal (or at least the opponent loses tempo in doing so).

Andrik is a real show stopper here, that +4/2 is truly amazing. Just make sure to work your market before you drop him else you commit to not using the market while he is out (or at the very least you aren't going to be able to play anything turn of market pull).

Most of the units are just good units on curve, nothing too special. Everything works together great and currently I am skyrocketing through the ranks playing this.

Enjoy!

Just a faceroll praxis deck to crush ladder with. Does pretty well in my experience.

Just thought that Blood Quill and Means to an End could make a nice pair. And Desecrate helps this deck a lot.
It can win as a simple midrange deck, with Means to an End being just an alternative win condition for fun.

Edit/Update: After some edits from looking at Batteriez deck, I've gone 15-5 with this deck and hope to ride it to Masters so I can go back to inventing more :)

A few notes about the changes:

District Infantryman: Not bad in the opening hand, but I always wanted to fetch grenadins and honestly this deck doesn't want as many 1-drops.

Secret Passage: I still love it so I kept in 1. It's a good way to still sack cards from Madness, put through a revenge unblockable unit, hit with a unit to allow Camrin to grow, or deliver finishing blows, but you want more units first and desecrate is still more valuable in general. I could see bringing it back up to 2, but unsure what to cut.

Piercing Grief: Save this if possible on turn 4 with Ashara Ruthless Assassin out for a nasty surprise. Best with a torch or combust etc in hand as well. Overall this has performed very well.

Tripwire Grenadin: Upped this to 4 due to its versatility - kill Hojans or Scorpians, pump Camrin, deal that extra damage plus torch to kill Vargo.

Stonepowder Alchemist: A weaker addition, honestly, mainly because the 3 slot is clogged since I prefer Ashara Ruthless Assassin in this deck (my unique inclusion vs other similar decks) so this is my cut. That being said, the lifesteal can be useful and occasionally key.

Whispers of the Void: This has won me a couple of the longer games. Infinite ways to pump Camrin or Ashara and inevitability. Can't be effected by opponent shutting off the void (other than being able to grab the Tormentor with DoA

Regent's Tomb: Honestly, cutting this and replacing it with Highwayman was one of the best things I did. Nothing about Regent's Tomb is inherently bad except that it doesn't actually match this deck's tempo. It's a card that wants to sit back and fulfill its agenda to be really useful. You want to win before then.

Vicious Highwayman: Best new inclusion - great for the games when behind on life or when the board is cleared and you need a charge unit.

Overall, this new iteration has performed great. Very fun and I hope others give it a try!

-----------------------------------------------

I know Camrin isn't the best or most exciting card from the new set, but I wanted to try her anyways.

And I got surprised - the deck is actually pretty good and fun to play. So far, after the campaign, aggro is actually in a good spot because many others are playing control with maybe one unit (Vargo). Madness is great in this situation.

A couple tips from playing with Camrin - it's best to play her after you've attacked and gone through so you can immediately pump her to a 5/5 out of torch range.Your deadly units and Ashara are great at setting up situations where this is the case. Also, her plus Madness as as good as it sounds, since the sacrifice doesn't cost anything, so it's easy to set up with other spells etc. I've even considered putting Forge Wolf in as a fetchable for Press-Gang due to the fact that it can immediately pump Camrin and draw you an extra card. Camrin's Card Draw plus Display of Ambition keep your aggro hand relatively full, which is a plus.

Other than that, this is a pretty standard Madness deck. Hope you enjoy it!

Infinite Spitfire Combo - With 2 Severin on the board, Elvish Swindler tutors Spitfire from the deck. With 4 Severin on the board, spitfire costs 0 to activate and deals infinite damage.

If opponent disrupts the combo more than once, don't struggle to piece it back together. Just shift gears, leverage your relics for any advantage you can, and beat face with elves.

Combo pieces: Cabal Scavenger + Dig Site*2 + Antique Polisher + Severin, the Mad Mage or The Praxis Arcanum

How to play:
A is safer(8 Mana). B is faster(4~5Mana), also need setup.
A. Play The Praxis Arcanum(4Mana), then play Antique Polisher(2Mana)to reduce the 1st copy of Dig Site to 0 (The Praxis Arcanum reduce the cost by 1). Play 0 cost Dig Site to return Antique Polisher to hand. Play Antique Polisher(2Mana) to reduce the 2nd copy of Dig Site. Play Cabal Scavenger, then play the Dig Site in hand to return the one in play. repeat until you win.

B. 4 Mana fast combo (need setup)
set up:
play Antique Polisheron 1 of theDig Site to reduce the cost to 1. play 1 cost Dig Site return Antique Polisher. play Antique Polisher to reduce the 2nd copy of Dig Site to 1.
then,
play The Praxis Arcanum(4Mana) or Severin, the Mad Mage(need 5 Mana), play Cabal Scavenger. Now Dig Site cost 0. Play Dig Site in hand to return the one in play. repeat until you win.

Good Luck

The deck is designed to try and control the board and cheat your pit into play early, hopefully then running away from the game. The combo is to use your Governor to sacrifice a relic, and since the pit is your only relic in the deck, it will always find that. To do that you need relics from other sources, and this deck has 13 options. Two new cards from homecoming, call for aid and severin the mad, and then you have mesmerized moth and a rat cage in your market as a cheap search target. There are plenty of flex slots available as this is my first draft, but results have been good so far.

Call for Aid or Severin gets you a relic, then Sahin turns that into a Pit. Can also get the eternity core from the market to create a pit. Draw cards to find the combo. Privilege of Rank gives you sigils for Pit or fodder for merchants, similar to its role in Isomorphic's reanimator.

Not sure about Azindel in the market, temple scribes, or the lone observer. I think the permafrosts may be necessary to buy time against aggro, but these might also want to be something else. Caveat emptor.

Fun deck that makes use of Camrin, the Fox and Ashara, Ruthless Assassin. The idea of the deck came around when I realized both cards want to sacrifice and Scavenge exists.These two cards combo with Madness, Rolant's Memorial, and tokens and feel so good to go off with.

Rolant's Memorial is a really fun win condition. Slightly inconsistent but extremely satisfying to play.

Of course Red Canyon Smuggler is a win condition by herself with Deepforged Plate.

Otherwise, the deck plays as you would expect from a mashup of Haunted Highway/Burn Queen.

Numbers on the cards is still iffy. Display of Ambition is great but drawing too many early can kill all momentum. Combust and Devour are at 2 since Ashara and Camrin act as sudo-removal with madness already and we're running 4 Quarry. Market cards are definitely up for debate.

This shell feels like it is exactly where Camrin, the Fox belongs.
I finally join the Dark Side.

You don't need to draw into cards when your starting hand wins on turn 6.

You will effectively always get the Vargo + Palace combo, and almost always curve out, so mull aggressively for action.

50 power decks aren't supposed to have a positive winrate, but this one carried me through diamond 25-5.

An evolution of my previous Rakano Orenes deck, and I think a stronger list overall. The 8 smugglers are very powerful and even better they give you access to Tomb and Maiden in the market, both of which can be game-winning by themselves. Quarry is ridiculously good here, giving a second way to get free Privilege of Rank casts as well as letting you slam an early Svetya, Rizahn, or Amilli. It's possible that the vanquishes should be slays, but I'mliking the split for now. No Xo's for market abuse feels a little bad, but having more threats we can cast makes it worth it I think. So far I've really been liking the deck, and resolving Svetya continues to be one of the most powerful things you can do in the game right now.

Came up with this deck idea when Defiance first released.
Key cards:
• Rat Cage
• Lethrai Courtier
• Lethrai Hideaway
• Araktodon Egg
• Display of Knowledge
• Xenan Obelisk
• Great Valley Smuggler
• Severin The Mad Mage

Lethrai Courtier and all the low cost relics like rat cage, lethrai hideaway and araktadon egg synergize well. Obelisk buffs all allies and Courtier helps maximize it’s potential. Added Star-reader recently, he can be powerful later in game, also spelunker and smuggler both get buffed fairly quickly by having a relic equipped. Spelunkers ultimate can be a great combo with rat cage equipped & star-reader in grave yard. Smuggler can fetch some pretty powerful cards in black market, my favorite is Nightmaw when I have a field full of 5/5 rats and they all become unblockable. Cleaver with 7 power is also powerful, specially if you use Dark Return and get to reuse killer ability.

Still tweaking this deck. I’m playing Homecoming campaign and aim to add Severin the mad mage in this deck once I unlock him, I’m expecting this to be one of the missing links to this deck, just synergizes so well that it’s like a gift from developers to me! 😄

Sideboard:
• Elvish Swindler would be a perfect fit for this kind of deck, you can swap Chalice for him to help you amass a rat army quicker. Another good combo is using him to fetch secret passage to get an unblockable kill.
• Equivocate was my original removal spell, I swapped it with scorpion wasp, there’s pros and cons to either option.

An updated version of the deck I used to take down the community championship. It's been performing extremely well on ladder as well, especially against top-tier decks like FJS midrange, as well as most variants of aggro.

Current Rank: Top 25 (Climbed from rank ~250 to top 25 in 2 days)

I haven't changed much from my invitational version, but the few changes are fairly important, so I'll give a short explanation of the thought process behind them.

Market Changes:
First off, one of the biggest issues for the deck has been Deepforged Plate. Because of that, I really wanted to find a way to fit Bore into the market. Not only is bore a good answer to plate, it also answers cards like Permafrost and Eternity Core, and it has amazing synergy with all of our merchants and Strategizes. Of course, this meant that we had to switch to a mono-fire market, at which point Torrential Downpour needs to come out too. This isn't as much of a problem as it might seem, since downpour was never that useful for me unless I had at least 1 Howling Peak Smuggler in play. The fact is that with Snowball, Torch, Heart of the Vault, and Amaran Stinger, we have a lot of ways to deal with swarms of tiny units. I also don't think that Bore and Kaleb's Choice are both needed in the market, so I replaced Kaleb's Choice with Urn of Choking Embers. Urn is a massive boon to the highway matchup - it's even better than downpour most of the time.

Maindeck Changes:
The maindeck changes are mostly a consequence of the market changes. Obviously, we have to take out the Great Valley Smugglers and replace them with Ixtun Merchants. Past that, I also added a 3rd copy of Jotun Hurler, as we're relying more heavily on snowballs now that we don't have downpour in the market. I took out a copy of Display of Instinct for the hurler, as display was consistently my worst card in the championship. 4 damage for 3 power is not a good rate, and holding up a counterspell that costs 3 power is rarely feasible. I do still like the card because of how versatile it is, as well as the situational lifegain it grants, so I think 3-of is the sweet spot.

Strengths:
- Favored against FJS (~60% at least)
- Favored against most aggro variants thanks to all the removal + anti-aggro units (stinger, SST, hurler, HoV)
- Counterspells for Temporal/Reanimator
- VALUE!

Weaknesses:
- Low on hard removal, so you can get overwhelmed by beefy time units
- Low on answers to giant units (Deepforged Plate, Mystic Ascendant, etc)
- Somewhat low on finishers, though aggressive lines of play + burn is almost always good enough

Edit I:
-1 Permafrost
+ 1 Jotun Hurler
With all the Hojan Hooru decks running around, I wanted to max out on snowball value. Snowballs also tend to get better in multiples. Although permafrost is a stellar removal spell, it gets hard countered by the new hooru site. I think 3-of is a safe spot to be in.
- 1 Urn of Choking Embers
+ 1 Kaleb's Choice
I've been really missing the counterspell in the market, so I wanted to find a way to get Kaleb's Choice back in. Urn has been pretty useless to me as I have not seen a single highway deck on ladder, so it was a fine card to cut.

Finally getting to use Display of Honor's 2nd line of text.

I’ve taken this deck to Masters the last three seasons. It was built to battle the top decks in the format by incorporating a lot of Silencing creatures that can later jump in for 6 or more damage holding either blade.

It is critical to get to 3 power and 2 Justice quickly. The deck can usually stabilize around that Power with the abundance of 2 and 3 drop creatures that need to be dealt with and have other effects on the board. The Empowered creatures and those with Reknown contribute to the multidimensional way that the deck wins. The win usually occurs off Empowering from a sigil that was magically crafted.

At times you struggle to get a single creature to stay on the board. And when you do, thern you land Telut. Or, you hand it one of the swords. Hijab or Icarus usually carry them.

(No guarantees regarding this new format.)

Another very, very consistent gauntlet grinder for me that got a lot better with the addition of the Homecoming campaign. I won't claim the list is optimally tuned and I'd be willing to bet that you can find a better list out there but this is definitely consistent and enjoyable for me. The Memory Dredger tech in this deck is the strongest attribute but you can easily win with just playing small, threats and Vara, Vengeance-Seeker as well. Shadowlands Tyrant is lots of fun and obviously lives more frequently than it would in ranked but if you're working with a budget it can easily be replaced with something else. I think Impending Doom should probably be in this list but I don't have any. Hope you guys enjoy.
****NOT AN ACTUAL DECK! This is to be used as a reference point only.

Goal of the deck is simple: Control the board until you get a bear down, then continue controlling the board.

Notable cards in the deck:
4x Permafrost used to be 4x Eilyn's Choice but I ended up wanting more proactive and cheaper cards on ladder when coming up against more and more aggro decks.

4x Hailstorm - Just say no to aggro. Also kills almost all the merchants in the format right now.

4x Jotun Feast-Caller - I wanted another "threat" other than just the bear and while Feast-Caller doesn't survive through Harsh Rule like the bear. I found it works really well with Korovyat palace (and we already know it works well with peak).

Power in the market - First the Hooru Banner fixes if you are missing your 3rd color no matter which smuggler goes and gets the power. Second, this is a control deck so missing a power drop on any turn really hurts your game plan and this market power lessens the possibility of that happening. Third, and connected to the second point, the power in the market makes a lot more opening hands keep-able when you can trade off your Xo (or whatever) for a power on turn 3. I have always been a fan of power in markets, and especially in control decks running 8 merchants.

A note on the mirror match:
Because your main way of controlling the board is by harsh ruling it over and over again, you are in an awkward situation if the opponent has a bear of their own. In these situations it is important to hold onto your torches to combine them with either more torches, hailstorms, or Howling peak smugglers to remove the bear. In the mirror match, an uncontested bear usually wins so you always have to be playing around how you will deal with a bear from the other side and how to protect your own bear.

Haven't optimized this list but I've won 6 in a row with it so far at masters level. The goal is to get a pledge on a good unit early (moonstone vanguard is the best if you can make it happen). Then ramp up with maximum power units and the new 1 cost primal weapon. Glasshoppers will give you more pledge cards at a reduced cost. Ultimately you can ramp into Eiylin or apex predator. This list is not optimized, maybe you all have some suggestions but it definitely works. Thinking another copy of Eiylin would be good but I don't have 2 haha.

Basically a deck with Governor Sahin and ways to create relics... but only three real (and powerful) relics. Currently:
1) Martyr's Chains: the strongest relic in the game
2) Pit of Lenekta: the next best
3) Azindel's Gift: especially early on, can destroy an opponent

The Strategizes are there to put any of those relics that we draw naturally back into the deck.
The remaining cards either try to get us more power, create relics to be fodder, or serve as removal. Now the balance on that removal may need tweaking. Vara's Choice and Feeding Time are both great answers to Vargo. I suppose so is Display of Knowledge. But not running Stray into Shadow in the Market (or main?) might just be wrong. We shall see, I suppose.

The "Sideboard" is cards I either have or am still considering for flex spots.
The Spitfire can be cut for better cards if you are a lamo.

The combo is set up invoke the waystones on top with Means in play, then amplify diogo and draw waystones. It triggers, draws 4 and plays 1 card. Then you draw another copy, also with destiny, and play that, and so on until you're milled and means to an end kills the opponent. Note that I don't gave any copies of Invoke or Means to an End and I'm f2p so I'd appreciate it if someone tested it before me and gave feedback. You set up the combo with second sight into diogo amplify so you need to hit 8 power.

Deck got me to Masters very quickly. Pressure from the air feels really strong in the current meta, even though this list is unrefined at best. Still, the concept feels strong.

Permafrost is not very good in the current metagame, but this deck still wants it to press damage through, even if only for a turn. The combination of aggressive 3-drop fliers, backed up by the robust late-game of Amilli, Cloudmarshal and Korovyat Palace, feels very strong. Resolving Sack the City on a board of fliers is pretty disgusting.

Shelterwing Rider has been missed, but it is excellent in this deck. The Palace can restore Aegis, giving you a huge threat that can threaten lethal with the follow-up berserk.

Main concerns are the saturation of cards at the 3-drop slot and the lack of good two-drops. Dusk Raider is acceptable, and giving berserk to your aggressive units is nice, but it still feels lacking. Overall, the deck feels strong, and a good blueprint on what might be strong in the new meta.
Draw alot of cards, protect your Fanatic and gain some health.

Pretty rough draft but I've been having good success with it so far. Pretty much a generic midrange deck that emphasizes sites. You basically just don't die and keep some units on board long enough to play and complete sites, crushing them in value.

Between all the midrange-y units, Slay, and Defiance it's pretty easy to protect the sites. And either site is capable of winning you the game if it sticks, although the Palace is obviously the best for that. Tomb is more to distract/soften them up.

Tomb is a really nice stepping stone to Palace. It finishes on turn 6 if you play it on 4 and it sticks, and the revenge is nice to get more value out of all the unit buffs on Palace. And of course the power from Lingering Influence helps get you there.

Palace is pretty nuts when you have units, but even if you don't just drawing two cards and distracting them for a turn is worth a lot of the time. Especially if you have Harsh Rule from the market. But other than Wisdom all the agenda cards need a unit so watch out for that. Having every agenda card hit a good target is a very good way to win games.

The rest is pretty standard, it's just valuable units/recursion to gum up the board while we wait for sites. Pacifier has been great with all the Ixtun/Rakano/Skycrag decks running around. Harbinger has been great as usual. Amilli has been better than Makto ever was. He's a one card wincon that gums up the board and leaves leftover units, basically perfect for the deck.

I think the deck could make great use of 1-2 Dizo's office as well, but again I'm not sure what to cut.

You could also try running the Argenport Smuggler instead, but Defiance and the Sites being in the main and Market has been straight gas. Also the extra flying blocker/threat has been super nice.
