A crownroach deck with the pledge goodstuff.

Seems strong, but it’s probably because the support cards rather than the roaches.

My first deck on eternal warcry so don't expect this to necessarily be competitive but I am getting really good results with it. More importantly, it's a lot of fun and refreshing.

This is combining the new pledge focused cards Glasshopper and Bear Guard Bayonet with Severin, the Mad Mage to build your board at a discount. Since Glasshopper on its own is a bit weak, I have been digging out the good oldClockroach.

Just make sure you pledge something on turn one (the deck still works if you don't but you have no free units or sigil so you are losing some momentum). Each pledge unit has already proven to be really useful, even Heirloom Seeker. The relics fromSeverin, the Mad Mage are even more free actions and Shadowlands Borderscout is just absurd once obelisk is out.

The market probably needs some work but, to be honest, I generally just grab the two obelisks.

Don't hesitate to make suggestions in the comments. I am still new to Eternal so this deck is probably a bit naive on higher ranks (I am gold, just arrived in diamond but with another one of my pre-campaign brews).

This probably needs more testing, but what I can i say? I played a couple games, won, and got excited about the idea.

Vargo is a great weapon carrier due to his ability, so Doorknocker and Plate is a deadly combo and both decent to good on their own. Harsh ruling with Vargo on the field is fun and crushing for you opponent. Giving him endurance through Korovyat Palace breaks off permafrosts and gives him +4/+4 and aegis (to protect from Equivocate/Teleport) and/or berserk. Kaleb's choice protects him from Runehammer. If you see more equivocate, you could swap Choice with Unseal, though obviously only one set of smugglers can fetch it.

Doorknocker is nice because it can be played after a harsh rule to still threaten the board and it can be fetched along with runehammers or plate with Display of Honor or reforge to have a cute 3/5 DD Helpful Doorbot. Svetya it great at stalling their interaction when she comes out, so she is also safe for a turn to put weapons on. I finished one game with her with plate, doorknocker, and pumped by Display of Honor to deal 28 overwhelm damage for lethal.

Fun deck and fun new card. Hope you enjoy!

I really liked the new Profane Censer card and wanted to build a deck around it. Black Iron Manacles are an awesome fit as they're a curse. I was hoping to get some value out of Affliction and Arachnophobia together on a low attack unit but haven't had any such luck yet. The Direfang Spiders from Arachnophobia and Miris Nightshade work well with Memory Dredger. Miris Nightshade's Nyctophobia also combos well with Profane Censer, Black Iron Manacles, and Encroaching Darkness.

Updated the deck a bit. Found that putting a Cowardice on the computer's Copperhall Shieldman or Dune Phantom is particularly entertaining.

Been playing this quite a bit lately, it's had some 7-0 gauntlet runs, I've also had it get shut down on the first match against an agro/burn deck.

THE PLAN
- Pledge something but try to pledge Dread.
- Then bounce Dreads, make Clockroach army, and abuse inspires.
- Lots of drawing, inspires, and cost reductions to achieve goals.

NOTES
- Alheds and Journey Guides need to get down asap and don't be shy about Dark Returning them. Then work Crowns, Dreads, and the Roaches.
- Alhed is power with his inspire ability and Dreads with destiny are just nuts!
- 2 Dreads in play will bounce each other back to your hand which gains them more inspires and beefs.
- Severin's rings are handy and his big butt helps stabilize the board.
- Lots of fun things you can drop in the market like Talir, Azindel, Apex Predator...

Work in progress but shows some promise.

Working on a variation on all the Ixtun goodstuff piles I've been seeing. I really think that people are sleeping on Bear Guard Bayonet, so I'm trying to incorporate it into a little bit more aggressive variant. The idea here is that we use Bear Guard Bayonet and Hojan, Crownbreaker to help us reach the top end more consistently or a little faster.

Swapped in Gunrunner as the deck consistently hits 5 power and I think I can get more value out of gunrunner especially when combined with palace.

Xo of the Endless Hoard has worked out quite well as a finisher being able to capitalize on the early game pressure put on by Hojan, Crownbreaker.

Chunk Chunk seems like he might actually be stronger than Aniyah, Arctic Sheriff currently as when played on curve his stun will naturally wear off about when opponents play Korovyat Palace where as Aniyah, Arctic Sheriff will likely have just started.

Currently working on figuring out how to handle the mirror where opponents get down a Vargo Redclaw and may replace something in the market for Mortar.

I'll do more of a writeup once I've got it working comfortably.

I've been running 4 of each crest today and liked the results. Haven't really missed plays and being able to control the topdecks has been huge. Bear Guard Bayonet really helps guaruntee a lot of power, and functions almost as well as seek power for controlling some fixing. Going to stick with Crests for the near future.

So far, this has been the best performing deck for me that came out of the campaign, and definitely the best Svetya deck. Heavily inspired by the Rakano Valkyries decks from pre-Defiance times. Having palace would be nice, but with the heavy Justice requirements from Icaria and Privilege as well as trying to hit FFF for Yushkov, I don't think the deck's powerbase can support heading into Ixtun. Games where you land Bulletshaper into a turn 5 or 6 Svetya just feel completely unloseable, it's like Knucklebonesing your entire deck into Icarias.

Someone did a deck called Stunning Silence. This is how you improve this type of deck. You need all units that can silence or stun. You need more weapons that can stun. I also added more cards for stunning & silencing units include ones that don't have a particular sigil cost requirement.40 units, 44 spells & 16 Attachments

The primary win con is to get many rats and relics and then buff your board with Bazaar Stampede from the market.

This is one of my current builds for FJP (ixtun) Midrange. I've been very happy with most of the cards, so I'll give you a quick rundown of my key card choices. Then I'll address some of the points that I'm not so high on, and what could be done to fix those.

- Defiance
Defiance is the only real answer to amaran stinger. That alone makes it worth including. It's also a great answer to any aggro deck, as well as merchants. However, it's a reactive removal spell as opposed to a proactive one. This means that you can't respond to something like Palace's buff by killing the unit, which is a large downside. I think 3-of is a good spot, given the wealth of anti-aggro removal this deck already has.

- Strategize
With all the fate cards we play strategize is essentially a 2-cost wisdom of the elders. Always play 4 copies.

- Smugglers
These are the best smugglers in the game, so definitely play 4 of each.

- Vargo
Vargo is a great combo with harsh rule, and is just a good unit in general. He's not on the level of Vara or SST, but he's good enough for our purposes.

- Harsh Rule
Amazing combo with Vargo, just a good card in general for catching us back up.

- Jotun Hurler
Good anti-aggro, pops aegis, card advantage with strat/smugglers. What's there not to like?

- WWH
A good 5-drop, which is something these xo midrange decks tend to lack. Also has the potential to just "oops, I win" with the market scattershot

- Howling Peak vs Korovyat Palace
Howling peak has mirror image, palace has withstand. Peak has kaleb's choice, palace has wisdom. But where peak has gun down, arguably the most important spell in its repertoire, Palace has garbage. Palace is a good card, and has utility for punishing permafrost and just beating down, but peak is the better maindeck card by far.

- Xo
Never less than 4 xo.

Strengths:
- Near-infinite value, similar to FTP
- Harsh Rule to reset the board
- "oops, I win" combo of WWH + Scattershot
- Decent answers to Amaran Stinger
- Great against aggro

Weaknesses:
- peak is a clunky card
- vargo is not the greatest 4-drop, herald is not the greatest 5-drop
- can get overwhelmed by fatties if you don't find removal in time

A camrin sacrifice aggro/value/whatever deck, based heavily on Kaelos' Scraptank Milos deck. Display of Ambition is insanely great here, as it deals with literally all your problems:

- Sandstorm Titan blanking your attacks
- A huge Camrin being chump blocked
- Running out of units

Desecrate is another big boon for this deck, giving us a cheap way to clear blockers without taking a turn off to Slay them.

Not sure how good it is yet, but it can do some pretty silly stuff.

The concept behind this deck started with me wanting to make Camrin, the Fox work, and has gone through a few changes since my first version.

The deck shares some synergies with Stonescar lists, having a solid self-sacrifice package to gain value. Combust is, as usual, one of the MVP's, and Casualties of the Cause from Homecoming seems to a valuable addition with similar synergy. Camrin fits into this gameplan nicely, as well as providing extra juice for the late game, letting you really turn games around. Madness is amazing and can singlehandedly win games, but you don't need me to tell you that.

With regards to synergies geared towards Camrin, the deck includes Secret Passage to help her meet her conditions and Kerendon Merchant works well with her, often being a card your opponent won't enjoy blocking. The small revenge package of Piercing Grief and Stonepowder Alchemist are good cards in general, but work especially well with the sacrifice synergy, and both help with health gain. In quite a few games, I've gone below 5 health only to be pulled back by clutch healing from them.

Hojan, Crownbreaker is mostly just here as a good card, but can have his renown activated by both Casualties and Obsidian Armor if necessary. In the same category is Regent's Tomb, which is just generally good, and the Sabotage effect is invaluable against some decks.

This is quite a janky deck, but it's performing decently in casual, and it's very fun to play, regardless of quality. If you try it, please tell me if you enjoy it. Also feel free to comment if you made any changes, and tell me if they work well. I'm always interested in feedback. Cheers!

Simple to understand hard to master.

Ramp into Diogo, then chain big spells. The part that makes the deck really hard to master is the market. When in doubt, Diogo early and let the market recover the explosive state in case of fizzle.

You typically explode on turn 5. This means you lose hard to aggro and win against midrange/control as long as they don't have negates or early sweepers.

Thinking i was going to be the first to post a deck with Diogo I saw Sunnyveil already had one up but this was my take on it which i came up with last night with success against most midrange decks. aggro can still be a problem if you miss landrops. The difference between mine and Sunnys version is that im not going all in on the invoke the waystones plan hence why only 1 in the market. Ways to combo:

Master cartographer or Honor of claws - discard spell...excavate spell to the top same turn you amplify diogo

or
West wind herald discarded spell

If your running into alot of harsh rules you wanna go the invoke the waystones route as no deck can grind you through that. you market for invoke discard it excavate to the top then diogo...next turn you draw your entire ddeck completely till you have around under 3 cards make sure you have lumen reclaimer already in your hand before doing this or a merchant or you risk losing the game. Hey you! Do you like Wump, Party Starter? Did you ever sit quietly in your bed at night, wondering why you can't have a deck that is all Wump? This deck is not, but it gets close.

To get the obvious out of the way: This is a meme deck. I mean look at it! But it actually got me through Gauntlet a couple of times and somehow works out in Casual as well.

Let me get to the Strategy:

Wump, Party Starter is obviously the heart of this deck and Messenger Hawk, Mirror Image, Sudden Schism and Quicksilver Mirror are here to kick of literal landslides of furry monsters and their cold, hard snowballs into the enemy's face.
With around 10% of the main deck being Wump or Merchants, you should be able to play Wump by turn 3 or 4.If it takes longer, you should be able to stall somewhat awkwardly. Once Wump is out, try to copy him as fast as possible, so that the enemy has a hard time to remove all that fur from the board. Spiritward Shaman may help you stop the odd spell or curse aimed at your or Wumps shaggy little heads.
Avigraft and Rain of Frogs are your biggest threats here. Luckily, you are playing a Primal deck and have Cobalt Waystone, Eilyn's Favor and the Shaman to protect you somewhat reliably.
The rest of the deck is designed either to stall, build on Wump's Yeti-bonus. Infiltrate automatically when played after Wump and most importantly, draw cards so you can Wump faster and harder.

A few tricks:
If you have a copying spell and a merchant on your hand, get the Shaman from your market, copy the merchant and get some Wump.
Remember that you can proc Infiltrate with Wumps ability.
Justa, Regglar Jotun can be hit by one of your own snowballs.

I am still unsure about putting Mating Call in here, as it disappointed me most of the time. The Sidedeck cards are all viable copy-cards, though I like to stay with the classics.

Snatch that relic hate then bone 'em.

The legend rides again.

A.k.a. Ixtun Palace V3. I really think we're getting somewhere here.

This is a Justice-heavy bulletshaper version, which lets us do some extremely cool things like play Sherrif Marley as a stabilising 4-drop, or drop a Palace on turn 4 to make a Red Canyon Smuggler a 6/6 aegis endurance double damage. This version should hit power more consistently thanks to the Privilege of Rank, but I might end up finding out that 4 rank and 3 wisdom is too many do-nothings, in which case I'll likely opt to replace the Wisdoms with more interaction.

I wanted to mess around with the new cards from Homecoming to see if the support that Pledge got will make it viable. I chose TJP as my shell because while Primal doesn't really have the same powerful Pledge units that the other factions have, I think Korovyat Palace is an absolute bomb of a card so I wanted to include it. In many ways this deck takes some inspiration from the old 4 Peaks Jennev Midrange deck and its game plan is mostly similar: cycle through your deck and develop your power base early while answering early threats from the opponent, and then close out the game with the deck's powerful and efficient units.

Some notes on the deck
Aniyah, Arctic Sheriff: Aniyah can be a really strong card, but this deck lacks the ability to trigger her Renown apart from Palace, therefore I'm only running 2 copies of her. As a Pledge unit, I think she's too good not to include, but this is something to keep in mind. Jamming in extra spells or weapons didn't seem worth it to me, but if you really dislike not being to Renown her you could possibly fit Sword of Unity in somehow, although you'd probably have to cut Hooru Pacifier to do that.

Korovyat Palace: I think this card is extremely strong, possibly on the same power level as Howling Peak. Right now I'm testing out 3 in the maindeck and 1 in the market, but there's the potential that just one in the market could be sufficient.

Sandstorm Titan: Not including Titan is probably a mistake and its likely just a better inclusion than Pacifier, but I have to see how I like Pacifier before I come to my decision.

The market is the part of the deck that I'm least happy with. Switching to just one copy of Palace in the market lets you run Great Valley Smuggler instead of Jennev Merchant and opens up some additional options to consider in the market (like the Sword of Unity I mentioned above). There's also a chance that this could be an 8 merchant deck, although I'd only consider that if I end up cutting the maindeck Palaces.

I'm sure this deck will need some tweaking as I start to figure out its strengths and weaknesses, but so far it's been very fun to play.

This is my first time posting any brews so I apologize if I leave anything important out.

The goal of this deck is to survive the early game against aggro with removal and the early blocker Glasshopper which also generates significant value with its summon ability. The midgame is the time to stabilize/win game with the threats of Sandstorm Titan , Severin, the Mad Mage, and Moonstone Vanguard. The late game is almost a sure win with Apex Predator and Quicksilver Mirror providing a huge amount of value.

This deck is extremely good at generating value so trading deficits when stabilizing are often ok.


Notable Cards:
Glasshopper : The start of the deck. Originally the deck was a spam of weak pledge minions, but I realized this card can be so much more useful in a shell with less but high impact pledge units. Great early blocker and the cost reduction is incredibly useful especially for stabilizing against aggro.

Bear Guard Bayonet : Surprisingly decent card. Plays the power undepleted so its incredibly powerful and efficient ramp. In games where you miss pledge on turn 1 it's bad but not unplayable

Display of Knowledge : The card that supports throwing random relics in the deck. It's great for surprising blockers, drawing into that Xenan Obelisk or Eye of Winter , or yeeting an attacker into the nether realm.

Call for Aid : Very powerful fast speed ramp card, but it's a bit awkward. The 4 drop slot is pretty saturated, but the effect is powerful and the ramp is significant. This card is very welcome late game as this deck doesn't usually reach 9 power for Apex Predator . Edit: too slow for this deck

Apex Predator : The level 99 Chad boss of the mafia. Endurance, Killer, Ambush, and Pledge make this card insane if you can play it. Killer + Endurance allows it to kill and then block in the upcoming turn.

Quicksilver Mirror : Extremely powerful but kind of slow. The discount it gets from Severin, the Mad Mage is great and is what got its place in the market over Azindel, Revealed . This card is great at breaking board stalls especially if you have units with killer. Doesn't seem too necessary for the deck. Mirror image could just be better

Severin, the Mad Mage : Arguably the best card in this deck. The discounts are extremely relevant for all relics, especially for the activables like the rings and Eye of Winter

This deck is extremely rough so any input is welcome. All of the cards in the deck work decently, but I'm not sure what exactly are the weaker links.

Edit: This deck really relies on a decent midgame so I put in Initiate of Sands to ramp through the early game and took out Hailstorm and Call for Aid
A variant on FJS grenadin, leveraging Carmin the Fox as a slightly cheaper draw engine.

The deck is fun and effective so far in limited testing. I would ABSOLUTELY put in a fourth Cykalis, the Burning Sand if you have it. (I refuse to craft a fourth copy of something in the new set because then I'll def pull it from a pack.)

Haven't had any problems activating pledge in a pleasant way. Anything is a viable pledge target but Cykalis is probably the best. A turn two glasshopper into a turns 3 and 4 Cykalis is pretty amazing. Teacher and Ponysnatcher are removal magnets.

I only have one Xenan Temple which is why its in the market but it has great synergy with Dread. I pulled a Heart of the Vault from my void last game.

Star-Reader's Blade is great on any of the units but prob best on the Glasshopper.

Went with the smuggler instead of Kerendon Merchant so that when I ponysnatch I have more chances I'll be able to play it. But the merchant's body is way more useful so we'll see.

Would love to hear how the deck treats you and how you improve upon it! Have fun!

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Blackhall Warleader and Stormtamer Operative: Warleader is a really good option in a Midrange deck that, while it has really solid choices along the curve, could use a couple extra stats on its units. Stormtamer Operative is one of those cards that takes advantage of a blind spot with the AI: It doesn't take it's ability into account before using removal. It will continually try and Torch 3-health units. It will continually try to ping 1-health units with Temper and Vara's Favor. It's ridiculous the amount of work Operative does just by sitting on the board.

Other Choices: Dusk Raider, Fenris Nightshade, Kerendon Steward, Ripknife Assassin, Tavia, Lethrai Raidleader, Twilight Raptor

3-Drops
Rhysta, Acantha's Herald and Skycrag Scalebreaker: Rhysta is an aggressive early game unit that also helps with Fixing. The weapon Scalebreaker creates can either be used as Market fodder, or attached to a unit to give it evasion (Warleader is a nice option).

Other Choices: Auric Interrogator, Gorgon Fanatic

4-Drops
Rindra, the Duskblade: A staple in this slot in a lot of Feln Midrange decks. Good stats, solid keywords, and card draw in one unit. While Vara, Vengeance-Seeker would be the other auto-include in this slot, the inclusion of Champion of Cunning means she sits this one out. The other options weren't too exciting, so I added a bit more removal to the list.

Other Choices: Impending Doom, Midnight Gale, Torgov, Icecap Trader, Vara, Vengeance-Seeker

5-Drops
Champion of Cunning: Probably the first unit most players think of with regard to the Feln faction. I tend to favor the Aegis ability first, because the AI will definitely throw removal at it, but if the pump ability is active, I'll play the unit out.

Other Choices: Jotun Feast-Caller

6-Drops
Black-Sky Harbinger: Champion/Harbinger have been closing out Feln Midrange decks since the very beginning. While Harbinger lacks the stats usually associated with a top-end unit, the evasion, life gain, and board impact make it an easy choice.

Other Choices: Thunderstrike Dragon

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Other Choices: Cull the Deck, Dark Return, Devour, Wisdom of the Elders

Fixing
Seek Power: Most of my Midrange builds do not run 1-Drops because, for the most part, they are underwhelming. That leaves Seek Power as the best solution for Fixing, as it can give the deck something to do turn 1.

Other Choices: Petition, Vara's Favor

Market
Kerendon Merchant: Primal offers no Relic removal options for the Market, so Kerendon Merchant is the pick here. Neither Merchant is very exciting as a unit, however.

Other Choices: Jennev Merchant

Miscellaneous
Dizo's Office: Unit removal, card draw, life gain, and a solid Agenda payoff makes the Office a decent pick here. I don't usually go out of my way to protect the site, however.

Other Choices: Madness, Mirror Image

Unit Removal
Desecrate: This card has "Feln" written all over it. It pairs especially well with Stormtamer Operative, as the damage it deals to you is reduced by the Operative's ability.

Permafrost: While decent as an early-game control option, I tend to use Permafrost as a way to remove blockers from combat. They're also pretty effective against annoying Revenge units like Inquisitor Makto and Elias, the Broken Wing.

Other Choices: Annihilate, Crystallize, Deathstrike, Feeding Time, Rindra's Choice

Power
Power Sources: 33 (25 power, 4 Rhysta, Acantha's Herald, and 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 26 sources of Primal and 23 sources of Shadow (counting Diplomatic Seal and Seek Power as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

This is my janky brew that I was inspired to make with Severin. Dies to people that notice that rats can't block. Chalice is great with Severin though, shimmerpacking a ton of rats and stampeding them feels great

It's homecoming, and here comes the homecoming queen, Svetya.


Wanted to make a "JP" deck without "F", plus with the new campaign cards.


** Deck's Engine**

This deck utilizes around Privilege of Rank. Helps you draw Justice Sigils, so no mana block and extra targets for market.

Following cards are discard cards.

1. Herald's Song
2. Master Cartographer
3. Workshop Tinker


**Renown Mechanic**

Following Cards that are renown,

1. Hojan, Crownbreaker
2. Aniyah, Arctic Sheriff

Hojan goes really well with this deck. Lifesteal, push potential with extra sigil power boost. However, Hojan is also used as a removal eater. Taking elimination cards in the beginning phase for the team. Aniyah acts as mid range annoyance for your opponent. Rarely this deck will carry out victory in early phase of the game. Often you will find yourself either losing or winning by the end of mid-game. Plus she gets really reliable once she gets aegis, buying your little bit more time and making your opponent use 2 cards against your 1 card. (Pledge actually saved my opening hands few times.)


**Weapon Cards**

1. Vanquisher's Blade

For renowns and removal(plus voidbound). Since this deck runs Privilege of Rank, many times you'll find yourself having 5 mana by turn 5. It's pretty easy to pull off vanquish when you need to.


**Aggro + Swarm Stoppers**

1. Copperhall Bailiff (Also AoE Aegis Popper)
2. Harsh Rule (3 copies)
3. End of the Story (1 copy in market)

This deck don't use Primal AoE damage cards such as Hailstorm. Instead, it banks on heavy removal with low mana cost minions till mid-mid late game.

**Late Game**

1. Svetya, Orene of Kosul (After mana 8, draw Minions, preferably after your deck gets shined by Svetya, Merciful Orene. (Plus, buys you a turn from your opponent with spells)
2. Svetya, Merciful Orene (Buffs your deck + Aegis Beat Stick)
3. Telut, Queen's Hand (Plays well with renowns, and reliable if you have at least a single minion card on the field before summon)
4. Korovyat Palace (Just 2 copies. Any more than that felt like a dead hand since it has no removal. In my opinion, with "6-costs draw-2" doesn't justify having more than 2 copies in your deck.)

You only really need one Svetya, Merciful Orene in your market. Her cost isn't so good like other scion cards. So often she becomes a dead hand until later phase. Better to have her in the market, and bring it out right before you are ready.


**Market**

1. Vision of Austerity (Since no Bore, I used this.)
2. Honor of Claws (Surprisingly I felt good having this in the market. Not just because it has target for Privilege of Rank, but giving you opportunity to cope with bad hand.


**Conclusion**

Still Work in Progress. But wanted to share. Tell me how it goes.

Thanks.

A different take on an Ixtun Palace deck, this time inspired somewhat by Manu's Winchest Zuberi list from the World Championships last year. Zuberi dying for no value to something like Slay is legitimately problematic, but fortunately this list has 16 cheap pieces (8 smugglers, 4 strategize, and 4 wisdom) to instantly gain value from him if that's something you're worried about in slower matchups. Whirling Duo gains life and wears a Withstand well, and the rest of the deck is fairly standard fire and primal smuggler draw and removal stuff. The market is the bit I'm most uncertain about atm. I think Deepforged Plate is a firm inclusion because pulling it with Red Canyon Smuggler puts a very firm clock on an opponent in a topdecking situation. Howling Peak is probably the best late-game powerhouse here, even if it rubs up against the maindeck Palaces, purely because Martyr's Chains costing JJJJ is fairly difficult for this deck to achieve off of only 12 justice sources. Bore is great. Skycrag Banner might be unnecessary, and Jawbone Greatsword could be a Burn Them All. I wish this deck had soemthing comparable to Statuary Maiden, something that all 8 smugglers could pull on turn 3 to play on turn 4 and force an aggressive opponent to have removal or be stonewalled. Unfortunately, I don't think these colours have access to anything of that nature and power level just yet.

Edit: It occurs to me that if you cut Wisdom of the Elders for Privilege of Rank, probably then finding room for Bulletshaper, then you could possibly justify Martyr's Chains in the market. An idea to explore.

So this is basically a "Time" take on FJS - replacing our FJS Gauntlet deck: https://eternalwarcry.com/decks/details/MMUIN2HFG1w/fjs-gauntlet-march-2019

We lose Xo, Bore, Torch, Maiden, etc. We replace some of the Smugglers and Displays accordingly, and we gain Sand Storm Titan and the Xenan Temple - which is pretty good - as well as Finest Hour (replacing Torch).

So, how does it do compared to FJS? Well, we still have our Saviors that remain all stars - and in fact are slightly better in the TJS shell. Why? Because of finest hour. Our 1/1's turn still eat premium removal and kill the x/1's like Oni Ronin - but now they get a combat trick to eat AI creatures. It's not a HUGE deal, but it is something.

The deck plays similarly to FJS in that we still have all of the Defiances, slays, vanquish, etc. However, our influence requirements are slightly more taxing since we now have 8 Four Drops in Little Vara and Sand Storm Titan to go with our 3 Drop Bailiffs - so that's TT JJ and SS. Accordingly, I have gone with Petition over Seek Power. I do not know if that is correct, but it seems good?

I was very uneasy about the Ebon Smuggler. That 2/2 body for 3 without the double damage upside worried me, and I actually tried the Auralian Merchant in its place at first. But Auralian just limited our Market too much, and grabbing Harsh Rule was already hard enough with only having 4 Justice Merchants versus 8 in FJS. So I wanted something that could grab all three Sites in the Market and ended up with Ebon. It took me a while to get used to figuring out when to run out Ebon, but it's actually really nice to have an ambush creature as another way to surprise the AI.

I chose Varas Choice to replace Maiden - after experimenting with a myriad of options. Since we no longer have Bore, our 4 Displays take care of that issue - and all three options for the Display are actually quite good versus the AI decks - combat tricks, board wipes, fixing, ramp and sometimes just digging with Scout Crests trying to find an answer. Oh, and the Displays are nice fast speed buffs for lethal when attacking with Regent's Tomb.

We actually end up casting the Saviors in this deck more often than in FJS, and the sites are an integral part of the overall game plan. Overall, I "think" the deck is slower than FJS just because we seem to have more options than FJS. FJS sometimes provides very specific lines that are the only ones we can reasonably choose, whereas this deck gives you aggressive vs safe choices - neither of which is necessarily wrong, but the safe choice allows us to increase our win percentage at the expense of playing out a little slower.

Having said that, I want to be clear that losing Xo definitely hurts some of the consistency, but having 8 high end 4 Drops that highly impact the board can result in some very fast games. So is this deck better? I am on the fence here, and would love to hear some feedback and thoughts about many of the deck choices such as thoughts on:

1) Petition versus Seek Power
2) Vara's Choice versus ???
3) Xenan Temple/Dizo versus Passage of Eons or ???
4) Merchants? Anyone like some of the mono colored ones better??

I think the win percentage is relatively the same as FJS - and this deck might be slightly better against the Bosses, not sure about that. Regardless, I actually enjoy this deck more than FJS right now as I have gotten a little burned out with that deck and this one seems to have a little more "play" with it.

Hope you enjoy it!!

This is a variation on a storm deck in which you try to play a lot of draw spells through having two Tamarys out in play and then capitalize on it somehow. My choice of capitalization? A big stick in the form of Staff of the Arch-Magister, which is regularly a 20/20 weapon for 5. Naturally, I tried to put other win conditions in here too through Rizahn, Xo, Howling Peak, and Plate.

This is not a tier 1 deck by any means, but it does win games and I have fun while playing it. It's especially fun to start a chain of 0 cost draw cards and then have your opponent concede just because.

I also made a variation with shadow instead of justice using Vara. Both are fun, this is just the decklist I decided to post (though happy to post the other if anyone wants. Tamarys is fun and the longer the game is out, the better she gets.

This market needs some real work, I have never pulled anything except clutch and the palace.

Getting the site down will usually win the game, sheriff is overpowered in this deck and then real mvp.

Kosul brigade should probably be Quinn for competitiveness but the theme is just too much fun at the moment and then I'm not sure what you would replace the privilege of rank with.

The idea behind this deck is to use Imperial Loyalist to renown out stuff you may need at any particular time and Hojan and Icaria to ramp you up into big stuff that can carry you to victory. Mirror Image and Skycrag Goad are great renown enablers on the loyalist, but the best is Korovyat which can cheat out any unit in the deck while giving her a giant buff. Unseen Commando and Anniyah are also good targets for mirroring. Note that if you play Sudden Schism as a combat trick on Anniyah, she does not get to stun any unit.

This is an aggro focused Ixtun deck using some of the best cards in the game with Xo and Hojan, while trying to incorporate the new cards I think are strong. This build has been performing very solid in Master rank. Play aggressive and keep pressure on the opponent, this deck has a lot of firepower.

I'm really liking Korovyat Palace. The Withstand unit buff is usually my number one choice, as it can trigger your Hojan Renown (and also if you want to run Aniyah) or it can turn Rizahn and Red Canyon Smuggler into a lot of face damage. Wisdom of the Elders gives you needed draw, and Sack the City is another win condition with just a couple big units out. The icing on the cake is the static Endurance that all your 4+ attack units get (including Rizahn, despite his Reckless). After the site goes off you can use Svetya to dig for even more units with her Pay 8 ability. Palace in this build has been a much stronger main deck card over Howling Peak.

I'm also running Svetya because she feels like an insane card right now, she wards off removal/locks your opponent out of spells while you continue to drop minions and push damage. I was running 3x Aniyah in this deck, but swapped her out for Jotun Hurler, which feels way more natural here (though Aniyah also works fine), with the added card advantage and extra Snowball spells to combo with Howling Peak Smuggler. Display of Honor has been huge in this deck, it can fish your Plate/Blade weapons back, give you unit damage, or a much needed polymorph effect. I'm also running a Howling Peak in the market, which has been pretty clutch certain games (copying a giant Aegis unit etc.), or especially when you don't draw Palace for turn 6.

Why each card is in the deck.

Power Base-

It’s very simple but has been pretty balanced so far, maybe needs a bit of tinkering but not bad for a 5F deck.

Units-

Smugglers, Xo, Brel. Efficient units that have great value. Smugglers are great early game units that get the best market options for your situation. Xo is an incredibly powerful unit that works as good Market fodder and can be bought out later. Brel was chosen mostly since she fits well with both Display of Ambition AND Display of Honor which I’ll address later.

Displays-

Display of Ambition- Solid removal and every unit in the deck is a fantastic buyback target. The Overwhelm mode is pretty irrelevant.

Display of Honor- Weakest Display by far and is probably better off as a Hailstorm or Wispm of the Elders but I like the Display suite theme. Transforming units can be important in matchups with Display of Ambition and Reanimator. Lifesteal and a surprise pump is great but we have limited units so it’s typically not an option. Being able to buyback Brel’s Mallet comes up occasionally and it’s a sweet synergy.

Display of Instinct- Probably our best Display overall. Great removal that also deals with Sites, able to counter key spells in matchups such as reanimator and FJS, can occasionally bounce units which is pretty good since it either resets Xo or a Merchant or we can replay Brel and get another Mallet OR the dream of pumping an existing Mallet.

Display of Knowledge- Likely our second best Display. QuickDraw clause is mostly irrelevant, we run a package of Relics that can synergize with our game plan or pull ahead and we want to make sure we know which relic we want in each matchup. Gavel for Void abusing decks, Crown is mostly for fun but has been solid against Temporal and other Control decks, Daisho is great against control decks that can’t deal with relics and can just eat multiple units if needed, Knuckelbones is a win condition, as is Martyr’s Chains, and Temporal is great when the board is clear so we can be full control. The unit tucking ability is excellent for making it through the early game by removing units.

Display of Vision- mostly here for Ramp and fixing but also extremely important against token style decks and being able to remove cards like opposing Chains/Eternity Core/Temporal/Crown is fantastic

Other Spells-

Harsh Rule-Sweeper to help stabilize

Seek Power-Fixing

Market-Every card can be found by either Smuggler

Slay-Unconditional removal
Regent’s Tomb-Fantastic card to follow a Smuggler. Disrupts opponent, helps hit power, possible win condition.
Memento Mori-Ramp and fixing for our crazy deck
Shatterglass Mage-A body that also removes attachments
Moment of Creation- An excellent win condition that is frequently 8+. This card has really overperformed

Any questions? Leave a comment for me below =) Hope you enjoy

This is my fire deck full of gunslingers. I always like On The Hunt because it's a 4/4 cost 2 fire and has charge. I put in a lot of weapons because I like boosting my units attack and health. I put in the best fire spells I have in it also. I added Bad News & Jekk, Hunted Fugitive, I decided to add disrupt to deal with a really annoying unit that can silence every turn for 4 power cost.

I feel like Ixtun is actually pretty well positioned in Hero's Welcome since you have a mix of nice draw options, inspire effects, pledges, rewnowns, removal, and a few solid tutor options. This lets you more easily neutralize enemy threats while snowballing by yourself.

I chose Xo of the Endless Hoard as my hero since, simply put, this is arguably one of the best cards in the game at this time so you want him in your hand early and often. Giving him aegis or unblockable on top of his already-copious bonuses is also wonderful.

This list has taken me to 6-3 and 7-2 finishes in its current form. I'm not sure I'll have time to play my last 5 leaderboard runs this event. A better pilot would likely have more success with it.

If I do change anything, it will be to add further power tutors (such as Kaleb's Favor) but I think the deck is already pretty compelling as-is.

Description
Even ramp deck that aims to play big threats. Even means that you should ramp with even cost spells.
To fully show power efficiency this deck uses mostly even cost with small exceptions.

Deck Design
- 28 Units, 16 win cons 12 with Pledge
- 8 Ramp relics
- 12 Spells, 4 utility, 4 Ramp, 6 Draw
- 25 Sigils

Game Plan
You absolutely need a pledge card in starting hand, so you redraw until you have one. It doesn't mean that you will have no chance winning if you will have none, but Glasshopper will be less effective.
Also as a second part of play you need at least 1 card with ramp for 2 power. Crucial part is influence management, you need 3 Primal for Daraka, Queensguard and Eilyn, the Rising Storm, also you need 3 Time influence for Apex Predator.

Synergies
- Glasshopper: reason why you play this deck. It cycles itself into big threats and reduce their cost at same time. It is arguable best card in deck.
Moonstone Vanguard, Eilyn, the Rising Storm, Apex Predator, Tunneling Gargantua our cards that work with hopper.
- Daraka, Queensguard + Eilyn, the Rising Storm: Daraka is very underplayed card, good stats and control potential, also has a neat synergy with all Eilyn units, making them hard to counter.

Cards & Reasoning
- Messenger Hawk: more copies for our cards.
- Seek Power: another t1 play that helps in stabilization, searches for us such needed Sigils.
- Glasshopper, Trail Maker, Power Stone: t2 ramps with different tasks. Glasshopper gets our pledged threats, Trail Maker leads us to desired influence levels, Power Stone is a simple ramp that doesn't fear unit removal.
- Honor of Claws: Good draw effect.
- Call for Aid, Eternity Core: our t3 ramp. Call for Aid is a fast ramp with cycle and gain life effect and Eternity Core is a great ramp that doesn't afraid of unit removal.
- Moonstone Vanguard, Eilyn, the Rising Storm, Apex Predator: pledge finishers with great benefit from Glasshopper synergy. Eilyn and Apex can be used as a unit removal in different ways. Moonstone is a card generation mechanism and guardian of life total.
- Daraka, Queensguard: removal & protection for Eilyn on a big body that is hard to block.
- Eilyn, the Rising Storm, Tunneling Gargantua, Apex Predator our fatties. Also you can consider all of those as a removal coz they will kill in most cases opponent's units.

If you pleased with a deck then don't forget to hit that like button.
If you have questions about deck you can ask it in comment section

Main deck
the original deck had statuary maiden in place of bandit queen
the idea of the deck is to get in for instant damage the turn you play a unit and the oathbook allows the unit to potentially trade or win the battle if its in play, and also combos well with the display as recurring any of the buffed units is a bonus, the non charge unit in the deck is baby vara, but feel this is a necessary inclusion for the life gain for the display and for the removal of aegis allowing for 1 for 1 removal. harsh rule or other board wipes don't really hurt the deck too much either as you can usually just play out a unit and attack with it next turn and even ruling your own board is fine, if you are on 8 power you can rule and still play and attack with whirling duo

Market
the original market had avigraft in place of gavel, as i removed or switched out maiden for bandit queen i wanted some anti void recursion, but this is my preference
update (apr 2019) I took out Icaria the Liberator and put in Xo instead even though this does not have charge the immediate value it can give when drawn from the market and when drawn from the void makes up for this as well as the potential draw and damage on attack, and still giving you an evasive unit and in testing found I wasn't really using Icaria too much so wanted something that would be useful even if I didn't play it, I have also added urn of chocking embers as another way to remove aegis and to allow you to attack in while they are stunned - this is a flex slot though and I have tried deep forged plate and obliterate in this slot, but it could also be a vanquish or vanquishers blade or even martyrs chains or some other choice

This deck is a variation of my first eternal deck, and though it was built around my early legendary cards it still runs reliably, and in general is an all around fun feel deck.
The premise of the deck is to stall and maintain board control long enough to play Champion of Cunning, ideally with it's a shadow effect enabled, and grow the strength of your token cards from there.

Ripknife Assassin is in my opinion one of the best 2 drops in the game allowing early control and the use of warcry to boost your units stats.

The other 2 drop, Lethrai Target Caller, has good synergy with champion of cunning, the former adding quickdraw while the latter boost attack strength only.

Lastly, while the inclusion of vara prevents CoC's aegis effect, her disruptive nature and utility to maintain board control, makes her worth the cost.

As always, let me know what you think. All comments are appreciated.

Ramping into some very, very powerful cards. Built the deck to just stay alive in the early game and win out mid to late damn near always. Honestly, none of my games were particularly close. Double Wisdom of the Elders, double Linebreaker's Shield, double Infused Guardian and a legitimate bomb in Predatory Carnosaur is about as good as you can realistically ask for. Rallying Banner is also an absurdly powerful, almost always first pick (almost being if there is some absolutely ridiculous rare in the pack) card that can win games on its own.

Key to this format = take the best card out of any given pack, period, and then just figure out the mana after the fact. The decks that lose are the ones that simply do not have enough truly powerful cards.

This is my version of Elysian Chalice Control for Gauntlet play. Lets take a look at the cards:

Deck Strategy
A very typical Chalice deck. Try to survive the early game until you can get a Chalice into play, and then slowly outvalue your opponent. Most of the units offer additional value beyond meeting the requirements for Chalice, and it is possible to win a game without finding a Chalice (especially with a Crow in play).

Win Condition
Crystalline Chalice: The backbone of the deck. The drawback of its ability (exhausting a unit) can be negated with Infinite Hourglass. Getting multiples into play usually snowballs into a rather quick (well…quick for the deck) win.

Units
Acquisitive Crow: There are a lot of really useful 1-cost spells, which makes Crow a second win condition in the deck. I don't usually have a problem finding a Chalice, but there have been games where Chalice hasn't been necessary because the AI didn't have an answer to Crow. A tremendous value generator in this deck.

Amaran Camel: The stabilizer. Gain health off of a few draws and the AI will start prioritizing the Camels with its removal, leaving your other units to flex their muscles. The deck wouldn't be as consistent without them.

Amaran Stinger: The scorpions certainly don't need to be buffed to be effective, but they do provide extra targets for Chalice. Worst case scenario, she is a pretty decent early game blocker thanks to 4 health.

Bazaar Trickster: A great card in a deck that usually ends up with a great deal of power. I try not to play it until I can activate it at least once, but that isn't always possible. The fact that the ability can be triggered even if the Trickster is exhausted is key to its value here.

Campfire Watchman: An absurd early game ground blocker that can be buffed with Chalice to a 4 / 10 stat line. I feel like it was made for Chalice decks.

Ephemeral Wisp: Another early game ground blocker that can absorb a lot of damage.

Pteriax Hatchling: The extra copies can be used as Market fodder, or they can be used to exploit the AI's disdain for anything with Flying.

Scorpion Wasp: Not really a Chalice target, but I have buffed one before. Wasp is really the only answer the deck has to really big threats. The bane of Sandstorm Titans everywhere.

Other Choices: Archive Curator, Breeze Dancer, Derry Cathain, Ripclaw Rider, Dusk Raider, Illumination Wisp, Lumen Defender, Sand Viper, Snowcrust Yeti, Stormtamer Operative, Veteran Strategist, Waystone Infuser

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Other Choices: Call for Aid, Moondial, Temple Scribe, Wisdom of the Elders

Fixing
Seek Power: There aren't a lot of tricky influence requirements in the deck - just double Primal for Chalice and Crow - so I went with the cheapest option.

Other Choices: Amber Acolyte, Find the Way, Petition

Market
Auralian Merchant: Another good early blocker. The ramp isn't as important as the 4 health or the ability to grab a Chalice, but it can help.

Other Choices: Jennev Merchant

Unit Removal
Permafrost: Usually, once the deck gets rolling, removal isn't necessary, so I went with the best early game option. A great answer to annoying early game Oni and Yeti.

Other Choices: Equivocate, Passage of Eons

Power
Power Sources: 33 (25 power, 4 Auralian Merchant, and 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 22 sources of Time and 23 sources of Primal (counting Diplomatic Seal and Seek Power as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

Sick draft deck that rolled over 5 other Master level players en route to a 7-0. Life is easy when you open two bombs of the same color (though they were in the third and fourth pack, respectively). A lot of people don't like them, but the Viper's Bites were really good and in this deck with multiple Renown triggers, a 1/5 Flying, double Fireheart Recruit and several large dudes they simply made a lot of sense.

Noteworthy cards in my sideboard-

1 Scorpion (the last cut- I really wanted to play it)
2 Awaken the Ages (tempting to ramp into one of my good 5 drops but I just couldn't find room and I hate that it's a RANDOM Sigil)
1 Sirocco Elementalist (meh... I think this card is playable but almost always underwhelming. It only makes my bad decks as an in general)
1 Copperhall Porter (I have many better 2 drops and in this case the ability hardly matters. Yes, a Sigil is a Sigil, but Green is my lightest color as it is and I don't ever need double Green so essentially I'm just playing a bad creature, that I can't always even play on turn 2 mind you, that digs up an essentially colorless Sigil when it dies)
1 Siraf's Beacon (I don't see myself as a really fast beatdown deck which is what this card wants and I wanted to play as few Green cards as possible to make my mana base more consistent since I don't have as much fixing as I'd like and I have very powerful cards in White that I need to be able to play reliably when I draw them)
1 Sky Crew (I don't see myself having trouble finishing games- I think my late game is super strong as is- and again I wanted to play as few Green cards as realistically possible for the sake of my mana base)
1 Skycrag Huntsman (The argument can be made that this should have been played over Lazy Firemane. Most of the time if I survive til late game I probably win. I opted for a more aggressive approach and I felt I had solid early game defense already, but I don't hate this swap)
1 Astromancer's Compass (I think this card is pretty underwhelming in general outside of very specific decks. I felt my card quality was high enough to where I didn't need to play this or really have room for it)

The commentary is mostly for myself and my own "putting my thoughts on paper" kind of thing, but if any of this helps anyone else, awesome! :)

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Dusk Raider and Stormtamer Operative: There are quite a few big Overwhelm units in the deck, and Dusk Raider can make them pretty difficult to block effectively. Stormtamer Operative is one of those cards that takes advantage of a blind spot with the AI: It doesn't take it's ability into account before using removal. It will continually try and Torch 3-health units. It will continually try to ping 1-health units with Temper and Vara's Favor. It's ridiculous the amount of work Operative does just by sitting on the board. That being said, drawing it late isn't great, so there are only 3 copies in the deck.

Other Choices: Resolute Monk

3-Drops
Dawnwalker and False Prince: If you can cast Xenan Initiation on Dawnwalker, it turns into a value engine. With 4 Time influence in play, every other non-2-drop, non-Merchant unit has at least 5 power, so it's pretty easy to boomerang in and out of the void. False Prince is another blind spot for the AI: It will not target it with removal unless the removal does 5 or more damage. Sometimes the AI will get lucky with a Torch only because the initial plan was to use 2 Torches, but it still ends up Torching a frog, so it's a win in my book (The best is when the AI silences the Prince!).

Other Choices: Amaran Stinger, Lunar Magus, Skycrag Scalebreaker, Teacher of Humility

4-Drops
Champion of Wisdom and Sandstorm Titan: With Titan in the deck, there isn't any pressure to get 4 Primal influence into play for the Champion, and since Dawnwalker needs 4 Time influence anyway, it's a pretty solid option here. It is the weakest of the big units, though, so there are only 3 copies in the deck. Titan is generally an auto-include in any Time-based Midrange deck, and is simply the best option in this slot.

Other Choices: Torgov, Icecap Trader

5-Drops
Cirso, the Great Glutton: Yet another great target for Xenan Initiation, and a pretty good target for a Dusk Raider buff. I don't need much of an excuse to include Cirso in an Elysian build.

Other Choices: Jotun Feast-Caller, Moonstone Vanguard

6-Drops
Worldbearer Behemoth: The top end choices were rather underwhelming, so I doubled up in the 5-drop slot. Another big Overwhelm unit to use with Dusk Raider and Xenan Initiation. It also helps thin the deck out while ramping up to 8 power for Xenan Obelisk. It is also a pretty good target for Alhed, Mount Breaker's ability.

Other Choices: Curiox, the Collector, Eilyn, the Rising Storm, Thunderstrike Dragon

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Other Choices: Ancient Lore, Call for Aid, Temple Scribe, Vital Arcana, Wisdom of the Elders

Fixing
Seek Power: Most of my Midrange builds do not run 1-Drops because, for the most part, they are underwhelming. That leaves Seek Power as the best solution for Fixing, as it can give the deck something to do turn 1.

Other Choices: Amber Acolyte, Find the Way, Petition, Secret Pages, Trail Maker

Market
Auralian Merchant and Great Valley Smuggler: Auralian Merchant brings ramp to the table, which gets the deck to the mid-game units faster. Great Valley Smuggler is a solid stat line that can get extra value from Obelisk. The deck doesn't really need 8 merchants, though, so cutting one or the other for something else wouldn't impact it too much. I just didn't see anything I liked better for the slot.

Other Choices: Crown of Possibilities, Infinite Hourglass, Jennev Merchant, Mirror Image, Pit of Lenekta

Unit Removal
Xenan Initiation: Combines really well with the big Overwhelm units in the deck (well, except for False Prince). Dawnwalker is the top choice, but I don't usually hold it to wait for the "perfect" unit.

Other Choices: Equivocate, Permafrost, Striking Snake Formation

Power
Power Sources: 33 (25 power, 4 Auralian Merchant, 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 25 sources of Time and 20 sources of Primal (counting Diplomatic Seal and Seek Power as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

This deck is based off of an Elysian Killers deck I saw on a Twitch Tournament stream. I honestly can not remember who was piloting it, nor the tournament, and I've searched high and low here for the deck with no luck. Regardless, I found it to be a pretty fun deck to play, and a nice alternative to the much more common Xenan Killers archetype. Let's take a look at the cards:

Deck Strategy
Use Hailstorm and Permafrost along with the Smuggler to stall the board early until you can start dropping the heavy mid-game units, all of which provide extra value beyond their stat lines. Use Savagery and Xenan Initiation to pick off blockers until your units have a clear path to victory.

Win Conditions
Cirso, the Great Glutton: No Elysian Killers deck is complete without Cirso. The only unit in this deck that laughs at Deadly units. Also the only unit that comes with Overwhelm (because he's better, duh). Still waiting for my Cirso avatar!

Jotun Feast-Caller: A hard-to-kill unit that draws a card or two whenever Killer is activated? OK, if I have to…

Moonstone Vanguard: Pairs with Sandstorm Titan to get around Stun-heavy decks, and pairs with Jotun Feast-Caller to provide you with plenty of options.

Sandstorm Titan: A natural for Killer decks, thanks to Endurance. Keeps fliers in check. Giant stat stick for its cost. Seems like a perfect fit for the deck!

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Wisdom of the Elders: With all of the units costing 4 or 5 power, it's best to keep the utility cards as low in cost as possible, which is why no Honor of Claws here.

Fixing
Seek Power: Plenty of options for this slot, but I didn't see a need to run anything else.

Market
Great Valley Smuggler: The deck doesn't need the ramp, so I went with the best stat line available.

Other Choices: Auralian Merchant, Jennev Merchant

Unit Removal
Hailstorm: Gets rid of the vast majority of Grenadin, Onis, Humbugs, and other annoying early game pests. With an Infinite Hourglass in play, all of the units in the deck will survive the blast.

Permafrost: Buys the time needed to get to the big units. They don't really need to stick around the whole match to be effective.

Savagery: I have really liked this card. Removing a unit, drawing a card (or cards) and pushing face damage puts you so far ahead. One of my favorite cards from Set 5 (Defiance).

Xenan Initiation: You could make an argument for Twilight Hunt because it's cheaper, but I like Initiation better in most cases.

Power
Power Sources: 31 (27 power and 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 23 sources of each color (counting Diplomatic Seal and Seek Power as a source for each).

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.
