The deck is really designed to maximize the the power of Tavrod, and put you in a position where one attack should close out the game even if he dies in combat. I'm still not in love with the market and the curve is a bit wonky, so let me know if you have any ideas or how if goes for you if you try it out.

Edit: the Seek Power made the deck feel a bit heavy on power so I'm trying Copperhall Porter and Vara's Favor instead. Should keep us from getting starved, but actually do things in games where we're flooded

Here's the only deck I managed to get seven wins with in the event. It's... it's just Argenport Midrange. You take all the cards which have ever seen play in AP Mid, jam them together, season to your preference, and choose Tavrod as your hero. You can instead swap him for Telut, if that's more your style. The deck plays mostly the same either way: play dudes, suit 'em up, see if your opponent has an answer. Eventually you play your hero, maybe. Tavrod is the better hero choice if you seem to be running into a lot of FJS; Telut is better against board stalls.

This is by no means an "optimal" list, since just like AP Mid in ranked there is a lot of room to adjust it to your preferences. Feel free to swap in things like Protect/Corrupt, more minotaurs, or replace all the legendaries with other things you have lying around. Pump spells would be fine, as would inspire units or more ways to pop face aegis.

This deck is a fairly linear attempt at a Combrei Control deck. Lets take a look at the cards:

Deck Strategy
The main avenue for victory with this deck is a giant Mystic Ascendant that has Overwhelm thanks to Porcelain Mask. There are a couple other options to help get over the finish line (Sword of the Sky King, Pit of Lenekta), but the main victory line involves controlling the board, ramping into Ascendant, drawing a bunch of options, and denying the AI the ability to chump block.

Win Conditions
Marshal Ironthorn: Ironthorn is a natural to pair with Ascendant. Extra cards, extra stats, extra power - I'm not up on the lore, but I hope the Combrei faction is as greedy in the story as their cards seem to indicate. In the event that Ascendant doesn't show up, clearing the board with Ironthorn's Ultimate can also end the game.

Mystic Ascendant: The main Win Condition of the deck. Ordinarily a somewhat lackluster board option, Set 5 (Defiance) gave Time Porcelain Mask, and the one Time card that gets A LOT better with Overwhelm is this guy. If you have the pieces already, you only really need one of these on the board (so you don't draw all of your deck).

Sword of the Sky King: A back-up Win Condition for the deck. It's actually "Plan C" (I would go with Pit over Sword if given a choice), so it's more like a back-up for the back-up, but it's still a solid option here. Relic Weapons in Gauntlet tend to force the AI to make REALLY poor attacks just to remove the weapon. It's also good at picking off annoying creatures like Blistersting Wasp and Steward of the Past.

Other Choices: Knight-Chancellor Siraf, The Great Parliament

Card Draw
Call for Aid: Combrei doesn't have the greatest options when it comes to Card Draw, so a value card like Call that also heals and ramps is pretty good.

Temple Scribe: Another value option, this time offering life gain and a chump blocker. It is odd that, in a faction devoted to learning and knowledge, this is the best Card Draw option. But I suppose the slower Card Draw in Time does make a bit of sense, flavor-wise.

Other Choices: Ancient Lore, Inspire, Moonstone Vanguard, Vital Arcana

Fixing
Find the Way: More food for the Ascendants. If the extra copy created by Echo isn't needed, it becomes the perfect option to Market away.

Seek Power: No need to overthink anything here.

Other Choices: Amber Acolyte, Petition, Privilege of Rank, Secret Pages, Trail Maker

Market
Auralian Merchant: The best option here, not because of Market choices, but because of the ramp. The fact that Justice doesn't have any answer to Relics also makes me lean towards the Time Merchant here.

Other Choices: Winchest Merchant

Miscellaneous
Worldbearer Behemoth: Feed. The. Machine. Getting a Behemoth rolling and then dropping an Ascendant is usually the quickest path to victory. It doesn't have to stay in play either - 2 or 3 power pulled out of the deck with Behemoth is generally game over.

Other Choices: Citywide Ban, Etched Monolith, Eternity Core, Infinite Hourglass, Sandstorm Scarf

Unit Removal
Defiance: The best removal choice available for the early game. Not so great against Warcry units, but Vanquish can clean up the buffed units.

Harsh Rule: Eternal's easy button. Push it when you need it.

Porcelain Mask: While played for its static ability, the Silence effect is a nice little bonus. It can clean up some really annoying units (like anything with Deadly or something like Hero of the People) and it can give you a little information about the AI's hand.

Vanquish: The standard Justice removal option. For those times where you need to get rid of a big threat, but don't want to push the easy button.

Other Choices: Auric Runehammer, Desert Marshal, Martyr's Chains, Striking Snake Formation, Valkyrie Enforcer, Xenan Initiation

Power
Power Sources: 45 (25 power, 4 Auralian Merchant, 4 Call for Aid, 4 Find the Way, and 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 31 Time sources and 26 Justice sources (counting Find the Way as 2 sources of each, and Seek Power as a source for each).

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

Decided to update my old Tavrod, now with 50% more op deck. I've been running this deck for awhile with ARK instead of Kemmo. For the recent Singleton event I crafted a copy of Kemmo and really liked him, so I lazily threw him in here instead of building around him. Performing pretty good so far, first thing I'm thinking of changing is the Chains in the market.

-Updated for Homecoming.

The gameplan is to use units to spawn relics, such as Teacher of Humility and Severin. Alternatively, Smugglers can fetch Moondial out. The end-goal is to market for Governor Sahin and cheat out Martyr's Chains, which is a guaranteed hit since there are no actual relics in the main.

Strategize can be used to tuck copies of Chains that get stuck in hand. Alternatively, the deck functions as a regular time midrange deck, and has no problem simply winning with strong units like Sandstorm Titan and Moonstone Vanguard.

Moondial is the market relic of choice, considering Severin reduces the activation, and lets you grind when you need to. Overall, this deck is pretty experimental, and I'm sure there are saner ways of utilizing the new Severin. Still, this deck will be on my testing list once Homecoming releases.

Edit: I've updated the list after some initial testing. It works rather well, and the addition of Amaran Stinger has been particularly strong.

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Awakened Student and Resolute Monk: It's hard to beat Student when it comes to 2-Drops. If not answered early, it can get pretty big, and it's a very nice target for Sword of Unity. Monk can push some nice early damage heading into Combrei's fairly stout mid-game units.

Other Choices: Hojan, Crownbreaker

3-Drops
Auric Record Keeper and Knight-Chancellor Siraf: Record Keeper is a nice stat stick that can permanently buff another unit if removed. Siraf is a good early game unit, a good target for Killer or Sword of Unity, and can win games late thanks to her ability.

Other Choices: Amaran Stinger, Lunar Magus, Teacher of Humility, Valkyrie Enforcer

4-Drops
Sandstorm Titan and Sheriff Marley: Titan is a no-brainer in a deck with no flying units. Take care with Titan against the heavy Flier decks - the AI will remove or silence it at first chance. Titan's immunity to Stun makes the Stun-heavy AI decks a lot easier (although be careful of Rebuke). Marley is a solid pick that can create chump blockers every turn while potentially having a Silence at her disposal.

Other Choices: Copperhall Elite

5-Drops
Moonstone Vanguard: Possibly the best non-Smuggler Rare in Defiance (flip a coin between Vanguard and Hojan, Crownbreaker - both can be gross, in different ways). The AI will often attack into Vanguard thinking it has lethal, which can gain you enough life to not only stabilize, but go on the offensive. Another unit that can abuse the Stun-heavy AI deck strategy.

Other Choices: Amilli, Cloudmarshal, Marshal Ironthorn, Serene Meditant, Worldbearer Behemoth

6-Drops
Telut, Queen's Hand: A no-brainer, really. It makes Student and Monk bigger. It provides more power to use Siraf's ability. It clears the board with Chains in play. It fills your board with Pit in play. Also, despite Combrei's "Big Bodies" reputation, the units that cost 6+ power are kind of underwhelming.

Other Choices: Nothing too exciting. Maybe Svetya, Merciful Orene or Vodakhan, Temple Speaker, but neither feels better than Telut.

Card Draw
Seek Power: Combrei doesn't have great low-cost card draw, so I went with extra Fixing here to synergize with the Empower units in the deck.

Other Choices: Ancient Lore, Call for Aid, Inspire, Temple Scribe

Fixing
Secret Pages: When used in conjunction with Student or Monk, Secret Pages becomes a sort of combat trick. It also works rather well with Pit or Chains in play. It can also help to get from 5 to 7 for Telut.

Other Choices: Find the Way, Petition, Trail Maker

Market
Auralian Merchant: No smuggler means choosing between a Merchant with a useful ability or one that doesn't really do anything. Justice also has no way to deal with Relics for the Market.

Other Choices: Winchest Merchant

Miscellaneous
Martyr's Chains: When Chains was first revealed, it feels like everyone focused on the removal portion and figured it was a Control card (including me). Its strength, though, is definitely the buff ability. The cost keeps it from being a top-end finisher for Midrange decks (which is why Korovyat Palace is so good), but including a couple of copies in a deck that wants to play power seems OK. It does a really good job of clearing up board stalls, which tend to happen with Combrei decks in the Gauntlet.

Other Choices: Inquisitor's Blade, Stand Together

Unit Removal
Xenan Initiation: A great removal option in Combrei due to the beefy units, but really good in any deck running Moonstone Guardian (or Sword of Unity, for that matter). Just remember that Killer does not trigger Telut's ability.

Other Choices: Auric Runehammer, Defiance, Desert Marshal, Scorpion Wasp, Stormhalt Knife, Vanquish, Vanquisher's Blade

Power
Power Sources: 37 (25 power, 4 Auralian Merchant, 4 Secret Pages, 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 26 sources of each color (counting Secret Pages and Seek Power as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

Use early unit plays of Xenan Lifespeaker and Dusk Raider to draw out opponent’s removal.
This helps get your threats Direwood Beastcaller, Gorgon Fanatic, and Vara, Vengeance-Seeker to stick to the board.
Every other card is there to push damage and get your threats back on the board.

Overall it’s fun and can get turn 3 explosions from beastcaller, but it can also win late against Winchest.
It does need Into Shadow Campaign for Vara.
You can switch out Desecrate for Annihilate or some more Suffocates.
Crests help with color consistency but aren’t necessary, might switch em out for Diplomatic Seals

Jennev is the worst matchup. Stunning and equivocate hurt our strategy.
Winchest, Combrei Chains are favorable.
Aggro can be a problem but recognizing it and pinging with intervention and favor, then pushing a beastcaller through or getting a Vara to stick on turn 4, help stabilize.

This is my version of TJP Temporal Control for Gauntlet play. Lets take a look at the cards:

Deck Strategy
Find a Merchant. Pull Temporal Distortion out of the Market. Grab the power and influence you need to play it. Start drawing cards until you find a Win Condition (Pit of Lenekta, Sword of the Sky King, The Great Parliament). Most Control decks tend to play a bit slow, and this deck is no different - I've drawn two-thirds of my deck in a game before. I try to mulligan for a Merchant and a Hailstorm, with Temple Scribe being a nice bonus. Otherwise, you just want to hit your influence requirements (double Primal early for sure, double Time by the mid-game and triple Time for Pit, and double Justice by the mid-game and quad Justice for Chains).

Win Conditions
Martyr's Chains: The least necessary of the deck's Win Conditions. Chains can be used to keep the AI's board clear, but it's main purpose is to end the game quickly in combination with Pit or Great Parliament. It can be marketed away if it feels like you don't need it for the game.

Pit of Lenekta: Pit allows you to be a little aggressive using your Owls on defense while also offering some life gain. The nice thing about Pit is that the AI will do everything it can to remove the tokens, but they just. keep. coming. Feel free to market it away if it is drawn early - sometimes Great Parliament is all that is needed to finish the game.

Sword of the Sky King: The finisher of choice in Justice-based Control decks since the very beginning. There are 3 copies in the deck, so it's very easy to market one copy away or place one on the bottom of the deck with Strategize.

The Great Parliament: The main win condition of the deck. Parliament works really well with Temporal, allowing you to snap play flying blockers if you need them, or sneak them in without giving the AI a chance to remove them. I try to hold off on playing Parliament until there is 8 power in play, but sometimes I will play a copy for a single token if necessary. These can also be marketed away early.

Card Draw
Brilliant Idea: It's really easy to draw massive amounts of cards in the late-game with Idea. I've used it on multiple occasions to draw 10 cards. It's purpose is to reload in the late game and find a Win Condition if you're still looking for one.

Call for Aid: I really like this card in Temporal, but it's also been the one card that I've played around with the most. I started with 4 copies, but it can be awkward early if multiple copies are drawn. So I cut it down to 3 copies and ran 2 copies of Honor of Claws while cutting a single copy of Sword. I found this arrangement to be too clunky as a huge chunk of the card draw was suddenly 4 power or more. I cut Honor, went back to 3 copies of Sword, but kept Call for Aid at 3 copies and added another copy of Temple Scribe. At first glance, this card maybe doesn't look special, but having a Power Stone / Temple Scribe combo card is really helpful in a deck with a lot of design options.

Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Temple Scribe: Card draw and life gain attached to a chump blocker. This card has helped out so much in this deck that I added a 4th copy. Since it dies to Hailstorm anyway, if I have to choose, I'll go for double Time influence first to play Scribe, and then work on getting the double Primal for Hailstorm.

Other Choices: Channel the Tempest, Honor of Claws, Vital Arcana, Wisdom of the Elders

Fixing
Petition: There are only 7 sigils in the deck, so I went with Petition over Seek Power. With the key removal each needing double sources of their respective influence, grabbing Crests out of the deck is so valuable.

Secret Pages: While they can help ramp a little early, once Pit or Chains is on the board, Secret Pages turns into a bit of a combat trick. Creating wurm tokens at the end of the AI's turn or enticing an attack and then removing a key AI unit to blow up the AI's board with blocks is really nice. Playing a power with Secret Pages doesn't count towards your 1 power per turn limit either, which can help squeeze out another Owl token.

Other Choices: Seek Power, Trail Maker

Market
Auralian Merchant and Great Valley Smuggler: 8 merchants to make sure you can pull Temporal out of the Market. The ramp from Auralian is nice as well. I feel like this deck will benefit a bit when the Combrei smuggler is released with Set 6.

Other Choices: Jennev Merchant, Winchest Merchant

Unit Removal
Hailstorm: The key to surviving the early game. I always try to have one in my opening hand if I can.

Harsh Rule: Eternal's easy button. Push it when you need it.

Vanquish: I originally had Defiance in this spot, but the addition of Temple Scribe to the deck meant a little less pressure in the early game, and Defiance doesn't do a whole lot late. Vanquish has felt a lot better in this spot.

Other Choices: Defiance, Desert Marshal, Equivocate, Permafrost

Power
Power Sources: 40 (25 power, 4 Auralian Merchant, 3 Call for Aid, 4 Petition and 4 Secret Pages)
Influence: 22 Time sources, 23 Justice sources, 22 Primal sources (counting Diplomatic Seal, Petition, and Secret Pages as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

That being said, don't sleep on Etched Monolith. Being able to heal back up to 25 HP usually means game over.

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Awakened Student and Stormtamer Operative: It's hard to beat Student when it comes to 2-Drops. If not answered early, it can get pretty big, and it's a very nice target for Sword of Unity. Stormtamer Operative is one of those cards that takes advantage of a blind spot with the AI: It doesn't take it's ability into account before using removal. It will continually try and Torch 3-health units. It will continually try to ping 1-health units with Temper and Vara's Favor. It's ridiculous the amount of work Operative does just by sitting on the board.

Other Choices: Dusk Raider, Kothon, the Far-Watcher, Resolute Monk

3-Drops
False Prince and Knight-Chancellor Siraf: False Prince is another blind spot for the AI: It will not target it with removal unless the removal does 5 or more damage. Sometimes the AI will get lucky with a Torch only because the initial plan was to use 2 Torches, but it still ends up Torching a frog, so it's a win in my book (The best is when the AI silences the Prince!). Siraf is a good early game unit, a good target for Killer or Sword of Unity, and can win games late thanks to her ability.

Other Choices: Amaran Stinger, Auric Record Keeper, Hooru Pacifier, Icaria, Valkyrie Captain, Lunar Magus, Skycrag Scalebreaker, Teacher of Humility, Valkyrie Enforcer

4-Drops
Sandstorm Titan and Shelterwing Rider: Titan is a no-brainer in a deck with only one flying unit. Take care with Titan against the heavy Flier decks - the AI will remove or silence it at first chance. Titan's immunity to Stun makes the Stun-heavy AI decks a lot easier (although be careful of Rebuke). Shelterwing Rider doesn't synergize with Titan very well, but it is a big unit that draws removal without killing it, and is the perfect target for Withstand from Korovyat Palace.

Other Choices: Sheriff Marley, Svetya, Orene of Kosul

5-Drops
Cirso, the Great Glutton and Marshal Ironthorn: Always happy to run Cirso - it's my favorite card in Eternal. A perfect target for Killer. Running Ironthorn without anything to ramp into may seem odd, but without much evasion, board stalls can be a reality. For those games where the AI is content to just sit there, Ironthorn offers a one-sided board clear. Ironthorn is actually the 6-Drop selection for the deck, as I didn't really love any of the other choices, so he certainly could be swapped out rather easily.

Other Choices: Alhed, Mount Breaker, Eilyn, Clan Mother, Jotun Feast-Caller, Moonstone Vanguard, Serene Meditant, Svetya, Merciful Orene, Telut, Queen's Hand, The Great Parliament, Worldbearer Behemoth

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Other Choices: Ancient Lore, Call for Aid (I really like this card!), Temple Scribe

Fixing
Seek Power: Most of my Midrange builds do not run 1-Drops because, for the most part, they are underwhelming. That leaves Seek Power as the best solution for Fixing, as it can give the deck something to do turn 1.

Other Choices: Secret Pages, Trail Maker

Market
Great Valley Smuggler: Even without any Relics in the deck, this is a great option for the market due to her stats. Also the only merchant currently available to Time-Justice-Primal (can't they just leak the names of the other 5 tri-faction groupings?) that allows for both Sword of Unity and Korovyat Palace in the Market.

Other Choices: Auralian Merchant, Jennev Merchant, Winchest Merchant

Miscellaneous
Petition: I generally don't like to run fewer than 30 power sources in a deck. There are also a few double influence combinations that can be difficult to grab. That said, these could be swapped out for just about anything else if you wanted.

Other Choices: Infinite Hourglass, Mirror Image, Pit of Lenekta, Stand Together

Unit Removal
Xenan Initiation: A great choice in any deck running Time stat sticks. Also makes Cirso extra gross. Just don't cast it on False Prince.

Other Choices: Defiance, Desert Marshal, Equivocate, Martyr's Chains, Permafrost, Scorpion Wasp, Stormhalt Knife, Vanquish

Power
Power Sources: 31 (25 power, 2 Petition, 4 Seek Power)
Influence: 22 Time sources, 22 Justice sources, 16 Primals sources (counting Diplomatic Seal, Petition, and Seek Power as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.
Janky crownroach deck with shadow goodstuff. Don't use if you like winning.

Deck filled with cards designed to kill units of all sizes.Mostly units with life steal ability. Priority with this deck should be to kill units first, then summon units to move in for the kill. I put Hero Of the People in this deck because it can copy abilities of other units played after it. I will be improving it as I get cards I feel it needs.

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Ripknife Assassin and Stormtamer Operative: Ripknife is a really flexible 2-Drop that can be used aggressively or defensively, and it doesn't feel too awful to draw later in the game. It's a toss-up if the AI dislikes Fliers or Deadly units more, and so it will sling removal at it, which brings up the other choice for the 2-Drop slot. Stormtamer Operative is one of those cards that takes advantage of a blind spot with the AI: It doesn't take it's ability into account before using removal. It will continually try and Torch 3-health units. It will continually try to ping 1-health units with Temper and Vara's Favor. It's ridiculous the amount of work Operative does just by sitting on the board. That being said, drawing it late isn't great, so there are only 3 copies in the deck.

Other Choices: Blackhall Warleader, Dusk Raider, Kerendon Steward, Resolute Monk, Tavia, Lethrai Raidleader

3-Drops
Ayan, the Abductor and False Prince: Ayan is another flexible unit that can be used to remove annoying early units, and the ultimate can be useful later in the game against removal heavy decks. False Prince is another blind spot for the AI: It will not target it with removal unless the removal does 5 or more damage. Sometimes the AI will get lucky with a Torch only because the initial plan was to use 2 Torches, but it still ends up Torching a frog, so it's a win in my book. (The best is when the AI silences the Prince!)

Other Choices: Amaran Stinger, Auric Interrogator, Lunar Magus, Rhysta, Acantha's Herald, Skycrag Scalebreaker, Teacher of Humility

4-Drops
Sandstorm Titan and Vara, Vengeance-Seeker: Two of the best, if not the best, 4-drops in the game. Take care with Titan against the heavy Flier decks - the AI will remove or silence it at first chance. Titan's immunity to Stun makes the Stun-heavy AI decks a lot easier (although be careful of Rebuke).

Other Choices: Rindra, the Duskblade

5-Drops
Moonstone Vanguard: Possibly the best non-Smuggler Rare in Defiance (flip a coin between Vanguard and Hojan, Crownbreaker - both can be gross, in different ways). The AI will often attack into Vanguard thinking it has lethal, which can gain you enough life to not only stabilize, but go on the offensive. Another unit that can abuse the Stun-heavy AI deck strategy.

Other Choices: Cirso, the Great Glutton (my favorite card in Eternal - swapping in Cirso requires adding some Killer to the deck, as Cirso with Killer is one of the grossest comobos in the game), Jotun Feast-Caller, Worldbearer Behemoth

6-Drops
Black-Sky Harbinger: Not the most powerful 6-Drop available, but one that does a pretty decent job clearing board stalls while also gaining you some health. Harbinger wrecks the Grenadin decks, as well as a lot of the go-wide decks, and can help shore up the air defense in case Titan is a no-show. Probably the easiest card to swap out of the deck, though (which is why there are only 3 copies).

Other Choices: Caiphus, Wandering King, Eilyn, the Rising Storm, any of the other choices from the 5-Drops

Card Draw
Strategize: My go-to for card draw in any Primal deck. The ability to get dead cards out of your hand is so good. I'm honestly surprised this card doesn't require double Primal influence.

Other Choices: Call for Aid (I really like this card!), Cull the Deck, Dark Return, Temple Scribe

Fixing
Seek Power: Most of my Midrange builds do not run 1-Drops because, for the most part, they are underwhelming. That leaves Seek Power as the best solution for Fixing, as it can give the deck something to do turn 1.

Other Choices: Petition, Secret Pages, Trail Maker

Market
Great Valley Smuggler: Even without any Relics in the deck (although you can find them), this is a great option for the market due to her stats. Auralian Merchant can also grab all of the cards in my Market, however, if you value the ramp.

Other Choices: Auralian Merchant, Ebon Dune Smuggler, Jennev Merchant, Kerendon Merchant

Miscellaneous
Auralian Cargo: The deck requires double Time and double Shadow fairly early (and double Primal if you want Cirso out of the Market), and Cargo helps out with that, while also contributing some extra draws once you find the influence you need. Even if the choices aren't great, the cards Cargo pulls are great choices for Market swaps.

Other Choices: Mirror Image

Unit Removal
Feeding Time: My personal favorite among Eternal's removal options. Renders Dark Return and Stirring Sand strategies moot.

Other Choices: Annihilate, Deathstrike, Desecrate, Display of Knowledge, Dizo's Office, Equivocate, In Cold Blood, Permafrost, Rindra's Choice, Scorpion Wasp

A ramp deck with Pit of Lenekta and Brilliant Idea as the payoffs. Temporal Distortion is a great ramp card that allows you to play your ramp on your turn and Idea on theirs.

Torgov's Trading Post was put in for the fun Arcanum Hourglass ramp combo. The large amounts of card draw allow you to find the Titans from Call the Ancients and Torgov frequently appears if you play it on 2 against a deck without 2 drops. The power discards are also extremely helpful in preventing your hand from getting clogged with power after casting Brilliant Idea.

This deck is not great but I find it amusing. I've managed to play Pit after only playing three power cards.

A modified version of an Argenport Control list that I saw Sunyveil playing on stream right before the Homecoming campaign was released.

The vast majority of this list came directly from Sunyveil. I did make one small change:

I removed 2 copies of Auric Runehammer and 1 copy each of Defiance and Suffocate, and added 4 copies of Inquisitor Makto. I'm not sure the deck NEEDS them, but they do add yet another layer of value to the deck, at least in Gauntlet.

I was really impressed with this list - it's a very smooth-feeling Control list with Regent's Tomb and Dizo's Office generating a ton of mid- and late-game value.

I'd link to Sunyveil's original list, but it doesn't look like it's been posted on Eternal Warcry.

Power
Power Sources: 38 (26 power, 4 Lost Scroll, 4 Regent's Tomb, 4 Vara's Favor)

I tend to build my Midrange Gauntlet decks using a very linear shell: 8 1- or 2-Drops, 8 3-Drops, 8 4-Drops, 4 5-Drops, 4 6-Drops, and 4 each of Card Draw, Fixing, Market and Unit Removal, with the remainder of the deck filled with whatever I think the deck can use. With that in mind, I thought I would go over the card choices here:

2-Drops
Blackhall Warleader and Ripknife Assassin: At the very worst, both of these units will draw a Torch out of the AI. If Warleader hits face even just once, the snowball effect is ridiculous. Ripknife is just a really solid 2-Drop that can be used aggressively or defensively, and it doesn't feel too awful to draw later in the game.

Other Choices: Fenris Nightshade, Hojan, Crownbreaker (only one trigger for his Renown), Kerendon Steward, Tavia, Lethrai Raidleader

3-Drops
Rhysta, Acantha's Herald and Valkyrie Enforcer: Rhysta is here to help with fixing while also providing an aggressive early-game unit. I wasn't sold on her due to her inability to block, but I definitely see her value now. I like her here a lot better than something like Vara's Favor. Enforcer is the best Justice 3-Drop, and it's not really close. I never feel bad playing Enforcer on curve without any targets for the ability.

Other Choices: Auric Interrogator, Icaria, Valkyrie Captain (Similar to Rhysta but I like Rhysta better because the AI goes out of its way to remove Icaria before her ability can be activated)

4-Drops
Vara, Vengeance-Seeker: Vara is an easy pick. The AI almost always sacrifices a unit to keep Vara small, which can get rid of some really annoying units. Unfortunately, the best Justice 4-Drop is Sheriff Marley, which doesn't work very well with Vara. I initially had Impending Doom in the deck, but Rhysta into Impending Doom ended up being a good way to get steamrolled by the AI. Without any other really decent choices, I opted to make a change to the shell instead (see Miscellaneous below).

Other Choices: Crownwatch Traitor, Howling Kurtarr, Impending Doom

5-Drops
Inquisitor Makto: Another easy choice. If Makto can avoid silence (or Feeding Time), it's usually game over. The AI will do everything it can to remove Makto, and doesn’t mind tossing multiple removal spells at him. Just a huge value generator.

Other Choices: Amilli, Cloudmarshal, Marshal Ironthorn, Tavrod, Auric Broker

6-Drops
Caiphus, Wandering King: Just the best big unit choice in Argenport. The lack of influence requirements is a plus, and sometimes the RNG rolls are just gross (Deadly, Overwhelm, and Quickdraw? OK!).

Other Choices: Grinva, Judge of Battles, Svetya, Merciful Orene (only two Justice units in the deck), Zelia, the Vain (she does have synergy with Ripknife Assasin, but tends to be a little too slow)

Card Draw
Cull the Deck: The best choice in a faction pairing that doesn't have a lot of options. An argument can be made for Dark Return. Reanimating either Vara or Caiphus is huge value (and potentially game-winning when it comes to Caiphus). Ultimately, I chose the option that is a little more flexible that also helps find the Maktos with Destiny.

Other Choices: Dark Return, Devour

Fixing
Seek Power: Most of my Midrange builds do not run 1-Drops because, for the most part, they are underwhelming. That leaves Seek Power as the best solution for Fixing, as it can give the deck something to do turn 1.

Other Choices: Copperhall Bracers, Lost Scroll, Petition (not enough non-Sigil power to excuse the extra cost), Privilege of Rank, Vara's Favor

Market
Hidden Road Smuggler: Both mono-color Merchants in Argenport are rather underwhelming units, so I sacrificed a little bit of consistency for a better unit. The only other real option is Kerendon Merchant, because I like something in my markets to deal with Relics, and Justice doesn't have any options in that area.

Other Choices: Kerendon Merchant, Winchest Merchant

Miscellaneous
These cards are here to help the deck out, but they're not vital to the success of the deck, so there are only 3 copies of each.

Regent's Tomb: This is played strictly for Lingering Influence, so that you can guarantee the 5th power for Makto. Swear Vengeance is nice on a lot of the units, but not vital, and a bit of a waste if Makto is the only unit on the board when it resolves. Sabotage is a bit of a dud in Gauntlet. The AI does not hold spells, and the card tends to miss more often than not unless it's played very early. I'm never really happy to play the card in Gauntlet. Elias is a nice bonus, but nothing I go out of my way to protect the site for, and the passive ability is OK here, but nothing special. Absorbing an attack from the AI is a nice perk, however.

Suffocate: It might seem weird to see these here instead of something like Annihilate or Desecrate, but they are here for one reason: to open up the board in the early game to allow Blackhall Warleader to hit the AI. One or two hits from a Warleader is enough to snowball any match out of control. They can be placed in the Market later in the game if needed.

Other Choices: Bloodletter, Dark Return, Devour, Madness

Unit Removal
Slay: As vanilla as unit removal gets, but the best choice as well. The only other removal I would consider here is Desecrate, which is really good, but the extra cost in both influence and health total isn't worth 1 power, in my opinion.

Other Choices: Annihilate, Auric Runehammer, Deathstrike, Defiance, Desecrate, Vanquish

Power[/p]
Power Sources: 36 (25 power, 4 Seek Power, 4 Rhysta, 3 Regent's Tomb)
Influence: 24 sources of each color (counting Seek Power as a source for each color)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

This is my Mono Time list, there are many like it, but this one is mine

Hit Master with this list, seems good enough to be running a positive winrate around rank 500 at the moment.

How to play: Try to get an opening hand with 3 power cards in it, power screw can be real with this deck sometimes. Ramp into your big minions to out tempo the opponent and win by sheer force. Get Alhed from the market asap and just let him sit out to buff draws. Don't overextend against removal pile decks, playing one big minion each turn on curve is enough pressure to win, you are running near 50 creatures thanks to Amber Monument. Don't be afraid to use your Xenan Initiations to maintain tempo, the best targets for them are the Dawnwalkers (it sticks), a deadly Scorpion for a one shot, or on a Worldbearer/Moonstone to trigger their abilities.

If you need some graveyard hate you can throw Lumen Reclaimer in the market.

Now with Primal's Sandstorm Titan!

Copy Ruckus Rouser 2+ times, play a huge Clutch of Talons, fill the board with dragons, merchant for Kaleb's Choice with the 8 power generated from Clutch or play a Xo of the Endless Hoard if you're not worried about sweepers.

The deck also has a Plan B in beating down with 4-cost 6/8 Half-Overwhelm Half-Aegis Ambush units. Yes, Primal has found its very own rival to Sandstorm Titan and Vara, Vengeance-Seeker in playing one of your myriad copy effects on Glacier Shaper. Shaper provides a solid blocker vs aggro by itself, but when you get to ambush in a 6 Attack and 8 Health mixture of Ice Beast and Shaman with a Sudden Schism... kisses fingers.

Mass Entomancy targeting an active Rouser along with other units can double your power, setting up a lethal Flame Blast or massive Clutch. Bottoms Up serves a similar role and can act as a finisher with Ixtun Merchant's or a Glacial Monstrosity's Overwhelm, a Humbug, or a Screamed Rouser. Entomancy also has utility as a bad removal spell to deal with Sandstorm Titan, Telut, Queen's Hand, or any other unit preventing your dragons from closing the game. Flame Blast can also be pointed at an active Rouser to set up larger Clutches or a Bottoms Up.

Haunting Scream lets you play out a Rouser on 4 without concern for its safety. If it gets killed you can scream it back to go for the combo on 5 power if you have a Mirror Image or on 6 power with Sudden Schism or Clutchmate. You're in trouble if Rouser gets silenced or transformed, so use caution around Valkyrie Enforcer, Statuary Maiden, and Feeding Time. You can also Scream a Merchant at the end of the combo to grab Clutch, Blast, Choice, or even Skycrag Banner if you need the 3rd Primal or 3rd Fire influence for the wincon in-hand. Regardless of their size, Glacial Monstrosities cost 3-power and can be screamed, so making a monstrous monstrosity with Bottoms Up or Entomancy and screaming+copying can be a nice line to finish games.

While the deck is very fun to play and most games feel close, I still haven't found a build that can sustain a 50% win rate, so don't play this if you want to climb the ladder. Unfortunately, the deck's win rate will drop further if it gains popularity and opponents learn to make better market decisions and stop wasting fast speed removal on Merchants.

My basic redraw advice would be to redraw any hand that doesn't have a 3-drop and access to a Rouser. I would also keep Rouserless hands with a Shaper, a copy effect, a second unit and 3 power. Go for PPP before FFF when playing Seek Power since the Flame Blast kill is much harder to pull off than a sizable Clutch. Haunting Scream is your only Shadow card, so it is often correct to seek for your second (sometimes even third) Primal or Fire influence before your first Shadow influence.

Against aggro you need to play turn 3 Merchant into turn 4 Rouser and pray they waste their torch on the merchant or turn 3 Glacier Shaper into a copy effect on turn 4. If you can't play a unit on 3, you might be forced to block with your Rouser to survive, and that spells doom unless you have the Scream/Mirror Image immediate follow up.

The deck matches up decently with other removal-light combo decks like Chainbrei and Talir/Voda. Both decks can have access to Desert Marshal, which will mess you up, but, when undisrupted, I believe this deck goes off on turn 5 more consistently. Telut and/or Sword of Unity plus Icaria, Valkyrie Captain gives Chainbrei an out to a large Clutch, but Entomancy can help you fight through.

Against Harsh Rule control decks, pressure with Merchants and Shapers when you can and take your time to set up a large Clutch with Kaleb's Choice up or try for the Flame Blast kill before Cobalt Waystone comes online. Against Regent's Tomb decks it can be smart to hold a merchant until the combo turn to avoid getting your Clutch, Blast, or Choice sabotaged. Playing a smaller Clutch to pressure and bait out a Rule can be better than emptying your hand to play the max number of dragons if you can't protect them.

If you suspect the opponent is holding up Torch or Annihilate and you're not under immense pressure, merchant for Kaleb's Choice before going for the Ruckus combo. You get the power from Rouser's trigger immediately after casting a copy effect, so you'll have the power to cast Choice when your opponent tries to kill your Rouser in response to the copy spell. If you have to go for the combo into an opponent holding up fast removal like Equivocate, play your most expensive copy effect first as you still get the power from the Rouser trigger. Clutch at 8-12 power can still win the game or stall it out long enough for a second try at the big combo. It can even be correct to lead off with Flame Blasting or Humbugging your Rouser if your opponent's fast removal is face-up. Any copy effects left in hand are good at making additional dragons or "Snowstorm Titans" post-Clutch.

End of Hostilities is usually just a Mirror Image with Warp that gives you +6 power with Rouser as the deck has no tribute enablers, but keep an eye out for any lines where suiciding a merchant or spent Rouser enables a double copy on the best unit on the board. Flame Blasting your Rouser activates tribute and can generate the power to do things like play Xo and immediately double copy it. The deck only has 2 copies of EoH because a hand with two EoH goes off 2 turns slower than a hand with any other copy effect and a single EoH, but the extra 2 power can really matter when trying for the Flame Blast kill.

If the combo pieces don't come together, sometimes you can buy time by casting 6-power Clutches on Jennev Merchant. If your hand lacks Clutch or a lethal Flame Blast, you can try to get there with a 10-power Xo+Mirror Image Xo turn.

The card cost increase from Amplify works differently for spells and weapons. Amplified spells increase in effective cost, so Mass Entomancy on Rouser can double your power, whereas amplified weapons do not increase in effective cost, so Clutch of Talons only ever gives 8 power when triggering Rouser or a 4/4 monstrosity when attached to a Shaper. DWD has confirmed that these disparate Amplify interactions between card types are intended and not a bug.

Props to Almost's WWH combo decks for the inspiration to include Haunting Scream.

Small disclaimer: I don't play Ranked, I'm a total casual and I usually only play Gauntlet. That being said, I've had a lot of fun with this janky deck, even in Versus, so I thought I'd post it. Suggestions to improve appreciated :D

So I've named the deck Death By Inches. The idea is to ping your opponent to death with small amounts of damage. So far not so original, I guess. The way I do it is by combining lots and lots of Grenadin with the Disassembler armed with a Hunter's Harpoon. Every time a Grenadin dies, the Disassembler pings the opponent, drawing you a card, allowing you to draw more Grenadin to send to their deaths, pinging the opponent with the Disassembler, drawing more cards, rinse and repeat.

There are some contingency plans, of course, in case the combo doesn't immediately materialize (or simply gets removed by the opponent). For more card draw you can always Devour your Grenadin (bonus if the Disassembler/Harpoon combo is out) or use Cauldron Cookbook.

For more pinging action, there's Ticking Grenadin, Tripwire Grenadin, Calderan Gunsmith, and Icicle Marksman. The latter also works with the Harpoon in a pinch as there are a decent amount of spells in the deck.

Sparkbot is an okay blocker and a way of getting another Grenadin on the board.

Ixtun Merchant is there to get your combo together.

Signal Flare is probably an odd choice over Torch, but I like the scout effect.

The tactics of the deck consist of always pinging the opponent's face. I generally don't care about the board they're building as long as they're not able to Overwhelm or outnumber my units. I send my Grenadin to their deaths, one at a time, and hope they'll get stomped on by a bigger creature or hit the opponent's face, either is good. If the opponent attacks, I block with as many units as needed, always keeping the Disassember safe, and just crank out more of them.

It's too janky to be competitive but I do think this deck is a lot of fun to play :D

Thanks for reading!

I made this gunslinger deck out of justice cards, but it doesn't contain just gunslingers. I got some Valkyries for flying units, life stealing units & 4 Rolant the iron Fist for nearly unit invincibility.

A Control deck that plays a several 1-of relics that are situationally useful and relies on Display of Knowledge to tutor for them when needed. Having 4 of those and 4 copies of Display of Vision gives the deck a lot of flexibility, and DoV allows you to ramp early and in the lategame it's a Fast way to trigger Empower and potentially give you face-Aegis with Cobalt Waystone.
I tried running Temporal Distortion too, but Martyr's Chains is better at finishing the game.

A few things that aren't optimal and should probably be changed:
* the manabase: having 18 crests and 7 waystones means that most power in the deck is depleted, which means the curve is delayed by one turn; influence requirements are also quite heavy (TTTJJJJPPPPSSS for everything, but the deck functions on TJJPPS when you aren't looking for finishers)
* the Merchant-Market setup: having 8 merchants is nice, but not that useful since there's no must-have card in the market and all cards there are reactive (with the exception of Brilliant Idea, which works as a follow-up finisher once we have an Empower-relic in play, so it's "reactive" to your own plays)
* some relics in the deck (Auric Runehammer, Eternity Core, Citywide Ban) are rarely tutored for
* Channel the Tempest is a card I loved before the nerf, and I want to have it in the deck, but I very rarely find myself playing it


I've had a suprisingly decent winrate with this deck in low-Gold (7W 7L, with 1-1 being turn1 concessions).

So this is my latest waste of shiftstone. I find it difficult to pilot but REALLY rewarding to win with. Your basic plan vs Aggro is to control them and win with card advantage. Against Midrange decks, dropping aegis threats and playing clutch with multiple Amps is the plan and vs Control you rain of frogs their strongest play (merchant, Vara, Grasp etc.) And win with Aegis.
Open to suggestions, I feel like there's a good deck here but it's not quite there yet. Sideboard is my current considerations for cards.
Edit: chopped and changed a few things. The deck really only loses to bad draws against most matchups, but notable weaknesses are anything that dodges both hailstorm and vanquish (Statuatory Maiden[card], Lunar Magus etc) Crownwatch Standard is better than Hojan as we rarely need the lifesteal before turn 5 and it's fast and harder to predict. A hooru merchant would really help the deck and get it out of it's 1.5-2 tier standings atm.
Edit: Runehammer is what the deck has been missing for those 4 health threats (maiden, Magus etc.) After some streamlining changes and putting in linebreakers shield (I haven't seen much Reanimator in masters) the deck wins most matchups that aren't fjs pile with maidens varas and riza-hns.
Edits for metagame. Hurler provides snowball vs aggro and a body vs control so worthy inclusion. Banner in the market fixes influence and gets us to 4 power in a screw scenario.
Edit for Homecoming. Deck consistently crushing most opponents thanks to palace and Big Svetya. Throne warden is a placeholder for Omen in the market atm.
Edit: the previous version was riding on homecoming hype and poor decks in masters due to it, so I overhauled it and built this. A more midrange-oriented deck than controlling. The deck has come a long way from previous lists and is finally good imo. Probably going to edit it again soon when it bombs in an odd game though lol.

Matchups

Skycraggro or Yeti
Very favorable, we have a lot of lilinkers and removals, can be though when they have a lot of torhces and permafrost, but vara's favor is very strong and all your cards generally deal very well with theirs

Rakano Aggro

Similar to the one mentioned above, but probably easier because they are a bit slower, Memory Dredger is quite strong because it dodges Torch and Vanquish

Chainbrei

Almost unwinnable, I think that the best bet is to kill everything that they use to ramp and try to kill them as fast as possible

Reanimator

Very hard, but you can steal some wins with turn 2 Dreamsnatcher

Jennev

Favorable, I think that you can outgrind them very easily, especially now that they play at most 1 Zal Chi

Jund

50/50 you need a fast start and you need to make them go for suboptimal lines, if you do that you can win the late game value game, but if you arrive to that stage even they generally take over, be aware of marty chains. The market is very stacked for this matchup, every card is good basically.

A budget dino deck built with synergy in mind. The main idea behind this deck is to play big dino units and give them killer to remove threats.

The only off-tribe unit in the deck is Amber Acolyte and I am thinking of replacing it with Seek Power.

This deck started out as an attempt to build an Auralian Haunting Scream deck shortly after the release of Set 5 (Defiance) that tried to take advantage of Cykalis and Dread. It didn't work. Dread just never felt anything other than clunky. So, when I went to re-tool the deck, I noticed that the 4-Drop slot in Auralian had 3 REALLY good options, so I took the deck in a different direction, and this is the result. Lets take a look at the cards:

Deck Strategy
Fairly straightforward for a Control deck: Try and stay above water removing the AI's board while searching for the pieces needed to apply pressure. I usually play the deck rather defensively until I can find a unit (I prefer Rindra first, then Vara, and try to save Cykalis for lethal) as well as some form of reanimation (if I can, I Scream first, and then Dark Return, as the unit will retain the Flying and Charge from the Scream). Removal from the AI actually helps the deck's strategy, Silence isn't very fun, while Steward of the Past and Reality Warden are jerks. As with most Control decks, the Mulligan is one of the biggest portions of any game played with the deck. Look for Fixing, Unit Removal, and possibly some Card Draw early on, and double Primal and double Shadow are the priority for the first few turns. If Time influence is elusive early on, it's not a game killer, as it's only needed for Cykalis and Banish.

Win Conditions
Cykalis, the Burning Sand: The finisher in the deck. Since the AI spams it's removal, it never seems to have any hard removal left over for Cykalis. Cykalis and Mirror Image is fun, and Dark Return on Cykalis is great. I try not to use Cykalis as a target for Haunting Scream if I can help it, though.

Rindra, the Duskblade: If there is a choice, Rindra should be the first unit played. It will immediately draw a removal answer from the AI if it has one; the Nightfall means you draw a card at the very least; and Rindra is the best unit in the deck to use Haunting Scream on thanks to the Lifesteal. Playing Rindra and then following it up the next turn with a Haunting Scream and Mirror Image applies a lot of pressure while helping to stabilize your health total.

Vara, Vengeance-Seeker: If Cykalis and Rindra are the gas, Vara is the value. Any deck running Vara has to seriously consider using some form of reanimation because of her ability. Haunting Scream with Vara is just filthy, as the AI will sacrifice a unit to her ability if it can, even if it's a potential blocker. I've actually had the AI sacrifice Scorpion Wasp in response to Vara's ability, which is just silly. Getting rid of Aegis is the key to victory against a couple of the AI decks.

Card Draw
Dark Return and Strategize: Pretty easy choices. Dark Return makes the deck go, and Strategize is best card draw option in most Primal decks.

Other Choices: Call for Aid, Honor of Claws (This card might be good here, but the power cost makes me pause a little)

Fixing
Auralian Cargo and Petition: Don't hesitate to use Cargo to pull power whenever you can, as you're very unlikely to find double Time influence very early and the cards it generates aren't as important as finding the Primal and Shadow influence the deck needs. Petition is the pick over Seek Power here to better help find Time influence when it's needed (2 Sigil sources of Time vs. 6 Crest sources of Time).

Market
Jennev Merchant and Kerendon Merchant: I usually only run 4 Merchants, but I went with 6 here because the Win Condition package of units, reanimation, and Mirror Image took up a little more room in the deck then is typically the case in my Control decks. 6 Merchants helps to grab a Scream when you need one while also giving access to more Unit Removal options.

Miscellanous
Haunting Scream: Again, if Dark Return is the value, Scream is the gas. I run 3 copies main with the other tucked away in the Market.

Mirror Image: No Eternal deck is complete without some sort of greed. Mirror Image isn't necessary in the deck, but it does lead to some fun burst damage. If you're not familiar with the interaction, using Mirror Image on a unit brought back from the void with Haunting Scream creates a copy of the unit with Charge and Flying, but the copy is not sacrificed at the end of your turn. Since it's pure greed, there are only 2 copies in the deck, and I really wouldn't want more than 3.

Unit Removal
Annihilate: Pretty standard unit removal choice for Shadow. Instead of 4 copies of one or the other, I went with 2 copies each of Annihilate and Rindra's Choice. There are a couple of AI decks where Annihilate is always a dead card, and Rindra's Choice doesn't do anything against the mono-color AI decks. If it's a dead card, it's usually my first choice to Market away.

Banish: A really flexible removal option. In addition to dealing with the always annoying (unless it's on your side of the board) Sandstorm Titan, it also gets rid of Xenan Obelisk. It also helps against the Armory and Sentinel AI matchups. I personally like to run 3 copies in the main and 1 in the Market.

Feeding Time: The best hard removal option that doesn't have a drawback associated with it. In Cold Blood and Deathstrike are also very good, but Annihilate and Banish can sort of fill the same role as Deathstrike, while Feeding Time is better in more matchups than In Cold Blood. The cost can make it a little clunky, so only 2 copies in the main (I like 1 in the Market as well).

Hailstorm: The only defense against pure Aggro and go-wide strategies. I only play 3 copies total because the life gain from Rindra and Vara usually means that the deck can race if it needs to. There is an argument to be made that having 1 in the Market is wrong because only a single Merchant can grab it. It's possible swapping Hailstorm for something like Rindra makes the deck better.

Rindra's Choice: The yin to Annihilate's yang. Feel free to Market this card if the matchup renders it unplayable.

Other Choices: Desecrate, Equivocate

Power
Power Sources: 33 (25 power, 4 Auralian Cargo, 4 Petition)
Influence: 16 Time sources, 25 Primal sources, 22 Shadow sources (counting Auralian Cargo and Petition as a source for each)

Market Choices
I tend to build my Markets in a specific way (Win Condition, Unit Removal, Fixing, Relic Removal and a Wild Card spot). I never assume a Market for a deck is set in stone and neither should you - feel free to build it however you want.

My current love of Defiance. This list is inspired by LightsOutAce's Kennadins list; however, I'm testing more maindeck Bore because the card is total gas right now with Ixtun Merchant. Edit 3: Final edit for a while, I'm quite happy with this list, dropped an Assembly Line for the fourth Cell, running quite nice.

Control deck that curves out on turn 4, that's right you can control and top curve drop is a 4.

Deck Design
Control is about efficiency and card advantage. We have both, cards that are many for one and card advantage mechanism.
We utilize efficiency of Grenadins with sacrifice outlet of Shadow faction.

Units
- 4 Grenadin Drone is a great example of 2 for 1 efficiency, it places 2 units on the battlefield, where unit count matters in this deck for multiple reasons.
- 4 Dark Wisp card advantage and sacrifice for value target, it will be consumed by Ravenous Thornbeast to grow it scary or by Devour to draw 3 cards and gain some life, while chump-blocking opponent's threats.
- 4 Flamefang Charmer another example of card advantage, coz by getting in you get another quite useful creature, more that that you "draw" it that does benefit from Warpainter.
- 4 Obsidian Golem is another food for our sacrifice cards that can replace itself with same stats.
- 4 Scrap Hound this is our early agro drop and big mid game threat, biggest from available.
- 4 Ravenous Thornbeast another example of good midgame threat.
- 4 Lethrai Instigator or repeatable buff effect for the crowd we have. Other benefit is 4 life, it dodges most of removal.

Spells
- 2 Combust one of the best removal in format, more than that it's unconditional removal.
- 4 Torch reason Fire faction is most popular in this format. Pure efficiency.
- 2 Into the Furnace that's our secret tech, coz most of removal hit for 3, but this one will hit for 4 and opponent wouldn't be prepared for that.
- 2 Execute another example of removal, it's hard to use thou, coz you suppose to target exhausted creature, many think that you suppose to wait till creature will attack you, but you probably forget, that when creature blocks, it also exhausts. So attacking with bunch of 1/1s into some huge threats makes opponent relax and make mistakes.
- 4 Devour card advantage and way to efficiently champ-block with our small creatures.
- 4 Manufacture card advantage mechanism, generates pure value especially if you remember that it has Warp, so basically you can and should play it from top of your deck.
- 4 Dark Return helps to return our big beaters like Ravenous Thornbeast or Scrap Hound.

Pretty sweet games i had and pack of removal really helps to break even boards.

Don't forget to leave a like.

Control for Winter Welcome
Torrential Downpour is seems amazing. It makes this deck work against low to the ground decks and especially Grenadin Drone.
Frost Talisman is game winning in the late game. Very similar to moondial.
Wormstone is very slow, but the wurm is quite hard to answer.
Infused Guardian is a good bomb and pledge is great.
Not sure what best damage spells are. Torch is obviously great. Lightning strike is also great, but does allow a warcry. Conflagrate seems better than purify since common units are simpler. Meteor gets 4 toughness units. Magma Javelin can attack players, but is otherwise worse than Meteor.
Trailblaze adds consistency but I am not sure about it.
Archive curator provides a silence, which is diminished but can hit Corrupted Umbren. It's a good blocker.

Suggestions welcome
My notes on the deck, with video footage
Play Caiphus or Vara. Copy them a lot. Quicksilver Mirror is a very fun top end. Sudden Schism is seriously good.

A fun little deck that combines some of my personal favourite cards in the game: Chalice, Crown and Hero of the People.

Chalice and Moondial are your main draw engines here as usual.
You draw the Hero and play it with some cheap creatures with essential skills like Aegis, Flying, Endurance and Lifesteal.
Don't forget to buff your Hero with Chalice BEFORE you play other creatures next to it. If it goes above 2 strength with skills, you can't buff it with Chalice anymore.

If you enter the late game, you will be relying on Crown to keep the pressure on your opponent with small but dangerous creatures, or simply chump block with them until you draw something game-ending like Double Damage, Echo or Destiny.

Borderlands Waykeeper is slightly better than Silverwing Familiar or Crownwatch Paladin for Aegis imo because it is such a good aggro blocker. Plus you need some Primal creatures. There's too many Justice creatures in this deck as is.

Shelterwing Rider can be a big blocker and attacker with Aegis, but can also be buffed with Chalice when it loses its Aegis.

Market: Lumen Reclaimer is a minor insurance policy in case the game goes on for too long. But you probably won't need it. Passage of Eons was surprisingly helpful against Revenge and weapon decks (although it's probably too expensive to play against hyper aggro Rakano decks). Cirso's Choice protects you from relic destruction and it's the only damaging spell that can be drawn with Auralian Merchant, in case your opponent plays a bunch of Grenadins.

This deck is far from perfect and it needs some work. So please leave a comment with suggestions!

Here's a version of Cheap Bait - Which I'm now calling Meme Scream, I guess? This is the version I'm having the most fun with right now. I had to cut Crimson Firemaw, because he was always eating removal on play and never got his effect to go off.

The deck wants to keep a Stoneshaker in the opening hand, if possible, because that brings a lot of your power minions down to flashpoints. Gorgon Fanatic can be brought back with Dredger afterwards, and Bait becomes Screamable. Once you hit two of the Stoneshakers, you become able to scream Caiphus, which is *Chef Kiss.*

EDIT: It was getting hard in the current meta to recycle Pyroknight's Ult, so I switched it with Lifespeaker. Lifespeaker also helps Caiphus gain skills, which reduces a bit of the randomness he presents. Also added a couple of Quarry for more reliable draw / added cost reduction.

#Description (!whatis Unstable Rush):
Unstable Rush is a meme deck that has somehow managed to achieve measurable amounts of success while also being totally ridiculous. The player's goal is to cheat out North-Wind Herald, Sindok, Rage Incarnate, or Lurking Sanguar. The turn after, the power cost of each resets back to normal. At this point, the player can play Unstable Form to upgrade the unit to a better one that wouldn't normally be achievable that early in the game. The backup plan is basically Skycrag beatdown with a go wide strategy of 4 strength charge units... For more info, ask ScoreWin

#Gotchas:
- The Power Cost of a Conditionally Free Unit will remain 0 until the end of turn. Wait to play Unstable Form until the following turn or you will end up with a Random 1 Power Unit.
- North-Wind Herald will take into account the Unstable Form that targets it. Make sure that Unstable Form is the first spell used that turn and that you do not Unstable Form more than one North-Wind Herald a turn.

#Market Strategy:
- Watch the Market in action!
- Trail Stories can be fetched and immediately played on another 1 cast spell... which is then played... which triggers North-Wind Herald free activation. Total Power Cost: 3
- Sindok, Rage Incarnate can be fetched and played the same turn if enough damage has been dealt.
- Warhelm can be fetched to allow Ixtun Merchant to immediately attack for 4 damage.
- Bore can be fetched to free any units bound by Permafrost. NOTE: You can cast Bore repeatedly to activate North-Wind Herald.
- Stonescar Banner can be fetched as a fail-safe to play any Lurking Sanguars in hand.
